{{Infobox recurring event | name= 100th Anniversary of the Estonian Republic | native_name = ''Eesti Vabariik 100'' | image = File:Estonian Guard Battalion on parade-902227.jpeg | image_size = 500px | caption = The [[Guard Battalion (Estonia)|Guard Battalion]] during the military parade. | location= {{flag|Estonia}} | dates= April 2017-February 2020 | attendance= | budget= | patron= | website= https://www.ev100.ee/en }}
The '''100th Anniversary of the Estonian Republic''' (or more commonly used '''Estonia 100''') is an official government program for the celebration of the [[Republic of Estonia]]'s 100th [[anniversary]]. The official birthday of the Republic of Estonian Republic is on February 24, 2018, the centennial will be marked from April 2017 to February 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ev100.ee/en/centenary|title=Centenary|date=5 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>
== Historical background == {{further|History of Estonia}}
On 12 February 1919, The Estonian Provisional Government decided to consider 24 February to be the date of the independence of Estonia from [[Russian Empire|Russia]] which occurred when [[World War I]] was nearing its end. However, Estonia's independence came to a ''de facto'' end during [[World War II]] when the country was illegally occupied and annexed by the [[Soviet Union]] in 1940, then [[Nazi Germany]] in 1941 and returned to Soviet rule in 1944 when it became the [[Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic]]. As a result, an [[Estonian government-in-exile|government in exile]] was established.
As the [[Glasnost|political upheavals taking place]] throughout the Soviet Union in the 1980s, during the events of ''[[Baltic Way]]'', Estonia declared sovereignty on its territory in 1988, which restored its ''de facto'' independence on 8 May 1990 and declared Soviet rule illegal. Following the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|aborted coup]] in [[Moscow]], the country's full ''de facto'' independence was restored after the Soviet troops failed to seize the [[Tallinn TV Tower]] on 20 August 1991. The [[State Council of the Soviet Union|Soviet State Council]] recognized the Estonian independence on 6 September 1991. Since 2004, Estonia has been a member of [[NATO]] and the [[European Union]].
== Events == The birthday celebrations of the Republic of Estonia will take place over the next 3 years. The celebrations will kick off in April 2017 to mark a century since Estonia's administrative borders took their current form, will peak while events on various important dates take place throughout 2018 and 2019, and come to a grand close on the 2nd February 2020 when the 100th anniversary of the [[Treaty of Tartu (Russian–Estonian)|Tartu Peace Treaty]] will be honoured.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ev100.ee/en/Node/149|title=Invitation to the birthday celebrations of the Republic of Estonia|publisher=|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>
== Centennial Parade == A military parade on [[Freedom Square, Tallinn|Freedom Square]] in [[Tallinn]] was held on the occasion of the 100th anniversary. 1,100 troops and more than 100 pieces of military equipment took part in the parade. The parade was led by Gen. [[Riho Terras]], President [[Kersti Kaljulaid]] was present to greet the different units.
All service branches of the Estonian Defence Forces took part in the parade as well as soldiers from countries from NATO and other military partners of Estonia. The foreign countries that were represented were [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Italy]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Sweden]], [[Ukraine]], [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[Denmark]], and the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.err.ee/685636/gallery-independence-day-parade-on-tallinn-s-freedom-square|title=Gallery: Independence Day parade on Tallinn's Freedom Square|first=|last=ERR|date=24 February 2018|publisher=|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox book |italic title = <!--(see above)--> |name = 101 Vagina |image = 101 Vagina.jpg |image_size = |caption = |alt = |author = Philip Werner |cover_artist = |country = Australia |language = English |subject = Female body image/sexuality |genre = Photography |published = 2013 |media_type = |pages = 216 |awards = |isbn = 9780987409003 |oclc = |dewey = |congress = |exclude_cover = }} {{Italic title}} '''''101 Vagina''''' is a black-and-white [[Coffee table book|coffee table]] [[photo-book]] by Philip Werner, with a foreword by [[Toni Childs]]. It was [[Self-publishing|self-published]] in March 2013 in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. The book contains 101 close-up nude photos shot in a non-provocative way, along with an accompanying story or message written by each woman about her vagina.
The book's photos and stories were exhibited five times in Australia in 2013, with a US and Canadian tour in 2014 taking in six locations.
== Publication == ''101 Vagina'' was funded by [[crowd sourcing]] and took some two years to create.<ref name="The Age Carbone">{{cite news|last1=Carbone|first1=Suzanne|title=Here's a lesson on vaginas 101|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/melbourne-life/heres-a-lesson-on-vaginas-101-20130313-2g0ng.html|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=The Age|date=14 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="LBCP Hansen">{{cite news|last1=Hansen|first1=David|title=Hansen: The Shame and Joy of 101 Vaginas|url=http://www.coastlinepilot.com/opinion/tn-cpt-me-0425-hansen-20140424,0,144764.story|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Laguna Beach Coastline Pilot|date=24 April 2014}}</ref> Werner was initially inspired by ''[[The Vagina Monologues]]'' and subjects were found via [[social media]] after Werner publicised his objective to create a book that had both an educational and celebratory goal.<ref name="The Age Carbone"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Price|first1=Jenna|title=Bodybits 101: the personal side of Selfies|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/federal-politics/bodybits-101-the-personal-side-of-selfies-20121119-29m6x.html|work=Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=November 20, 2012}}</ref> Models, ranging in age from 18 to 65, remain anonymous. Singer-songwriter Toni Childs, who wrote the foreword, made contact with Werner after he initiated a [[peace march]] in honour of murdered [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] employee [[Death of Jill Meagher|Jill Meagher]] in his [[Brunswick, Victoria]] neighbourhood.<ref name="HS Robson">{{cite news|last1=Robson|first1=Suzanne|title=Private parts go public for a cause in coffee table book|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/leader/north/private-parts-go-for-a-public-cause-in-coffee-table-book/story-fnglenug-1226598417523|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Herald Sun|date=18 March 2013}}</ref>
Speaking to ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' about the book, Werner commented that: "I hope it finds its way to a few young women and girls...So they see that [these pictures are] normal rather than pictures in magazines."<ref name="SMH Berry">{{cite news|last1=Berry|first1=Sarah|title=Private parts go public|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/life/private-parts-go-public-20130320-2gfks.html|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=20 March 2013}}</ref> Stories accompanying the photos discuss various themes, including ageing, pregnancy, [[Bikini waxing#Brazilian waxing|Brazilian waxing]], [[virginity|first sexual encounter]] and poor [[body image]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bielski|first1=Zosia|title=Controversial exhibit unveils natural beauty of 101 women|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/relationships/controversial-exhibit-unveils-natural-beauty-of-101-women/article19147999/|work=Globe and Mail|publisher=Globe and Mail|date=June 12, 2014}}</ref>
== Reception ==
On publication ''101 Vagina'' received broad media coverage, including write-ups in ''[[The Age]],''<ref name="The Age Carbone"/> ''The Sydney Morning Herald''<ref name="SMH Berry"/> and ''[[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]]'' in Montreal.<ref name="La Presse Bernier">{{cite news|last1=Bernier|first1=Marie|title=Portraits Intimes|url=http://plus.lapresse.ca/screens/a884e8-206e6-1db97-0d5a3-787b9-a008c-e9722-0609?fb_action_ids=10152936883914848|accessdate=29 June 2014|agency=La Presse|date=31 May 2014|language=fr}}</ref> It was also discussed on [[Radio National|ABC Radio National]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Amanda|title=What lies below|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/bodysphere/what-lies-below/4616196|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=14 April 2013}}</ref> and [[2SER]].<ref>{{cite web|title=A Vagina Festival in the Studio|url=http://www.2ser.com/component/k2/item/4046-vagina-festival|website=www.2ser.com|ref=2SER FM|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209061149/http://www.2ser.com/component/k2/item/4046-vagina-festival|archivedate=February 9, 2015}}</ref>
=== Exhibitions === ''101 Vagina'' was presented as an exhibition on several occasions in Australia in 2013. This included being part of [[The Sydney Fringe]].<ref name="Broadsheet Rosenberg">{{cite news|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Jess|title=101 Vaginas on Display|url=http://www.broadsheet.com.au/sydney/arts-and-entertainment/article/101-vaginas-display|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Broadsheet|date=20 September 2013}}</ref> and [[Melbourne Fringe Festival]].<ref name=melbournefringe>{{cite web|last1=listing|title=101 Vagina book – exhibition|url=http://www.melbournefringe.com.au/fringe-festival/show/101-vagina-book-exhibition/|publisher=melbournefringe.com|accessdate=29 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130917004235/http://www.melbournefringe.com.au/fringe-festival/show/101-vagina-book-exhibition/|archive-date=2013-09-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In 2014, it was officially launched in the US and Canada with a series of exhibitions. The tour included Los Angeles<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gonzales|first1=Nanette|title=101 Vagina Art Show @ Think Tank Gallery (NSFW)|url=http://www.laweekly.com/slideshow/101-vagina-art-show-think-tank-gallery-nsfw-41098267/|work=LA Weekly|publisher=LA Weekly|date=April 8, 2014}}</ref> and Laguna Beach.<ref name="LBCP Hansen"/>
=== Controversy and censorship ===
In Sydney the exhibition was visited by police responding to a complaint that the images were visible from the street.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stubbs|first1=Vanessa|title=Hide the vagina|work=MX - Sydney|publisher=News Ltd|date=28 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="VAH Sano">{{cite news|last1=Sano|first1=Melanie|title=Police Monitor Vagina Exhibition|url=http://visual.artshub.com.au/news-article/news/visual-arts/police-monitor-vagina-exhibition-195868|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Visual Arts Hub|date=1 July 2013}}</ref> Images were required to be censored as part of a group exhibition at The Sydney Fringe.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hunt|first1=Adam|title=Vagina censorship offensive|url=http://www.altmedia.net.au/vagina-censorship-continues/83834|work=City Hub|publisher=Altmedia|date=September 19, 2013}}</ref>

One sentence of Arab Spring context + one sentence on various Jan/Feb/March pre-11 March Day of Rage protests + one sentence Facebook/Abdul-Ahad + one sentence al-Johani * labour rights protests included in 1st paragraph because short 2. Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia demos including protestor and security forces death counts. 3. countrywide pro-prisoner release demos paragraph after EP protests, since they earlier were mostly only in EP (Wikipedia listed sources) 4. women's rights actions (women's suffrage, right to drive, university protests). --> The '''protests in [[Saudi Arabia]]''' were part of the [[Arab Spring]] that started with the 2011 [[Tunisian revolution]]. Protests started with a [[self-immolation]] in [[Samtah]]<ref name="saudi_selfimmo65yr" /> and [[Jeddah]] street protests in late January 2011.<ref name="Montreal" /><ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained"/> Protests against [[Shi'a Islam in Saudi Arabia#Restrictions and persecutions|anti-Shia discrimination]] followed in February and early March in [[Qatif]], [[Hofuf]], [[al-Awamiyah]], and [[Riyadh]].<ref name="PressTV_PreRage"/><ref name="ThReut_demosillegal"/> A Facebook organiser of a planned 11 March "Day of Rage",<ref name="saudirage11March"/><ref name="guardian_rage_womensrights"/> Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahad,<ref name="handelsblatt_Abdul-Ahad" /> was allegedly killed by [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi security forces]] on 2 March,<ref name="handelsblatt_Abdul-Ahad"/><ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas"/><ref name="WSNewscast_Abdul-Ahadwas" /> with several hundred people protesting in Qatif, Hofuf and al-Amawiyah on the day itself.<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3"/> [[Khaled al-Johani]] demonstrated alone in Riyadh,<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3"/> was interviewed by [[BBC Arabic Television]], was detained in [[`Ulaysha Prison]],<ref name="AOL_alJohani"/><ref name="BBC_alJohani"/> and became known online as "the only brave man in Saudi Arabia".<ref name="AOL_alJohani"/> Many protests over human rights took place in April 2011 in front of government ministry buildings in [[Riyadh]], [[Ta'if]] and [[Tabuk, Saudi Arabia|Tabuk]]<ref name="presstv_literacy_5April"/><ref name="ThReut_10April_univ" /><ref name="ArabNews_10April_univ"/> and in January 2012 in Riyadh.<ref name="ABNA_14jan2012"/> In 2011, [[Nimr al-Nimr]] encouraged his supporters in [[nonviolent resistance]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cowburn|first1=Ashley|title=Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr profile: A 'holy warrior' who called for elections in Saudi Arabia|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/sheikh-nimr-al-nimr-executed-a-holy-warrior-who-called-for-elections-in-the-saudi-kingdom-a6793656.html|accessdate=3 May 2017|work=[[The Independent]]|date=2 January 2016}}</ref>
Anti-government protests demanding release of prisoners held without [[habeas corpus|charge or trial]] continued in April and May 2011 in Qatif, al-Awamiyah and Hofuf in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]],<ref name="ThReut_demosillegal"/><ref name="pressTV_17March_4kQatif"/><ref name="arabtimes_4kQatifetc_18March"/><ref name="IBT_1415April"/><ref name="PressTV_5May"/><ref name="presstv_13May"/><ref name="PressTV_20May"/> and extended to calls for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|Bahrain]]<ref name="KSA_ThReut_16March" /><ref name="KSA_ThReut_17March" /><ref name="AlAhramW_words_not_bullets" /> and for the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] to have a constitution and a legislature.<ref name="indep_oct_livefire" /> Four protestors were shot dead by Saudi authorities in late November in Qatif region protests and funerals,<ref name="HRW_Dec2011_protests" /> two on 12/13<ref name="AJE_Issam_Moh_Abd" /><ref name="BBC_Issam_Moh_Abd" /> and 26 January 2012,<ref name="presstv_alAbdel_26Jan2012" /> and two on 9 and 10 February 2012.<ref name="presstv_1shot_9feb2012" /><ref name="awamia_Munir" /><ref name="bbc_zuhair_said" /><ref name="awamia_zuhair_said" /> In the early 2012 demonstrations, protestors chanted slogans against the [[House of Saud]] and [[Ministry of Interior|Minister of Interior]], [[Nayef, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia|Nayef]],<ref name="cdhrap_16jan_70k_mourners" /><ref name="presstv_19jan2012" /> calling Nayef a "terrorist", "criminal" and "butcher"<ref name="GlobalMail_growing_rebellion" /> and throwing an [[:wikt:effigy|effigy]] of Nayef at tanks.<ref name="GlobalMail_growing_rebellion" /> Police described two of the fatal shootings as responses to unidentified gunmen who had shot first.<ref name="bbc_zuhair_said" /><ref name="ThReut_alMedani" /> Eastern Province protests intensified after Sheikh [[Nimr al-Nimr]] was wounded in the leg and arrested by police on 8 July.<ref name="ThReut_alNimrwounded" /> Four men were killed in a protest immediately following the arrest,<ref name="AJE_alNimrwounded" /><ref name="presstv_alNimrwounded" /><ref name="cdhrap_3killed_10kdemo" /> and on 13 July,<ref name="presstv_14jul2012" /> with several funerals and protests following,<ref name="ThReut_10July2012funeral"/><ref name="presstv_11jul2012" /><ref name="presstv_13jul2012" /> including calls for the downfall of the [[House of Saud]].<ref name="ThReut_11July2012funeral" /><ref name="AJE_8July_snipers" /> While detained, al-Nimr was tortured and started a [[hunger strike]], he was later executed in the [[2016 Saudi Arabia mass execution|2016 mass execution]].<ref name="alManar_alNimr_tortured" /><ref name="presstv_alNimr_hungerstrike" /> Protest organisers insisted on the use of [[nonviolent resistance]]<ref name="awamianet_26jul2012" /> and called for all Shia and Sunni detainees to be freed.<ref name="awamia_muna_jabir_funeral" /> A protestor and a soldier were fatally shot in Qatif during a 3–4 August protest,<ref name="aje_alQallaf" /> leading to more protests.<ref name="awamia_alQallaffuneral" /><ref name="presstv_5Aug2012" /><ref name="presstv_6Aug2012" />
Protests and [[sit-in]]s calling for [[political prisoners in Saudi Arabia|political prisoners]]<ref name="IHRC_3rd_decade_silence" /> to be released spread beyond the Eastern Province to protests at the [[Ministry of Interior]] in Riyadh on 20 March<ref name="aljaz_20March" /> and in Riyadh and [[Buraidah]] in December 2011,<ref name="HRW_Dec2011_protests" /><ref name="presstv_buraidah_14jul2012" /><ref name="presstv_buraidah10arrested_14jul2012" /> and in July and August 2012 in front of the Ministry in Riyadh,<ref name="presstv_buraidah23jul2012" /><ref name="presstv_Riyadh25jul2012" /> in [[Mecca]]<ref name="presstv_RiyadhMakkah28Jul2012" /> in [[Ta'if]],<ref name="presstv_9Aug2012" /> in Buraidah,<ref name="presstv_15aug2012_EP_Bur" /> and near [[al-Ha'ir Prison]].<ref name="MFQahtani_alHair120813" /><ref name="MFQahtani_alHair120819a" /><ref name="MFQahtani_alHair120819b" />
Women organised a Facebook [[women's suffrage]] campaign called "Baladi", stating that Saudi Arabian law gives women electoral rights.<ref name="GulfNews_women2325April" /> In April 2011, women in [[Jeddah]], Riyadh and [[Dammam]] tried to register as electors for the [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|29 September municipal elections]] despite officials stating that women could not participate.<ref name="GulfNews_women2325April" /><ref name="AJE_women2325April" /> In May and June, [[Manal al-Sharif]] and other women organised a [[women to drive movement|women's right-to-drive campaign]], with the main action to take place on 17 June.<ref name="France24_huwaiderfilmed" /><ref name="AP_detained21May"/> In late September, Shaima Jastania was sentenced to [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia#Corporal and capital punishment; right to representation|10 lashes]] for driving in Jeddah, shortly after King Abdullah announced women's participation in [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2015|the 2015 municipal elections]] and eligibility as [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia|Consultative Assembly]] members; King Abdullah overturned the sentence.<ref name="NPR_lashes_revoked" /><ref name="Forbes_lashes_revoked"/> Al-Sharif and [[Samar Badawi]] filed lawsuits against Saudi authorities in the [[Legal system of Saudi Arabia#Court structure|Grievances Board]], a non-[[Sharia]] court,<ref name="Metz_KSA_legal_system"/> because of the rejection of their driving licence applications.<ref name="teleg_w2d_vs_Interior"/> Women university students protested in [[King Khalid University]] (KKU) in [[Abha]] in March 2012<ref name="akhbar_Abha_6_7March2012"/> and were attacked by security forces, leading to one death.<ref name="presstv_Abha_woman_killed"/><ref name="KKU_death_hajer_alyazidi"/> Other university protests followed in [[Taibah University]] in [[Medina]]<ref name="ANHRI_multi_city"/> and [[List of universities and colleges in Saudi Arabia|Tabuk University]] in March and April.<ref name="SGazette_8apr2012"/><ref name="arabianbiz_8apr2012"/> KKU students called for the university president to be dismissed. He was replaced on 1 July 2012.<ref name="Ottaway_KSAanalysis_Aug2012"/>
==Protests timeline== {{main|Timeline of the 2011–13 Saudi Arabian protests}}
===January–April 2011=== {{main|Timeline of the 2011–13 Saudi Arabian protests (January–April 2011)}} Protests started with a 65-year-old man's self-immolation in [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]] on 21 January<ref name="saudi_selfimmo65yr" /> and protests of a few hundred people in late January in [[Jeddah]], triggered by flooding,<ref name="Montreal" /><ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained" /> and several times throughout February and early March in the cities of [[Qatif]], [[al-Awamiyah]], [[Riyadh]], and [[Hofuf]].<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /><ref name="ThReut_demosillegal" /> A "Day of Rage" was planned for 11 March.<ref name="saudirage11March" /><ref name="guardian_rage_womensrights" /><ref name="torontostar_rev_longing" /> One of the main organisers, Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahad<ref name="handelsblatt_Abdul-Ahad" /> (or ''Abdul-Ahadwas''<ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas" />), was alleged to have been killed by [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi security forces]] on 2 March,<ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas" /><ref name="WSNewscast_Abdul-Ahadwas" /> by which time one of the ''Facebook'' groups discussing the plans had over 26,000 members.<ref name="eudigest_26k_FB" /> On 11 March, several hundred people protested in Qatif, Hofuf and al-Amawiyah.<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3" /> [[Khaled al-Johani]] demonstrated in Riyadh despite a massive police presence,<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3" /> was interviewed by [[BBC Arabic Television]], and has since then been detained in [[‘Ulaysha Prison]].<ref name="AOL_alJohani" /><ref name="BBC_alJohani" /> Al-Johani became known online as "the only brave man in Saudi Arabia".<ref name="AOL_alJohani" />
The [[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association]] (ACPRA) and the Saudi organisation [[Human Rights First Society]] called for ACPRA co-founder Mohammed Saleh Albejadi to be released following his [[arbitrary arrest]] in [[Buraidah]] on 21 March by [[Mabahith]], the internal security agency.<ref name="acpra_albjady_arrested" /><ref name="hrfs_aims" /> In April, several small protests over labour rights took place in front of government ministry buildings in Riyadh, [[Ta'if]] and [[Tabuk, Saudi Arabia|Tabuk]].<ref name="presstv_literacy_5April" /><ref name="ThReut_10April_univ" /><ref name="ArabNews_10April_univ" /> Protests, made up mainly of [[Shia]] protestors, continued in late March and April in [[Qatif]] and smaller cities in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] such as [[al-Awamiyah]], and [[Hofuf]].<ref name="ThReut_demosillegal" /><ref name="pressTV_17March_4kQatif" /><ref name="arabtimes_4kQatifetc_18March" /><ref name="IBT_1415April" /> The protestors called for the release of prisoners, for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain,<ref name="KSA_ThReut_16March" /><ref name="KSA_ThReut_17March" /> for equal representation in key offices and for reforms in political positions, as they feel marginalised.<ref name="IBT_1415April" />
In response to the 22–23 March announcement of [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|men-only municipal elections in late September 2011]] to elect half the members of local councils,<ref name="alawsat_details" /><ref name="bloom_women" /> women organised a Facebook [[women's suffrage]] campaign called "Baladi", stating that Saudi Arabian law gives women electoral rights.<ref name="GulfNews_women2325April" /> In April, women in [[Jeddah]], Riyadh and [[Dammam]] tried to register as electors for the [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|22 September municipal elections]] despite officials stating that women could not participate.<ref name="GulfNews_women2325April" /><ref name="AJE_women2325April" />
===May–December 2011=== {{main|Timeline of the 2011–13 Saudi Arabian protests (May–December 2011)}} [[File:New Saudi Arabia's traffic sign (women2drive).gif|thumb|Poster for the Saudi Arabia's [[women to drive movement]], artwork by [[Carlos Latuff]].]] In May and June, motivated by the [[Arab Spring]],<ref name="guardian_29jun2011" /> [[Manal al-Sharif]] and other women organised a [[women to drive movement|women's right-to-drive campaign]], with the main action to take place on 17 June. Al-Sharif drove a car in May and was detained on 22 May and from 23‒30 May.<ref name="France24_huwaiderfilmed" /><ref name="AP_detained21May" /><ref name="Indep23May_detained" /> Other women also drove cars, including actress Wajnat Rahbini, who was arrested after driving in Jeddah on 4 June and released a day later.<ref name="GulfNews_Rahbini" /> From 17 June to late June, about seventy cases of women driving were documented.<ref name="Guard_17June" /><ref name="alNafjan_29jun2011" /><ref name="alarabiya_50_17june" /> In late September, Shaima Jastania was sentenced to [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia#Corporal and capital punishment; right to representation|10 lashes]] for driving in Jeddah, shortly after King Abdullah announced women's participation in [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2015|the 2015 municipal elections]] and eligibility as [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia|Consultative Assembly]] members. King Abdullah cancelled the sentence.<ref name="NPR_lashes_revoked" /><ref name="Forbes_lashes_revoked" />
From 17 June to late June, more than seventy cases of women driving were documented.<ref name="Guard_17June" /><ref name="alNafjan_29jun2011" /><ref name="alarabiya_50_17june" /> Protests in the Qatif region continued in May<ref name="PressTV_5May" /><ref name="presstv_13May" /><ref name="PressTV_20May" /> and in October protests, police shot live ammunition at protestors.<ref name="indep_oct_livefire" /> The protestors called for [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] to have its own constitution and legislative assembly, and for their association [[Society for Development and Change]] to be legally registered.<ref name="indep_oct_livefire" /> In late November, Nasser al-Mheishi, Ali al-Felfel, Munib al-Sayyed al-'Adnan and Ali Abdullah al-Qarairis were shot dead by security forces in the Qatif region in successive protests and funerals.<ref name="HRW_Dec2011_protests" /><ref name="aljaz_Mheishi_Felfel" /><ref name="Guardian_Mheishi_age19" /><ref name="CDHRAP_4_Nov_deaths" /> The protests continued in December.<ref name="PressTV_Qatif30Dec2011" />
Hundreds of people protested in Riyadh and [[Buraidah]] in December, calling for the release or trial of prisoners.<ref name="HRW_Dec2011_protests" />
===January–June 2012=== {{main|Timeline of the 2011–13 Saudi Arabian protests (January–June 2012)}} [[File:Dawoud Al Marhoon.jpg|thumb|[[Dawoud al-Marhoon]], sentenced to death in September 2015]] [[File:Manal al-Shraif.jpg|thumb|[[Women's rights]] activist [[Manal al-Sharif]], one of the organisers of the [[women to drive movement|women's right-to-drive campaign]]]] A protest for [[labor rights|labour rights]] took place in Riyadh on 14 January<ref name="ABNA_14jan2012" /> and a [[sit-in]] calling for the [[Syrian diplomatic missions#Middle East|Syrian Ambassador]] to be expelled occurred on 5 February in [[Jeddah]].<ref name="MashallahNews_Kashgari" />
Protests in the [[Qatif]] region continued from January to May,<ref name="presstv_qatif_18May2012" /> with security forces using live fire against protestors,<ref name="presstv_1shot_9feb2012" /><ref name="PressTV_Qatif10jan2012" /><ref name="presstv_qatif_13apr2012" /> killing four, and arresting medical personnel.<ref name="Syrian_doctor_arrested" /> Security forces shot dead Issam Mohamed Abu Abdallah in [[al-Awamiyah]] on 12<ref name="AJE_Issam_Moh_Abd" /> or 13 January,<ref name="BBC_Issam_Moh_Abd" /> Montazar Sa'eed al-Abdel in al-Awamiyah on 26 January,<ref name="presstv_alAbdel_26Jan2012" /> and Munir al-Midani<ref name="presstv_1shot_9feb2012" /><ref name="awamia_Munir" /> and Zuhair al-Said<ref name="bbc_zuhair_said" /><ref name="awamia_zuhair_said" /> on 9 and 10 February. In the 70,000 strong funeral for Abdallah on 16 January in al-Awamiyah and the daily Qatif region protests that followed, protestors chanted slogans against the [[House of Saud]] and [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Minister of Interior]], [[Nayef, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia]].<ref name="cdhrap_16jan_70k_mourners" /><ref name="presstv_19jan2012" /><ref name="cdhrap_18jan2012" /> In mid-February, two medical personnel were arrested for having clandestinely treated injured protestors.<ref name="Syrian_doctor_arrested" /> In a 10 February protest and a 13 February funeral, an effigy of Nayef was thrown at tanks and participants described Nayef as a "terrorist", "criminal" and "butcher".<ref name="GlobalMail_growing_rebellion" /> Police described two of the fatal shootings as responses to unidentified gunmen who had shot first.<ref name="bbc_zuhair_said" /><ref name="ThReut_alMedani" /> [[Dawoud al-Marhoon]] and Abdullah Hasan al-Zaher were arrested on 22 May and 3 March 2012, when they were aged 17 and 16 respectively, for participated in the 2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests. Originally, in March 2012, Al Marhoon was questioned by Saudi police and asked to be an informant and report details about his fellow protesters. After he refused, Saudi security forces arrested him from the Dammam Central Hospital, where he was undergoing treatment for an eye injury sustained in a traffic accident. Saudi forces surrounded the hospital and arrested him as he prepared for surgery. He was arrested in May 22, 2012, and have been tortured and forced to "confess". Then sentenced to death by the [[Specialized Criminal Court (Saudi Arabia)|Specialized Criminal Court]] in September 2015, and {{as of|2015|09|23|lc=y}}, awaited ratification of his sentence by King [[Salman of Saudi Arabia]], to be carried out by [[decapitation|beheading]] and [[crucifixion]] (in that order).<ref name="reprieve">{{cite web|title=Case Study: Dawoud Al Marhoon|url=http://www.reprieve.org.uk/case-study/dawood-al-marhoon/|website=Reprieve}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Saudi Arabia: Fears grow that three young activists could soon be executed|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2015/10/saudi-arabia-three-young-activists-could-soon-be-executed/|accessdate=3 May 2017|work=[[Amnesty International]]|date=16 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Paul|first1=Katie|last2=McDowall|first2=Angus|title=Saudi Arabia to execute more than 50 convicted of terrorism, local media say|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/saudi-arabia-to-execute-more-than-50-convicted-of-terrorism-local-media-say-20151126-gl9a8q.html|accessdate=3 May 2017|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]}}</ref>
[[Manal al-Sharif]] and [[Samar Badawi]], active in the [[women to drive movement]], announced that they had filed lawsuits against Saudi authorities in the [[Legal system of Saudi Arabia#Court structure|Grievances Board]], a non-[[Sharia]] court,<ref name="Metz_KSA_legal_system" /> because of the rejection of their driving licence applications.<ref name="teleg_w2d_vs_Interior" /> As of the end of June 2012, 100 Saudi women had started driving regularly since the June 2011 campaign launch.<ref name="Bloomberg_W2Djun2012" /> Women university students protested in [[King Khalid University]] in [[Abha]] in March<ref name="akhbar_Abha_6_7March2012" /> and were attacked by security forces, leading to one death.<ref name="presstv_Abha_woman_killed" /><ref name="KKU_death_hajer_alyazidi" /> Other university protests followed in [[Taibah University]] in [[Medina]]<ref name="ANHRI_multi_city" /> and [[List of universities and colleges in Saudi Arabia|Tabuk University]] in March and April.<ref name="SGazette_8apr2012" /><ref name="arabianbiz_8apr2012" />
===July–August 2012=== {{main|Timeline of the 2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests (from July 2012)}} In July 2012, [[Amnesty International]] protested in the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] against legal persecution of [[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association|Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association (ACPRA)]] leaders.<ref name="AI_ACPRA_UNHRC" /> Ten female activists were detained in a [[Buraidah]] 14 July protest<ref name="presstv_buraidah_14jul2012" /><ref name="presstv_buraidah10arrested_14jul2012" /> calling for [[political prisoner]]s<ref name="IHRC_3rd_decade_silence" /> to be freed. Similar protests calling for prisoners to be freed and protesting against the Saudi government occurred in Buraidah on 23 July and in front of the [[Ministry of Interior]] in [[Riyadh]] on 25 July,<ref name="presstv_buraidah23jul2012" /><ref name="presstv_Riyadh25jul2012" /> in Riyadh and [[Mecca]] on 28 July,<ref name="presstv_RiyadhMakkah28Jul2012" /> in [[Ta'if]].<ref name="presstv_9Aug2012" /> in Buraidah,<ref name="presstv_15aug2012_EP_Bur" /> near [[al-Ha'ir Prison]]<ref name="MFQahtani_alHair120813" /><ref name="MFQahtani_alHair120819a" /><ref name="MFQahtani_alHair120819b" /> and in [[Dammam]]<ref name="MFQahtani_Dammam120818" /> in August.
In July and August 2012, protests in the [[Qatif]] region intensified after Sheikh [[Nimr al-Nimr]] was wounded in the leg and arrested by police on 8 July.<ref name="ThReut_alNimrwounded" /> Three men were killed in a protest on the evening of the arrest.<ref name="AJE_alNimrwounded" /><ref name="presstv_alNimrwounded" /><ref name="cdhrap_3killed_10kdemo" /> Funerals and protests took place on 10 July,<ref name="ThReut_10July2012funeral"/> 11 July<ref name="presstv_11jul2012" /> and 13 July,<ref name="presstv_13jul2012" /> including chants calling for the downfall of the [[House of Saud]].<ref name="ThReut_11July2012funeral" /><ref name="AJE_8July_snipers" /> Another protestor was shot dead in 13 July [[al-Awamiyah]] protest.<ref name="presstv_14jul2012" /> While detained, al-Nimr was tortured, had bruises on his face and broken teeth, and started a [[hunger strike]].<ref name="alManar_alNimr_tortured" /><ref name="presstv_alNimr_hungerstrike" /> Protest organisers in al-Awamiyah stated their support for al-Nimr and insisted on the use of [[nonviolent resistance]].<ref name="awamianet_26jul2012" /> Protester Mohamed al-Shakhouri was shot in the back and neck and arrested in a 26–27 July protest calling for al-Nimr's release.<ref name="AFP_27jul2012" /> Further protests called for all Shia and Sunni detainees to be freed,<ref name="awamia_muna_jabir_funeral" /> including al-Shakhouri.<ref name="presstv_03aug2012" /> A protestor and a soldier were fatally shot in Qatif during a 3–4 August evening human rights protest,<ref name="aje_alQallaf" /> leading to several more protests.<ref name="awamia_alQallaffuneral" /><ref name="presstv_5Aug2012" /><ref name="presstv_6Aug2012" />
==Aftermath== ===2014 Qatif protests=== {{wikinews|Saudi Arabia executes 47 people as 'terrorists'}}
In early 2014, conflict between protestors and the security forces continued, with Qatif being "a militarised zone, surrounded by checkpoints and armoured vehicles". A Saudi journalist who had been documenting the protests for two years for the [[BBC News|BBC]] left Saudi Arabia as she judged the situation "too risky for [her] to continue investigating."<ref name="BBC201405_EastProv" /> [[Nimr al-Nimr]] was sentenced to death by the [[Specialized Criminal Court]] on 15 October 2014 for "seeking 'foreign meddling' in [Saudi Arabia], 'disobeying' its rulers and taking up arms against the security forces".<ref name="BBC20141015_alNimr_deathsentence" /> His brother, Mohammad al-Nimr, was arrested on the same day for [[Twitter|tweeting]] information about the death sentence.<ref name="BBC20141015_alNimr_deathsentence" /><ref name="AI_alNimr_deathsentence">{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Saudi Arabia: Appalling death sentence against Shi’a cleric must be quashed|work=|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|date=2014-10-15|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/saudi-arabia-appalling-death-sentence-against-shi-cleric-must-be-quashed-2014-10-15|format=|doi=|accessdate=2014-10-15|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TLs4qEbd?url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news/saudi-arabia-appalling-death-sentence-against-shi-cleric-must-be-quashed-2014-10-15|archivedate=15 October 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> Al-Nimr was executed on or shortly before 2 January 2016, along with 46 others [[2016 Saudi Arabia mass execution|in a mass execution]].<ref name="AJE_Nimr_executed">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/01/saudi-announces-execution-47-terrorists-160102072458873.html|title=Saudi announces execution of 47 'terrorists'|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref> His execution was condemned by Iran and Shiites throughout the Middle East, as well as by Western figures and Sunnis opposed to [[sectarianism]]. The Saudi government said the body would not be handed over to the family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.mehrnews.com/news/113310/Saudi-govt-secretly-buries-Sheikh-Nimr-s-body|title=Saudi govt. secretly buries Sheikh Nimr's body|date=3 January 2016|work=Mehr News Agency}}</ref> In March 2017, after a long campaign of harassment, the Saudi security forces killed two members of Nimr family during a raid on a farm in eastern Saudi Arabia. Miqdad and Mohammad Al-Nimr were killed at a farm in Awamiyah, the Nimr family hometown.<ref>https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/saudi-forces-kill-two-relatives-slain-shia-sheikh-nimr-al-nimr/</ref> al-Nimr was very critical of the [[politics of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian government]],<ref name="08RIYADH1283">{{cite journal |last=Gfoeller |first=Michael |authorlink= |title=Meeting with controversial Shi'a sheikh Nimr |id={{WikiLeaks cable|08RIYADH1283}} |work= |publisher=[[WikiLeaks]] |date=2008-08-23 |url=https://wikileaks.org/cable/2008/08/08RIYADH1283.html |accessdate=2012-01-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64ufZsESb?url=http://wikileaks.org/cable/2008/08/08RIYADH1283.html |archivedate=23 January 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and called for free [[elections in Saudi Arabia]].<ref name="reaction">{{cite web | title=Saudi execution of Shia cleric sparks outrage in Middle East |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/02/saudi-execution-of-shia-cleric-sparks-outrage-in-middle-east |work=[[The Guardian]]| date=2 January 2016}}</ref>
In November 2014, unknown assailants in al-Ahsa governorate in the Eastern Province attacked a procession during Ashoura and killed eight Shias, including children, and left over 30 people wounded. The following week deputy governor of the province, Emir Jalwi bin Abdulaziz, was sacked by a royal decree and transferred to the Najran region. However, no official reason was given.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.in/detail/2014/11/12/385750/saudi-official-sacked-over-shia-killings/#sthash.1Pu9yj42.dpuf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112213945/http://www.presstv.in/detail/2014/11/12/385750/saudi-official-sacked-over-shia-killings/ |archivedate=12 November 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>

====Others==== On 21 January 2011, an unidentified 65-year-old man died after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of [[self-immolation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465 |title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia |publisher=BBC |date=23 January 2011 |accessdate=20 October 2012}}</ref>
On 21 November 2011, a 9-year-old girl was shot dead in a demonstration in [[Qatif]] along with Ali al-Felfel, during the funeral for Nasser al-Mheishi.<ref name="presstv_23nov2011" />
On 8 July 2012, an unidentified demonstrator was killed by the security forces along with Akbar Hassan al-Shakhouri and Mohamed Redha al-Felfel, during a protest against the arrest of [[Nimr al-Nimr]] by the Saudi authorities.<ref name="presstv_alNimrwounded" />
On 10 September 2012, a Bangladeshi man was shot dead in the [[Al-Awamiyah]] district of eastern Saudi Arabia. Saudi police said that the Bangladeshi man was driving when his car was hit by bullets fired at two security patrol cars. However, an activist in Al-Awamiyah gave a different account of the incident, saying the man had been killed by gunfire when security forces stormed a house while trying to arrest one of the 23 wanted activist for organising protest in Qatif.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Bangladeshi_man_shot_dead_in_Shiite_area_of_Saudi_Arabia.html?cid=33494664 |title=Bangladeshi man shot dead in Shi'ite area of Saudi Arabia- swissinfo |publisher=Swissinfo.ch |date=11 September 2012 |accessdate=20 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024223136/http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Bangladeshi_man_shot_dead_in_Shiite_area_of_Saudi_Arabia.html?cid=33494664 |archivedate=24 October 2012 }}</ref>
==Response==
===Domestic=== On 10 February 2011, a [[Reuters]] report claimed that 10 intellectuals, [[human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights]] activists and lawyers came together to create the [[Umma Islamic Party]] – considered to be the first political party in Saudi Arabia since the 1990s – to demand the end of [[absolute monarchy]] in the country.<ref name="threuters_umma_created"/> On 18 February however, all ten members of the party were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release.<ref name="washpo_umma" />
On 23 February, Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah, after returning to the country following three months spent abroad for health treatment, announced a series of benefits for citizens amounting to $10.7 billion. These include funding to offset high inflation and to aid young unemployed people and Saudi citizens studying abroad, as well as writing off some loans. State employees' incomes were increased by 15 percent and new housing loans subsidies were introduced. No political reforms were announced as part of the package, though the 86-year-old monarch did pardon some prisoners indicted in financial crimes.<ref name="AlJazeeraEnglishBenefits">{{cite news |title=Saudi king announces new benefits |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011223105328424268.html |publisher=Al Jazeera|date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=23 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110224181607/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011223105328424268.html| archivedate= 24 February 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 6 March, the [[Council of Senior Scholars of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian Council of Senior Scholars]], headed by [[Grand Mufti]] [[Abdul-Azeez ibn Abdullaah Aal ash-Shaikh|Abd al-'Aziz al-Ashaikh]], issued a [[fatwā]] (religious opinion) opposing petitions and demonstrations, declaring, "Therefore the council hereby reaffirms that only the reform and [counsel] that has its legitimacy is that which may bring welfare and avert the evil, whereas it is illegal to issue statements and take signatures for the purposes of intimidation and inciting the strife. ... reform should not be by demonstrations and other means and methods that give rise to unrest and divide the community. ... The Council affirms prohibition of the demonstrations in this country and [that] the legal method which realizes the welfare without causing destruction rests on the mutual advice."<ref name="fatwa_nodemos">{{cite web |last=Council of Senior Scholars of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia |title=A fatwa from the Council of Senior Scholars in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia warning against mass demonstrations |publisher=Islamopediaonline |date=6 March 2011 |url=http://islamopediaonline.org/fatwa/fatwa-council-senior-scholars-kingdom-saudi-arabia-warning-against-mass-demonstrations |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xeKnAzIs?url=http://islamopediaonline.org/fatwa/fatwa-council-senior-scholars-kingdom-saudi-arabia-warning-against-mass-demonstrations |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Guardian_fatwa">{{cite news |title=Saudi Arabia prints 1.5m copies of religious edict banning protests |date=29 March 2011 |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/29/saudi-arabia-edict-banning-protests |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xeJz2Dh0?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/29/saudi-arabia-edict-banning-protests |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The fatwa included a "severe threat against internal dissent",<ref name="alAlawi_fatwa"/> stating, "[The Prophet] again said: 'He who wanted separate affairs of this nation who are unified, you should kill him with sword whoever he is' (narrated by [[Sahih Muslim|Muslim]])." In late March, Abd al-'Aziz al-Ashaikh called for a million copies of the fatwa to be printed and distributed.<ref name="Guardian_fatwa" />
On 22–23 March 2011, officials of the [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Ministry of Municipal and Rural affairs]] announced that men-only municipal elections to elect half the members of local councils would [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|be held in September 2011]].<ref name="alawsat_details"/><ref name="bloom_women"/> ''[[Associated Press]]'' described the election announcement as having "coincided with rumblings of dissent in Saudi Arabia stemming from the wave of political unrest in the Arab world."<ref name="Star_KSA_municip_2011">{{cite news |title=Saudi Arabia to hold elections next month after year and a half delay |date=22 March 2011 |work=[[Toronto Star|The Star]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/958117--saudi-arabia-to-hold-elections-next-month-after-year-and-a-half-delay |accessdate=22 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xNsBXcwF?url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/958117--saudi-arabia-to-hold-elections-next-month-after-year-and-a-half-delay |archivedate=22 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
====Arrests and other repression==== About 30 to 50 people were arrested following 29 January Jeddah demonstration.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained" /> On 18 February, the ten founding members of the [[Umma Islamic Party]] were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release.<ref name="washpo_umma"/>
According to a [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] report on 2 March, Saudi activists have alleged that one of the main administrators of one of the Facebook groups calling for a "Day of Rage" on 11 March, Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahad<ref name="handelsblatt_Abdul-Ahad"/> (or ''Abdul-Ahadwas''<ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas"/>), was killed by [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi security forces]], who removed his body to "hide evidence of the crime".<ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas"/><ref name="WSNewscast_Abdul-Ahadwas"/>
On 5 March, thousands of security forces were sent to the north-east, causing delays on the road to [[Dammam]].<ref name="Fisk_troops">{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Fisk |title=Saudis mobilise thousands of troops to quell growing revolt |date=5 March 2011 |work=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudis-mobilise-thousands-of-troops-to-quell-growing-revolt-2232928.html |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wxaC4jgz?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudis-mobilise-thousands-of-troops-to-quell-growing-revolt-2232928.html |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> On the same day, following about two weeks of small protests in the eastern part of Saudi Arabia, the [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Ministry of the Interior]] warned that the "ban [on] all sorts of demonstrations, marches, sit-ins" imposed by Saudi law would be enforced.<ref name="ThReut_demosillegal">{{cite news |first=Ulf |last=Laessing |author2=Matthew Jones |title=Saudi Arabia says won't tolerate protests |date=5 March 2011 |agency=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/05/us-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72419N20110305 |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wxo8kIog?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/05/us-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72419N20110305?sp=true |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 9 March, Foreign Minister [[Saud Al Faisal]] stated that the government would not tolerate any street protests against it, while also saying that the "best way to achieve demands is through national dialogue".<ref>{{cite news |title=Thousands stage rally in Bahrain |publisher=Al Jazeera|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113917595654981.html|date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=9 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110310104859/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113917595654981.html| archivedate= 10 March 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 21 March, [[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association]] (ACPRA) co-founder Mohammed Saleh Albejadi (also ''Al-Bjady'') was arrested in [[Buraidah]] by [[Mabahith]], the internal security agency. ACPRA stated that the arrest was [[arbitrary arrest|arbitrary]], in violation of the [[Basic Law of Saudi Arabia]] and the ''Law of Criminal Procedures''.<ref name="acpra_albjady_arrested">{{cite web |title=ACPRA demands the immediate unconditional release of its co-founder, Mohammed Al-Bjady |publisher=[[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association]] |date=March 2011 |url=http://www.acpra.net/news.php?action=list&cat_id=12 |accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xQmQEnJ2?url=http://www.acpra.net/news.php?action=list&cat_id=12 |archivedate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> <ref name="hrfs_aims">{{cite web |title=Human Rights First Society – Human Rights Monitoring and Advocacy in Saudi Arabia |publisher=[[Human Rights First Society]] |date=March 2011 |url=http://hrfssaudiarabia.org/ |accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xQntUChA?url=http://hrfssaudiarabia.org/ |archivedate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Both the ACPRA<ref name="acpra_albjady_arrested" /> and [[Human Rights First Society]]<ref name="hrfs_aims" /> called for his immediate, unconditional release.
On 27 March 2011, [[Human Rights Watch]] estimated that the "scale of arrests [rose] dramatically during the preceding two weeks", up to about 160 protestors and critics being held without charge.<ref name="HRW_Laessing_etc" />
In early January 2012, Saudi authorities published the names of a list of 23 people who were allegedly involved in the October 2011 Awamiyah/Qatif protests, calling for their arrests.<ref name="ArabNews_listof23" /><ref name="ThReut_listof23" /> [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Ministry of Interior]] spokesman Mansour al-Turki alleged that the protestors "were working according to a foreign agenda" and were "sponsored financially or supplied with weapons and were working as part of an organization".<ref name="ArabNews_listof23" /> Shah Ali al-Shokan (or ''Shaukan'') from Tarout Island, one of the 23, was arrested by [[Mabahith]] on 2 January 2012.<ref name="ABNA_alShokan_arrest" /> Hussain Ali Abdullah al-Baraki, Mosa Ja'far Mohammad al-Mabyouq, and two others among the 23 were also arrested on 2 January.<ref name="ABNA_5_arrested"/> The Ministry of Interior claimed that al-Shokan, al-Baraki and al-Mabyouq had turned themselves in voluntarily.<ref name="ABNA_5_arrested"/> On 10 January, Aqeel al-Yaseen was wounded in [[al-Awamiyah]] by security forces, arrested and transferred to a [[Mabahith]] facility in [[Dammam]], and forbidden family visits.<ref name="CDHRAP_12jan2012"/>
====Censorship==== In mid-March 2011, Reuters chief correspondent in Saudi Arabia, Ulf Laessing, who had reported from Riyadh since 2009, had his journalistic accreditation withdrawn because of his reporting on the early 2011 Saudi Arabian protests, effectively forcing him to leave Saudi Arabia.<ref name="HRW_Laessing_etc"/><ref name="ThReut_LaessingDeported">{{cite news |first=Ulf |last=Laessing |author2=Crispian Balmer |title=Witness – Searching for reforms in King Abdullah's Saudi Arabia |date=24 March 2011 |agency=[[Reuters]] |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72N39E20110324 |accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xbOKqPaU?url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72N39E20110324?sp=true |archivedate=31 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
====Execution of Nimr al-Nimr==== One of the subsequent responses of the Saudi government was the arrest, conviction and subsequent execution of [[Nimr al-Nimr]] on 2 January 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/03/middleeast/saudi-arabia-executes-dozens-terror/index.html|title=Saudi Arabia severs ties with Iran as protests rage|first=Ben Brumfield, Yousuf Basil and Catherine E. Shoichet|last=CNN|publisher=}}</ref>
===International===
====Governments==== <!-- alphabetical --> *{{Flagu|Russia}} – On 12 July 2012, K.K. Dolgov, human rights representative of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], expressed "great concern" about the July events in the Eastern Province. He stated, "We expect that the authorities of the Kingdom will undertake all necessary measures to settle the situation in its eastern regions, to avoid conflict, including confrontation on interconfessional basis, and to ensure the observance of conventional human rights, including the right for freedom of expression of opinion, peaceful demonstrations and freedom of associations, as it is prescribed by the law."<ref name="Akhbar_RU_concern" /><ref name="RuMin_RU_concern" /> *{{Flagu|United States}} – On 8 March 2012, the [[United States Department of State]] awarded [[Samar Badawi]] the 2012 International Women of Courage Award, citing her filing of a lawsuit for [[women's suffrage|women's voting rights]] in the [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|September 2011 Saudi Arabian municipal elections]] and her encouragement of other women by the launching of an [[online campaign]].<ref name="USStateDept_award" />
====Street protests==== *{{Flagu|Australia}} – On 19 July 2012, 50 people protested in front of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in [[Canberra]] against the arrests of the [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|Bahraini uprising]], against "the crackdown happening in the eastern region of Saudi Arabia", and "to support the people seeking freedom of speech, seeking human rights, freedom for women".<ref name="Canberra_solidarityJul2012" /> *{{Flagu|Canada}} – On 21 July 2012, 30 people protested in front of the United States (US) Embassy in [[Toronto]] against US support of the Saudi Arabian government. A protest organiser claimed that the Saudi government was hypocritical because "Saudi Arabia says [it] support[s] Syria's push for freedom [in the [[Syrian uprising (2011–present)|Syrian uprising]]], but [it] repress[es] [its] own citizens". He called for the release of [[Nimr al-Nimr]].<ref name="Toronto_solidarityJul2012" />
====Media==== Journalist [[Robert Fisk]] said that the protests were known as the "Hunayn Revolution,"{{By whom|date=April 2011}} after the [[Battle of Hunayn]] fought between [[Muhammad]] and the [[Hawazin]].<ref name="Fisk_troops" />
====Other==== Exiled Saudi physicist and political dissident [[Mohammad al-Massari]] described police attacks on women in 3 March 2011 Qatif demonstration as a strategic error, saying, "They made a stupid mistake by attacking women and so on because they think Shia women do not have ... the honor protection like the rest of the women in the country. But attacking women in Saudi Arabia, in an Islamic country is very severe, very negative and catastrophic ... and this will have dire repercussions."<ref name="Qatif_women" />
On 21 February 2011, oil prices rose in response to the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] and speculation regarding 11 March Saudi Arabian Day of Rage.<ref name="saudirage11March" /> The Saudi [[Tadawul]] stock market index fell to a seven-month low on stability concerns.<ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite news|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-02/dubai-shares-slump-to-seven-year-low-on-saudi-arabia-concern.html |title=Dubai Stocks Extends Drop on Concern Mideast Unrest May Spread |publisher=Bloomberg |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}}</ref> During the week of 27 February, global stock prices fell as oil prices increased and silver reached a 30-year high price on stability concerns in the region.<ref>{{cite news|last=Regan |first=Michael P. |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-02/asian-stocks-fall-as-oil-surges-on-mideast-silver-rises-to-30-year-high.html |title=U.S. Stocks Rise on Job-Market Strength; Oil Jumps, Dollar Falls |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}}</ref> Regional stock market indices also fell on concern for Saudi stability.<ref name="bloomberg.com"/>
In August 2017, ten [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureates, including [[Desmond Tutu]] and [[Lech Wałęsa]], urged Saudi Arabia to stop the executions of 14 young people for participating in the 2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests.<ref>"[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/nobel-laureates-urge-saudi-king-to-halt-14-executions/2017/08/11/234f43b4-7ec9-11e7-b2b1-aeba62854dfa_story.html Nobel laureates urge Saudi king to halt 14 executions]". ''The Washington Post''. 11 August 2017.</ref>

(2009–2010) | this_tour = '''Farewell Tour'''
(2012) | next_tour = }} The '''Alexisonfire Farewell Tour''' was a [[concert tour]] by Canadian [[post-hardcore]] band [[Alexisonfire]], taking place in December 2012. After their tour in 2010, band member [[Dallas Green (musician)|Dallas Green]] expressed his desire to leave the band. The band officially announced their break-up in August 2011 and also announced plans of doing one last farewell tour before officially disbanding. The farewell tour was officially announced on August 9, 2012, when the band revealed the tour dates to take place in December 2012.http://exclaim.ca/News/alexisonfire_reveal_final_farewell_tour The band commented that the tour was short due to December being the only available time window for all five members when they were free from any other commitments, especially [[Dallas Green (musician)|Dallas Green]] who was touring with [[City and Colour]] and [[Wade MacNeil]] who was touring with [[Gallows (band)|Gallows]]. On August 17, 2012, after the tickets for the [[London]] date were sold out in just 5 minutes, the band announced that they added another London date at the same venue, a day before, on December 2, 2012.http://www.facebook.com/AOFofficial/posts/269760026467074 The band reunited in 2015. ==Tour dates== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! 1249-84-9 ([[hydrochloride]]) | class = | ATC_prefix = | ATC_suffix = | ATC_supplemental = | PubChem = 10023199 | IUPHAR_ligand = | DrugBank_Ref = | DrugBank = | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 8198772 | UNII_Ref = {{fdacite|correct|FDA}} | UNII = EPT876J73A | KEGG = | ChEBI = | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|changed|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 1615357 | C=25 | H=44 | N=2 | O=1 | molecular_weight = 388.63 g/mol | SMILES = C[C@]12CC[C@H]3[C@H]([C@@H]1CC[C@@H]2N(C)CCCN(C)C)CC=C4[C@@]3(CC[C@@H](C4)O)C | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C25H44N2O/c1-24-13-11-19(28)17-18(24)7-8-20-21-9-10-23(25(21,2)14-12-22(20)24)27(5)16-6-15-26(3)4/h7,19-23,28H,6,8-17H2,1-5H3/t19-,20-,21-,22-,23-,24-,25-/m0/s1 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = FMTFZYKYVZBISL-HUVRVWIJSA-N | synonyms = 20,25-Diazacholesterol; 20,25-Azacholesterol; Azasterol; Diazasterol; SC-12937; DAC; IMD-760; 17β-(3-(Dimethylamino)propyl)methyl-
amino)androst-5-en-3β-ol }} '''Azacosterol''' ([[International Nonproprietary Name|INN]]), or '''azacosterol hydrochloride''' ([[United States Adopted Name|USAN]]) (brand name '''Ornitrol'''), also known as '''20,25-diazacholesterol''', is a [[lipid-lowering agent|cholesterol-lowering drug]] (hypocholesteremic) which was marketed previously but has since been discontinued.{{cite book|author=J. Elks|title=The Dictionary of Drugs: Chemical Data: Chemical Data, Structures and Bibliographies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0vXTBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA110|date=14 November 2014|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4757-2085-3|pages=110–}}{{cite book|author1=I.K. Morton|author2=Judith M. Hall|title=Concise Dictionary of Pharmacological Agents: Properties and Synonyms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mqaOMOtk61IC&pg=PA43|date=31 October 1999|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-0-7514-0499-9|pages=43–}}{{cite book|author=William Andrew Publishing|title=Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Encyclopedia, 3rd Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_J2ti4EkYpkC&pg=PA463|date=22 October 2013|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-0-8155-1856-3|pages=463–}} It is also an [[bird|avian]] [[chemosterilant]] used to control the [[pest (organism)|pest]] [[pigeon]] population via inducing [[sterility (physiology)|sterility]].{{cite book|title=Progress in Medicinal Chemistry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wesIAirSEDkC&pg=PA79|date=1 January 1979|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-0-08-086264-4|pages=79–}} The drug is a [[sterol]] and [[chemical derivative|derivative]] of [[cholesterol]] in which two [[carbon]] [[atom]]s have been replaced with [[nitrogen]] atoms.{{Cite journal | last1 = Counsell | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Klimstra | first2 = P. D. | last3 = Ranney | first3 = R. E. | doi = 10.1021/jm01241a014 | title = Hypocholesterolemic Agents. III.1N-Methyl-N-(dialkylamino)alkyl-17β-aminoandrost-5-en-3β-ol Derivatives | journal = Journal of Medicinal and Pharmaceutical Chemistry | volume = 5 | issue = 6 | pages = 1224 | year = 1962 | pmid = 14056455 | pmc = }} Azacosterol acts as an [[enzyme inhibitor|inhibitor]] of [[24-dehydrocholesterol reductase]] (24-DHCR), preventing the [[biosynthesis|formation]] of [[cholesterol]] from [[desmosterol]].{{cite book|author=Peter M. Elias|title=Advances in Lipid Research: Skin Lipids|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rTeaBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA218|date=21 January 2016|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-1-4832-1545-7|pages=218–220}} Although it primarily acts to inhibit 24-DHCR, the drug also inhibits other steps in cholesterol biosynthesis. The [[contraceptive|anti-fertility]] effects of the drug in birds are mediated by inhibition of [[steroid hormone]] production, steroid hormones being synthesized from cholesterol. Due to prevention of the [[metabolism]] of desmosterol, the drug causes it to accumulate, in turn producing [[side effect]]s such as [[hyperkeratosis]], particularly of the [[hand|palm]]s and [[sole (foot)|sole]]s. ==See also== * [[Desmosterolosis]] * [[Triparanol]] * [[X-linked ichthyosis]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Lipid modifying agents}} [[Category:24-Dehydrocholesterol reductase inhibitors]] [[Category:Hypolipidemic agents]] [[Category:Sterols]] [[Category:Withdrawn drugs]] {{cardiovascular-drug-stub}}
