{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[File:percy-toplis.jpg|thumb|Percy Toplis in military uniform]] '''Francis Percy Toplis''' (20 August 1896 – 6 June 1920) was a British [[criminal]] and [[imposter]] active during and after the [[First World War]]. Before the war he was imprisoned for attempted rape. During the war he served as a private in the [[Royal Army Medical Corps]], but regularly posed as an officer while on leave, wearing a monocle. After the war he became notorious following the murder of a taxi driver and the wounding of a police officer who attempted to apprehend him. The manhunt was major news at the time. He was tracked down and killed in a gunfight with police.
In 1978 a book was published which claimed that he had a big part in the [[Étaples Mutiny]] from 9–12 September 1917, as "The Monocled Mutineer". The authors suggested that he was pursued by the political establishment in a vendetta and may have been innocent of the murder. The book was dramatised by the BBC in 1986 as ''[[The Monocled Mutineer]]'', creating considerable controversy.
Critics say that there is no evidence he was present and official records show that Toplis's unit was en route to [[India]] during the Étaples mutiny. No evidence exists to show that Toplis was absent from his unit; neither is there evidence that Toplis ever went to India and may only have got as far as [[Malta]]. It is now believed highly unlikely that he returned to Europe in time to participate in the mutiny.
==Birth and Youth== [[File:HMP Lincoln.jpg|thumb|[[HMP Lincoln|Lincoln Prison]] where Toplis served his sentence 1912–1914]] Toplis was born at Sanforth Street, [[Chesterfield]], [[Derbyshire]] and christened on 25 September 1896 at Skegby.<ref name=aboutderbyshire>{{Cite web | url=http://www.aboutderbyshire.co.uk/cms/people/percy-toplis-the-monocled.shtml | title=Percy Toplis - The Monocled Mutineer. | website=Tom Bates | date=31 May 2007 | last=Bates | first=Tom}}</ref> His parents, Herbert and Rejoice Elizabeth ([[Married and maiden names|née]] Webster), were unable to support him and he was raised by his grandparents.
He was educated at South Normanton [[Elementary School]], where he was reportedly an unruly bully who was frequently [[corporal punishment|caned]].<ref name=aboutderbyshire /> In March 1908, aged 11, he was [[birched]] for acquiring two suits using false pretences. His grandparents were no longer able to control him and the court released him to his aunt, Annie Webster. Toplis left school in 1910 aged 13, and became a blacksmith's [[apprentice]] at the Blackwell [[colliery]], but after a poor attendance record and an argument with the pit manager he took to an itinerant life in [[Scotland]]. In 1911 he was sentenced to ten days imprisonment in [[Dumfries]] for the non-payment of two train tickets. He returned to England and in 1912, aged 15, he was sentenced to two years [[hard labour]] for the attempted [[rape]] of a 15-year-old girl at [[Mansfield]], serving sentence in [[Lincoln (HM Prison)|Lincoln Prison]] and was released in 1914.<ref name=aboutderbyshire />
==First World War== In 1915, the year after the outbreak of the [[First World War]], Toplis joined the [[Royal Army Medical Corps]] and served as a stretcher bearer, his first active duty being at [[Loos-en-Gohelle|Loos]]. His unit was shipped to the landings of [[Gallipoli Campaign|Gallipoli]], and when they returned, Toplis was hospitalised for [[dysentery]]. Afterwards he briefly worked in a munitions factory. His unit was later posted to [[Salonika]] and [[Egypt]] but he was sent back when he contracted [[malaria]]. In September 1917 his unit was shipped to [[Bombay]] for some months and then returned to Britain. Toplis made a public revisit to Blackwell posing in the uniform of a captain. The visit and some of his anecdotes were reported by the local newspaper, the ''[[Nottingham Evening Post]]'', who took a photograph (shown in this article) that they later released to the police for his 'wanted' notice in 1920.<ref name=aboutderbyshire />
In August 1918, Toplis's father died and soon afterwards he deserted from [[Blackpool]]. He was sentenced at [[Nottingham]] [[Assizes]] to two years in prison for [[fraud]]. When released in 1920, he joined the [[Royal Army Service Corps]] and was stationed at [[Bulford Camp]]. He was soon selling [[rationed]] fuel on the [[black market]], [[forging]] false papers to steal other soldiers' salaries and wearing a colonel's [[uniform]] when he visited women in town. He often used a gold [[monocle]] as part of his disguise.
==Murder and pursuit== Toplis went [[AWOL]] again on 24 April 1920. After 9:00 p.m., taxi driver Sidney George Spicer was found dead from a gunshot wound on [[Thruxton Down]], near [[Andover, Hampshire|Andover]]. Toplis was seen in [[Bulford Camp]] around 11:00 p.m. The inquest into George Spicer's death took place in a barn on Thruxton Down. The jury returned a verdict of 'wilful murder' by Percy Toplis, foreshadowing the possibility of his execution when caught; it was the first British inquest in modern times to declare a man guilty of murder in his absence. Toplis spent the next couple of weeks in London posing as an officer. The police began to close in and he fled to [[Monmouth]], [[Wales]] and eventually to [[Tomintoul]], [[Scotland]]. On 1 June a farmer near Tomintoul saw smoke in a [[bothy]]. He alerted Police Constable George Greig and together they found Toplis sitting by a fire. Toplis fired his pistol, wounding them both and then fled on a bicycle. He cycled to [[Aberdeen]] and took a train to [[Carlisle railway station|Carlisle]], where he arrived on 5 June. He was seen in an Army base in [[Carlisle Castle]].
[[Image:toplis-mortuary.jpg|thumb|right|Mortuary photograph of Toplis]] On 6 June, in [[Cumberland]], Police Constable Alfred Fulton met and questioned a man in "partial military dress" but let him go. Back at the station, he checked police circulars and noticed that this man matched the description of a man suspected of the Andover murder. He went back to apprehend Toplis but retreated when Toplis threatened him with a [[Webley Revolver|Webley Mk VI revolver]]. Inspector William Ritchie and Sergeant Robert Bertram, joined Fulton armed with Webley revolvers and had also disguised their uniforms. It is believed that this may have been the result of orders from the Home Office to the [[Chief Constable]] Norman de Courcy-Parry. They set off by car to apprehend Toplis and were joined ''en route'' by the chief constable's civilian son, Norman de Courcy-Parry, Jr., on his 1000-cc motorcycle. Parry was armed with a Belgian automatic pistol, which he had brought back on his return from service during the war. They saw Toplis but did not recognise him until they had passed him and were some yards down the road. After quickly turning the car round, the group again approached Toplis. Norman de Courcy-Parry stopped the car, feigning mechanical trouble. He exited, pretending to check the trouble, as Toplis approached. The police officers then came out and challenged Toplis, who attempted to flee and fired at them. The officers ran towards him shooting and Toplis fell dead.<ref>[http://www.eden.gov.uk/leisure-and-culture/museum-penrith-and-eden/museum-collections/percy-toplis/ Penrith Museum, biography and photograph] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613204433/http://www.eden.gov.uk/leisure-and-culture/museum-penrith-and-eden/museum-collections/percy-toplis/ |date=13 June 2011 }}</ref>
An [[inquest]] was held on 8 June and the next day, Toplis was buried in an [[unmarked grave]] near the top of [[Penrith, Cumbria|Penrith]]'s Beacon Edge Cemetery. Toplis's belongings, including his monocle, were handed to [[Penrith and Eden Museum]], where they are on display. Despite plans by the Canadian Frank Dayson, a childhood friend of Toplis, to erect a headstone on the grave in 1980, as of 2017 Toplis's grave remains unmarked. In 2015 a plaque was unveiled to mark the spot where Toplis was shot dead.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cumbria-34842935</ref>
==Alleged mutineer==
In 1978 William Allison and John Fairley published ''The Monocled Mutineer'', in which they portray Percy Toplis as a leading participant in the [[Étaples Mutiny]] as a consequence of his being among a band of deserters based in that area of France.<ref>{{cite book | last1=Allison | first1=William | last2=Fairley | first2=John | title=The Monocled Mutineer | publisher=[[Quartet Books]] | year=1978 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MWAJAQAAIAAJ | isbn=07-0432-154-8}}</ref> They say that Toplis was sought in France following the mutiny and posters for his arrest were issued. The fact that the British authorities went to such lengths to apprehend or silence Toplis is thought by Allison and Fairley to add credence to the view that he was one of the only leaders of the mutiny that escaped retribution.
After the book was published, Toplis's supposed career as a mutineer was dramatised by [[Howard Barker]] in his 1980 play ''Crimes in Hot Countries'', in which he is portrayed as an irrepressibly subversive seducer, "irresponsible and amoral, with little concern as to the consequences of his action for others".<ref>Charles Lamb, ''The Theatre of Howard Barker'', Routledge, New York, 2004, p.62.</ref> The 1986 [[BBC]] series entitled ''[[The Monocled Mutineer]]'', an adaptation by [[Alan Bleasdale]] of the book in which Toplis was played by [[Paul McGann]], portrayed him in a much more positive light.<ref>{{cite book | last1=Bleasdale | first1=Alan | last2=Allison | first2=William | last3=Fairley | first3=John | title=The Monocled Mutineer | publisher=[[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]] | year=1986 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WabzAAAAMAAJ | isbn=00-9168-671-7}}</ref><ref name = "gg">Hanna, Emma, ''The Great War on the Small Screen: Representing the First World War in Contemporary Britain'', Edinburgh University Press, 2009, pp.120ff.</ref> The production fuelled accusations by the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government of the time of [[left-wing]] bias at the BBC. It was not only the right-wing press who denounced the accuracy of the series and the book on which it was based; the socialist historian [[Julian Putkowski]], originally recruited as a historical advisor to the programme, also publicly criticised the 'factual errors and misinterpretations that occur in the series'.<ref name = "gg"/><ref>Over the top with Hebert, Hugh 'Percy Toplis: The war with the BBC goes on. Hugh Hebert reports on the latest battle', The Guardian (1959–2003) [London (UK)] 15 Sep 1986: 11.</ref> Putkowski pointed out that it was unlikely that Toplis played any part in the mutiny.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/the-monocled-mutineer-is-innocent-466366.html | title=The Monocled Mutineer is innocent | newspaper=[[The Independent]] | date=12 February 2006 | last=Kelbie | first=Paul}}</ref>
Army records show that Toplis's unit was en route to India during the Étaples mutiny. No evidence exists to show that Toplis was absent from his unit but neither is there evidence that Toplis arrived in India, as the last recorded reference to him places him in [[Malta]]. He was a deserter and regularly moved between units masquerading as an [[Non-commissioned officer|NCO]] or an officer to get food, win money from gambling and for accommodation. It is possible that information about any involvement by Percy Toplis in the mutiny by soldiers in the training camp known as The Bull Ring at Étaples will be made clearer in 2017 when the official files regarding the mutiny are scheduled to be released into the [[public domain]] by the [[National Archives]] but the records of the Étaples Board of Enquiry have long since been destroyed.

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} '''Richmal Marie Oates-Whitehead''' (February 1970 – August 2005) was an employee of the [[British Medical Association]]. After the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]], she claimed to have tended to the attack victims as a doctor, though she did not have any medical qualifications. She was found dead shortly after coming to the attention of the press. Initially, it was suspected that she might have committed suicide, but it emerged later that she died of natural causes. == Early life == Oates-Whitehead was born and brought up in [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]]. She suffered from [[epilepsy]] in her childhood. She displayed interest in becoming a [[physician]] or entering the medical profession right from her school days.{{fact|date=July 2017}} Her school friends described her as a caring person. While she did not become a physician, she trained as a [[Radiation therapy|radiation therapist]] for a year in 1991, working on a study on prevention of blood [[coagulation]]. This included an internship at [[Auckland]]. She moved to [[London]] in 2001, and prior to her last employment with [[British Medical Association]] (BMA) as an editor of ''Clinical Evidence'' (an online journal of the [[British Medical Journal]]), she was with the [[Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health]] in the role of clinical effectiveness coordinator. Immediately prior to her employment at the BMA she worked as a medical writer for ''Euro RSCG Medical Education''; throughout her brief employment at this company she posed as a doctor. == London bombings == Oates-Whitehead came to attention in the aftermath of the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]] at [[Tavistock Square]]. She claimed to have been asked to help out by some firemen and that she did not hesitate for a moment. She was widely hailed as a "heroine", after her accounts of treating the seriously injured were carried out by the press, especially in New Zealand. Subsequently, the [[New Zealand Herald]], among others, researched her background and found that she was not a doctor, but an editor of a BMA publication, a job that did not require medical qualifications. The media's suspicion was triggered by an account by Oates-Whitehead of how she heard a controlled explosion of another bomb by the police while she was busy tending to the victims. [[Scotland Yard]]'s denial of such an explosion and the absence of her name on either of the [[United Kingdom|UK]] or the New Zealand Medical Council registers of doctors strengthened the suspicions. Nor could the [[University of Auckland]] confirm that she was a graduate of the institution. Oates-Whitehead contested the newspaper's contention and threatened to sue it for defamation, but resigned from her post on health grounds when BMA announced an inquiry into her antecedents. The controlled explosion that Oates-Whitehead heard was later reported by others. According to the Richmond and Twickenham Times newspaper there was a controlled explosion of a suspect package on the bus: 'Sergeant Graham Cross and his unit of five were trying to set up a cordon around the King's Cross bombing when the number 30 bus was blown up in Tavistock Square. "We were only 100 metres away," Mr Cross said. Team member PC Ashley Walker was looking at the bus as it exploded before his eyes. As they ran closer, they saw "people's body parts and lumps of flesh", PC Walker remembers. One man's legs were trapped under a bench, while another mangled victim hanged with his head over the edge of the bombed top deck.
Then they spotted a microwave box near a window. Another bomb? They thought it was. "But we had no choice, really," Mr Graham says. "We had to go get people off the bus." A bomb disposal unit later blew up the package in a controlled explosion.' http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/690500.0/ '''Testimony given at the Coroner's Inquest confirms the controlled explosion of the microwave oven''': Transcript: Q. In relation to secondary devices, you were aware, I think, during your time at the scene, in relation to secondary devices, of the attendance of a Metropolitan Police explosives unit, explosives officer. Is that right?
A. That's correct. Q. I think, to use the phrase that you did in your recent statement in which you went over your actions on the day itself, you noted that the box that you considered may have contained a secondary device—which would be the microwave oven, as it transpired to be — was neutralised by the explosives officer. There was a controlled explosion at one stage carried out by explosives officers that day. Was that subsequent—put it another way, was that something that occurred or that didn't occur while you were there?
A. Sorry? Q. The question is probably poorly phrased. Were you aware of a controlled explosion?
A. Yes. Q. -- or simply the attendance of explosives officers?
A. I heard the controlled explosion, yes. Q. Right. I don't suppose you can provide a time for that, can you, or can you?
A. After 30 minutes. That's my guess, I can't know. Q. All right. That's all I want to ask about that.http://7julyinquests.independent.gov.uk/hearing_transcripts/18012011pm.htm == Death == Following apprehensions from her family members, the Police entered her flat in West [[London]] on 17 August and found her dead body. Initially it was believed that she might have committed suicide due to the possible media [[Witch-hunt|witch hunt]] and loss of her job. However, [[Autopsy|post-mortem]] reports suggested that she died of a [[pulmonary embolism]]. The [[Coroner]]’s office ruled out an [[inquest]] as the death was due to natural causes. == Alleged personality disorder == Newspaper reports indicate that Oates-Whitehead seemed to suffer from some [[personality disorder]].https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1497099/Pathos-of-the-bogus-doctor-who-became-53rd-victim-of-77.html She always carried a [[stethoscope]] in her handbag despite not being a doctor; described herself as an [[epidemiologist]] or a [[professor]] in her correspondence and told others that she travelled to [[Iraq]] and [[Indonesia]] to provide medical assistance to the war victims and the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|tsunami]] victims respectively. Her claims also included being afflicted with [[cancer]], being [[stalking|stalked]], suffering a mini [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]], references to a retired professor as partner and giving birth to premature twins who died within a day. A common thread of appeal for either admiration or sympathy seems to have run through her stories. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://portal.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/08/28/ndoctor28.xml&sSheet=/news/2005/08/28/ixhome.html An article on Richmal Oates-Whitehead from ''The Daily Telegraph''] *[https://www.theguardian.com/attackonlondon/story/0,16132,1558598,00.html An article on Richmal Oates-Whitehead from ''The Guardian''] *[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/author/story.cfm?a_id=100&ObjectID=10342653 "The colourful life and sad death of a fabulist"], ''New Zealand Herald'', 27 August 2005. {{DEFAULTSORT:Oates-Whitehead, Richmal}} [[Category:July 2005 London bombings]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:People from Gisborne, New Zealand]] [[Category:People with epilepsy]] [[Category:Deaths from pulmonary embolism]] [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]]

{{Infobox recurring event |name=SHIFT Business Festival |years_active=Since 2016 |genre=Technology, business festival |venue=Turku Castle, Turku |country=Finland |website={{URL|www.theshift.fi}} |image= }} '''SHIFT''' is a two-day international business festival held every year in [[Turku|Turku, Finland]], at the [[Turku Castle]]. It was first held on May 31 and June 1, 2016. The attendees included over 1,000 visitors, 80 partner companies, 150 startups, and over 20 investors. Around 100 volunteers were part of this event. SHIFT 2017 is slated to be held on May 31 and June 1, 2017.
The SHIFT is backed by companies and the city of Turku, as well as Turku Chamber of Commerce<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://turunkauppakamari.fi/|title=Etusivu - Turun kauppakamari|website=Turun kauppakamari|language=fi-FI|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> and The Federation of Finnish Enterprises,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yrittajat.fi/en|title=Federation of Finnish Enterprises|website=Federation of Finnish Enterprises|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> while the event itself is put together by local JCI<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nuorkauppakamarit.fi/en/|title=Energiaa ja uusia mahdollisuuksia Nuorkauppakamarista - Suomen Nuorkauppakamarit - JCI Finland|date=2016-07-05|work=Suomen Nuorkauppakamarit - JCI Finland|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-US}}</ref> members, start-up actives and students.
== 2016 - First Year == The 2016 SHIFT business festival had key speakers such as: * Edward Jung, Founder and Chief Technology Officer, [[Intellectual Ventures]] * Andreas Korczak, [[Microsoft]] * Cecilia Hertz, Founder of Umbilical Design * Thor Gunnarsson, Co-Founder, Solfar * Jonathan Pulitzer, Managing Director in the energy practice, [[GE Ventures]] * Stephen Lake, CEO, Thalmic Labs * Mo-El Fatatry, Founder, Masar * Ravi Belani, Founder, [[The Alchemist Accelerator|Alchemist Accelerator]] * Henrietta Kekäläinen, Founder, Mehackit * Markus Alholm, CEO, [[GE Energy|GE Energy Finland]] * Oliver Rittgen, CEO, [[Bayer|Bayer Nordic SE]] * Keiichi Matsuda, Augmented reality designer * Teemu Arina, Founder, Biohacker Center * Aape Pohjavirta, Founder, Funzi * Kristoffer Lawson, Founder, Solu * Jussi Westergren, Co-founder, Virunga Alliance The business festival also featured performing artists such as: * Kalle Lehto, Circus performer * Kimmo Korpela, Breakdance champion * Anu Halmesmaa, Sculptor * Alessio de Marchi, Metallurgy sculptor * Sampo Kurppa, Circus artist * Masha Sha, Video artist * Celia Eid and Sebastian Bérangér, Animator and Composers * Albert Bayona, Visual artist and Cultural promoter * Alper T İnce, Painter and Video artist * Inna Demidova-Tuomikoski, Visual artist * Silja Selonen, Painter and Sculptor * Zinaïda Lihacheva, Artist * The Turncoats, Jugglers
== 2017 Lineup == The event is scheduled to be held in the [[Turku Castle]], in [[Turku]], [[Finland]], on May 31, 2017 and June 1, 2017.
[[Neil Harbisson]], the avant-garde artist and [[cyborg]] activist, was announced as first of the speakers in the event. The other speakers are: * Alan Laubsch, Founder, National Capital Alliance * Gerd Leonhard, Author, CEO of the Futures Agency * Melody Hossaini, Founder and CEO, InspirEngage International * Lauri Järvilehto, CEO and Co-Founder, Lightneer; Founder, Filosofian Akatemia * Cecilia Tham, Entrepreneur, MOB and FabCafe * Christopher Auel-Welsbach, Founder, Product Manager, Speaker on Artificial Intelligence, Leader of IBM Watson Partner Innovation (Europe) * Hugh Williams, VP Engineering, [[Google]] * Laila Pawlak, CEO and Co-Founder, SingularityU Denmark * Henrik Hautop Lund, Professor, Technical University of Denmark

{{flagicon|North Korea}} [[Kim Jong-un]] | chairperson = | follows = [[May 2018 inter-Korean summit]] | precedes = [[December 2018 inter-Korean summit]] | website = {{URL|1=http://www.korea.net/Government/Current-Affairs/National-Affairs?affairId=656|2=2018 Inter-Korean Summit}} | keypoints = | compactnav = yes }} {{Infobox East Asian name | koreanname = South Korean name | hangul = 2018{{linktext|년| 남북|정상회담}} | hanja = 2018{{linktext|年| 南北|頂上會談}} | rr = 2018nyeon Nambuk Jeongsang-hoedam | mr = 2018nyŏn Nambuk Chŏngsang-hoedam | koreanname2 = North Korean name | context2 = north | hangul2 = 2018{{linktext|년| 북남|수뇌|상봉}} | hanja2 = 2018{{linktext|年| 北南|首腦|相逢}} | rr2 = 2018nyeon Bungnam Sunoe-sangbong | mr2 = 2018nyŏn Pungnam Sunoe-sangpong}} The '''September 2018 inter-Korean summit''' was the third [[inter-Korean summit]] in 2018. On 13 August, the [[Blue House]] announced that South Korea's President plans to attend the third inter-Korean summit with leader Kim Jong-un at [[Pyongyang]] in September as expected. The agenda would be finding the strategy of the breakthrough in its hampered talks with the U.S. and solution for the denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula.{{cite web|url= https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/koreas-to-hold-pyongyang-summit-in-september-10612404 |title= Koreas to hold Pyongyang summit in September |date= Aug 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://www.news.com.au/finance/work/leaders/kims-new-look-as-pyongyang-summit-confirmed/news-story/f5e80c3d9e6dae4499038976250636b6 |title= Kim’s new look as Pyongyang summit confirmed |date= Aug 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://www.cbsnews.com/news/north-korea-kim-jong-un-summit-pyongyang-south-korea-president-moon-jae-in/ |title= South Korean leader to meet Kim Jong Un on his turf |date= Aug 13, 2018}} It was held for three days between September 18 and September 20.{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2018/09/103_254994.html|title=South Korea seeks to hold inter-Korean summit Sept. 18-20: reports|author=|date=4 September 2018|website=koreatimes.co.kr}} == Overview == It would be the fifth inter-Korean summit after the [[Korean War]] of 1950–1953. North Korea is currently soliciting economic cooperation and results from South Korea at the upcoming inter-Korean summit on September.{{cite web|url= https://thediplomat.com/2018/08/fifth-inter-korean-summit-scheduled-for-september-2018-what-to-expect/ |title= Fifth Inter-Korean Summit Scheduled for September 2018: What to Expect |date= Aug 21, 2018}} North Korea's state media announced the agreement to hold the next inter-Korean summit in [[Pyongyang]].{{cite web|url= http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20180814000135 |title= N. Korea's media report on agreement to hold inter-Korean summit |date= Aug 19, 2018}} == Progress == It was announced on August 31 that South Korean President Moon Jae-In will send a special delegation to North Korea on September 5 to hold more nuclear talks and set up the date for the summit.https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/s-korean-envoy-to-travel-to-north-for-pre-summit-talks/2018/08/31/bbe2e1fe-acf3-11e8-9a7d-cd30504ff902_story.html?utm_term=.4b70f501d6fe{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/south-korean-president-moon-to-send-special-envoy-to-north-korea-next-week|title=South Korean President Moon Jae-in to send special envoy to North Korea next week|first=|last=hermesauto|date=31 August 2018|website=straitstimes.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/08/31/asia-pacific/politics-diplomacy-asia-pacific/south-korean-president-moon-jae-dispatch-special-envoy-north-korea-next-week/|title=South Korean President Moon Jae-in to dispatch special envoy to North Korea next week|first=Jesse|last=Johnson|date=31 August 2018|publisher=|via=Japan Times Online}} On September 5, 2018, South Korean National Security Advisor Chung Eui-yong, National Intelligence Service Director Suh Hoon and other delegates travelled to North Korea to hold a meeting with Kim Jong-un, where they arranged the summit and help rescue faltering nuclear diplomacy between the United States and North Korea.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecourierexpress.com/news/world/s-korean-envoys-meet-kim-to-advance-nuclear-diplomacy/image_2807d380-876e-5eb2-a156-4d742600336d.html|title=S. Korean envoys meet Kim to advance nuclear diplomacy|first=Yun|last=Dong-jin|date=|website=thecourierexpress.com}} It was then announced that the three-day summit would take place between September 18 and September 20.{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/koreas-set-next-kim-moon-summit-for-mid-september/4559870.html|title=North-South Korea Summit Set for Mid-September|first=Steve|last=Miller|date=|website=voanews.com}} South Korean officials have insisted that Kim Jong-un has set a proposed denuclearization timetable and is working with Trump to achieve this goal.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-southkorea/north-koreas-kim-sets-denuclearization-time-line-prompting-thanks-from-trump-idUSKCN1LM07M|title=North Korea's Kim sets denuclearization time line, prompting thanks...|first=Hyonhee|last=Shin|date=|website=reuters.com}} ===September 18 (Day 1)=== [[File:Sept. 2018 Inter-Korea Summit 01.jpg|thumb|Moon Jae-in arriving at the [[Pyongyang International Airport]]]] The summit began as scheduled on September 18.{{cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/north-and-south-korean-leaders-embrace-each-other-korean-summit-begins-1125645|title=North and South Korean leaders hug ahead of summit|author=|date=18 September 2018|website=newsweek.com}} On the first day, Moon Jae-in and his wife Kim Jung-Sook arrived at [[Pyongyang International Airport|Pyongyang's Sunan International Airport]], where they got a rousing reception, which featured a marchpast by the guard of honor and the [[Central Military Band of the Korean Peoples Army]]. Kim Jong-un also greeted them and embraced Moon. Kim and Moon also arrived at the summit in the same car. Both also openly waved to an enthusiastic car parade. ===September 19 (Day 2)=== [[File:Sept. 2018 Inter-Korea Summit 07.jpg|thumb|Moon and Kim with the "Pyongyang Joint Declaration of September 2018"]] In Pyongyang, an agreement titled the "Pyongyang Joint Declaration of September 2018" was signed by both Korean leaders{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2018/9/19/17878428/north-south-korea-kim-moon-declaration|title=North and South Korea just signed a major agreement. It may be bad news for Trump.|author=|date=|website=vox.com}} The agreement calls for a military agreement, civilian exchanges and cooperation in many areas, and conditions to denuclearize North Korea.https://www.ncnk.org/node/1633 During this day, North Korean Defense Minister No Kwang Chol and South Korean Defense Minister Song Young-moo also signed a new Agreement on Reconciliation, Non-Aggression, Exchanges and Cooperation (aka "Basic Agreement") known as the "Agreement on the Implementation of the Historic Panmunjom Declaration in the Military Domain" (also called the Comprehensive Military Agreement, or CMA) to help ensure less military tension between both countries and greater arms control.http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/867186.htmlhttps://thediplomat.com/2018/10/north-and-south-koreas-new-military-agreement/https://www.cfr.org/blog/pyongyang-declaration-implications-us-rok-coordination-north-koreahttps://thediplomat.com/2018/09/at-fifth-inter-korean-summit-koreas-announce-major-military-to-military-agreements/https://www.ncnk.org/sites/default/files/Agreement%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20the%20Historic%20Panmunjom%20Declaration%20in%20the%20Military%20Domain.pdf The agreement calls for the removal of landmines, guard posts, weapons, and personnel in the [[Joint Security Area|JSA]] from both sides of the North-South Korean border.{{cite web|url=https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1034057/koreas-agreed-to-disarm-border-village|title=Koreas agreed to disarm border village|first=Associated|last=Press|date=|website=inquirer.net}}{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/moon-kim-sign-agreement-north-korea-steps-denuclearize/story?id=57925068|title=Moon, Kim sign agreement for North Korea to take further steps to denuclearize|first1=Joohee|last1=Cho|first2=Hakyung|last2=Kate Lee|date=September 19, 2018|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=October 2, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2018/09/19/North-South-Korea-to-halt-military-drills-in-border-area/5211537339644/|title=North, South Korea to halt military drills in border area|first=Wooyoung|last=Lee|date=September 19, 2018|publisher=UPI|accessdate=October 2, 2018}} The agreement also called for the creation of joint military buffer zones. The [[DPRK]] agreed to dismantle its [[Yongbyon Nuclear Scientific Research Center|nuclear complex]] in the presence of international experts if the U.S. takes correlative action. {{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-19/north-korea-agrees-to-dismanlte-nuclear-test-site/10282040|title=South Korea says North agrees to dismantle nuclear site — if US takes reciprocal action|author=|date=19 September 2018|website=abc.net.au}} The DPRK also agreed to complete its dismantling of the [[Sohae Satellite Launching Station]], which started in July 2018,https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/07/23/north-korea-begins-dismantling-key-test-site-satellite-imagery-suggests/?utm_term=.185bd31ee091 and that the dismantling of Sohae's missile engine test site and launch pad would be observed by international experts as well.https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2018/09/19/kim-jong-un-moon-jae-sign-agreement-peace/1355006002/ Kim Jong-un also pledged to visit the South Korean capital of Seoul "in the near future."{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/09/19/649413468/north-koreas-kim-jong-un-says-he-will-visit-seoul|title= North Korea's Kim Jong Un Says He Will Visit Seoul|publisher=National Public Radio|date=19 September 2018}}https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/31/north-korea-reportedly-readies-nuclear-missile-sites-for-inspectors.html In front of a capacity crowd of 150,000, Moon delivered a speech at Pyongyang's [[May Day Stadium]] calling for cultural unity and reunification of both Koreas. Moon received a standing ovation and was the first ever South Korean leader to give a public address in North Korea.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2164932/moon-gets-standing-ovation-after-first-ever-speech-south-korean|title=Moon Jae-in makes first ever public speech by South Korean leader in North|author=|date=|website=scmp.com}} At the same stadium, Moon, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and their wives attended the mass games performance of "The Glorious Country."{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OYw9gXA77Uk|title= VIDEO 2018 INTER-KOREAN SUMMIT PYEONGYANG MOON TO DELIVER SPEECH TO 150,000 PYEONGYANG CITIZENS |first=ARIRANG NEWS |last=Press|date=|website=ARIRANG NEWS}} ===September 20 (Day 3)=== [[File:Moon and Kim on Mt. Paektu.jpg|thumb|Kim and Moon at [[Heaven Lake]] of [[Mount Paektu]]]] The leaders of the two Koreas visited [[Mount Paektu]] together.{{cite web|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/nation-world/world/article218657795.html|title=The Latest: Moon, Kim visit crater lake on Mount Paektu|author=|date=|website=newsobserver.com}} Moon traveled from Pyongyang by plane to [[Samjiyon Airport]] near Mount Paektu where Kim arrived first to greet him. They then rode vehicles to the mountain on the North Korean-Chinese border. The leaders also rode together in a cable car to reach [[Heaven Lake]], located in a crater atop the mountain's sacred volcano area. Moon was the first South Korean President to visit Mount Baekdu. After reaching the lake, Kim, Moon, along with their wives, posed together in front of it for a picture. [[Baekdu Mountain#Korea|The mountain's volcano and Heaven Lake]] is considered to be the most sacred sites in Korean mythology{{cite news|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/04/160415-sacred-volcano-north-korea-waiting-eruption-science/|title=Sacred Volcano in North Korea May Be Waiting to Blow|first=Nadia|last=Drake|publisher=National Geographic|date=April 16, 2016|accessdate=September 22, 2018}}{{cite book|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=heaven+lake+korea+mythology&newwindow=1&ei=YtKmW7nyF8OP0gK_-bfgCg&sqi=2&start=10&sa=N&biw=768&bih=455|title=Inside North Korea|author=Mark Edward Harris|page=117|date=2007|accessdate=September 22, 2018}} and [[Kim dynasty (North Korea)|Kim's family]] has long identified themselves as the "Mount Paektu bloodline."{{cite web|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/article218657795.html|title=The Latest: Moon, Kim visit crater lake on Mount Paektu|author=|date=|website=miamiherald.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/20/asia/mount-paektu-kim-jong-un-moon-jae-in-intl/index.html|title=Mount Paektu: Moon and Kim visit mythical mountain|first=Joshua Berlinger and Yoonjung Seo,|last=CNN|date=|website=cnn.com}} Before Moon returned to South Korea,http://www.kurv.com/moon-returns-home-after-north-korea-trip/ a stone marker was dedicated during a tree planting ceremony in Pyongyang to commemorate his trip to North Korea. Kim also shipped 2 tons of North Korean pine mushrooms, known locally as songyi, across the border before Moon returned as well.https://www.newsweek.com/south-korea-giving-away-kim-jong-un-expensive-holiday-gift-1132169 Moon press secretary Yoon Young-chan stated that the mushrooms would be given to 4,000 South Koreans who had family members in North Korea. Senior citizens in this group also had the privilege of eating 500 grams each before the [[Chuseok]] festival. == Reactions == Chinese state media [[Xinhua]] greeted the decision of holding the next inter-Korea leaders' summit in [[Pyongyang]]. Xinhua expressed that the U.S. has had a vital impact on the "[[Korean Peninsula]] issue" and requested on [[Federal government of the United States|Washington]] to play a more dynamic role in regional matters. Xinhua also viewed negatively the United States' North Korea policy with "maximum pressure" although [[Pyongyang]] has made efforts to "shut down" the [[Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site|Punggye-ri primary nuclear test site]], return the remains of the U.S. soldiers from the Korean War, and stimulate negotiations between North and South.{{cite web|url= https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2018/08/14/Chinese-state-media-endorses-third-inter-Korea-summit/8321534230154/ |title= Chinese state media endorses third inter-Korea summit |date= Aug 17, 2018}} On September 19, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang praised the meeting, stating that it produced positive effects easing military tensions, promoting peace talks and the progressing denuclearization process.{{cite web|url=https://www.apnews.com/cf8c7a8a366e426c880f6a04a3c4423b/The-Latest:-China-welcomes-Korean-summit,-supports-talks|title=The Latest: China welcomes Korean summit, supports talks|author=|date=|website=apnews.com}} ==Aftermath== ===Gifts=== On September 27, 2018, Kim honored a request Moon made during the summit and gave the South Korean leader two rare [[Pungsan dog|Pungsan]]s, Korean hunting dogs, named Gomi and Songgang.https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/30/asia/north-korea-moon-kim-dogs-intl/index.html On November 8, 2018, Moon's office declared the mushrooms safe to eat and were not affected by North Korea's history of nuclear testinghttps://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/11/08/south-korea-declares-kim-jong-uns-mushrooms-safe-eat/ On November 11, 2018, South Korea airlifted 200 tons of tangerines to North Korea from [[Jeju Island]] as a goodwill gesture for the mushrooms.http://m.startribune.com/index.php/south-korea-ships-tangerines-to-north-which-sent-mushrooms/500244781/ On November 12, 2018, Gomi, the female Pungsan, gave birth to six "peace gift" puppies.{{cite news|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2018/11/12/71/0401000000AEN20181112006700315F.html|title=Pungsan dog gifted by N.K. leader to Moon gives birth to six puppies|publisher=Yonhap|date=12 November 2018}} When they were born, Moon tweeted "As the pregnancy period of dogs is about two months, Gomi must have come to us pregnant," and that "I hope inter-Korean affairs will be like this." On November 25, 2018, Moon presented photos of these "peace gift" puppies to the public.https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46336353 ===Kim's visit to Seoul=== It was announced that [[DPRK]] leader Kim Jong-un's visit to Seoul would occur in December 2018 based on the report from South Korea’s Yonhap news agency. https://www.nst.com.my/world/2018/09/413796/kim-jong-un-visit-seoul-december ===The meeting during UN General Assembly === Moon Jae-in at UN members requests world to acknowledge ‘positively’ to Kim Jong-un’s ‘new choices’ to inspire denuclearisation. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo earlier assembled with his North Korean counterpart Foreign Minister Ri Yong-ho in New York and announced that it's very positive gathering with DPRK during UNGA (General Assembly) to discuss upcoming Trump-Kim summit & next steps toward denuclearization of North Korea. {{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2165893/moon-jae-un-urges-world-respond-positively-kim-jong-uns-new|title=Moon urges UN to respond ‘positively’ to North Korea’s ‘new choices’|author=|date=|website=scmp.com}} ===Removal of landmines and discovery of remains of Korean War soldiers=== On October 1, 2018, North and South Korean military engineers began a scheduled 20 day removal process of landmines and other explosives planted across the [[Joint Security Area]] of the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]] (DMZ).https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/10/01/north-south-korea-begin-removing-landmines-along-fortified-border/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/north-korea-south-korea-removing-land-mines-dmz-panmunjom-arrow-head-hill/ The [[Joint Security Area]], located near the shared border village of [[Panmunjom]], will also undergo major changes following the demining as well. It was also agreed that Arrowhead Hill would afterwards undergo demining by both North and South Korean forces and that they would also assist in searching for potential remains of missing soldiers.https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/01/world/asia/koreas-land-mines-dmz.html Around 800,000 landmines were planted along these two regions since the division of Korea.https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-45704909 On October 19, 2018, after just 19 days of mine clearing operations by both sides,http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3054494 the [[United Nations Command]] announced that both North and South Korea had completed work to remove landmines from the Joint Security Area was now complete.http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3054494https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2018/10/356_257291.htmlhttps://pulsenews.co.kr/view.php?year=2018&no=653231 By October 25, 2018, demining had begun at Arrowhead Hill and resulted in the discovery of Korean War remains.https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/south-korea-finds-war-remains-border-demining-58732705https://www.dailyherald.com/article/20181025/news/310259972 Demining at Arrowhead Hill will continue until November 30, 2018. Five more sets of remains from the Korean were discovered at Arrowhead Hill on November 19, 2018.http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20181119000156 By this point in time, a total of nine sets of Korean War remains had been discovered at Arrowhead Hillhttps://www.dailyherald.com/article/20181025/news/310259972 Arrowhead Hill had previously been selected for both Koreas to conduct a pilot remains recovery project.https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/01/world/asia/koreas-land-mines-dmz.html A pilot inter-Korean Remains Recovery Project is another commitment which was made in the summit's Comprehensive Military Agreement. On November 22. 2018, a DMZ road was reconnected for the first time in 14 years in an effort to assist with both the demining and exhumation process.http://www.asianews.it/news-en/After-14-years,-a-road-to-unite-the-Koreas-and-recover-the-remains-of-the-fallen-45545.htmlhttps://www.yahoo.com/news/north-south-korea-join-roads-124905264.htmlhttps://www.cairnspost.com.au/news/national/north-and-south-korea-join-roads-after-14-years/video/af8a644187eb15024a900b16826ebd24 Work between both Koreas to remove landmines from Arrowhead Hill was completed on November 30, 2018.https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20181130002400315https://eng.belta.by/society/view/koreas-complete-work-on-removing-some-guard-posts-land-mines-in-dmz-116996-2018/ ===Dismantling of guard posts=== Once the Joint Security Area is demined, the guard posts will cease to exist. The dismantling of Joint Security Area guard posts was complete on October 25.https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/south-korea-finds-likely-war-remains-during-border-demining/2018/10/24/ec0b1a10-d802-11e8-8384-bcc5492fef49_story.html?utm_term=.fd077240de24https://www.theindependent.com/news/world/koreas-un-finish-withdrawing-firearms-from-border-village/image_55ab50f5-8704-5770-812d-87c7832e0568.htmlhttp://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/10/25/0200000000AEN20181025001351315.html The destruction of 20 guard posts located along the "front lines" of the Korean DMZ officially began on November 11, 2018.http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20181111000255http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/11/11/0200000000AEN20181111005200320.htmlOn November 15, 2018, destruction of two DMZ guard posts, one being located in South Korea and the other located in North Korea, was completed.https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2018/11/15/south-korea-destroys-guard-posts-along-border-with-north-korea.htmlhttps://www.military.com/daily-news/2018/11/16/south-korea-dismantles-guard-posts-dynamite-excavators.html Work was still ongoing to complete the destruction of other guard posts as well. On November 23, it was revealed that South Korea had slowly been destroying their guard posts with [[excavator]]s. As destruction of the guard posts began, it was announced that both Koreas had amended the summit's Comprehensive Military Agreement and decided to preserve 2 of the 22 now demilitarized frontline guard posts. Both of the posts which were planned to be preserved are located on the opposite sides of the Korean border.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/216465-north-south-korea-begin-destroying-border-guard-posts|title=North and South Korea begin destroying border guard posts|work=Rappler|access-date=2018-11-30|language=en}} On November 20, 2018, North Korea, hoping to further ease tensions with South Korea, destroyed all of their 10 remaining "frontline" guard posts.https://abc11.com/north-korea-detonates-dmz-guard-posts-at-southern-border/4726650/https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/seoul-north-korea-explodes-10-guard-posts-lower-59309949 The South Korean Defense Ministry released photos confirming this and also released a statement stating that North Korea had informed them about the plans to demolish them before it took place. This came in accordance with the earlier summit agreements. On November 30, 2018, both Koreas completed work to dismantle 10 of their "frontline" guard posts. However, the later agreement for each Korea to preserve one "frontline" post was upheld as well. The "frontline" guard post which was preserved on the North Korean side of the DMZ was visited by Kim Jong Un in 2013 when tensions were rising between both Koreas.http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20181120000703 ===Disarmament=== The Joint Security Area will no longer be armed with weapons of any kind after it is demined as well. Official disarmament of this area is complete on October 25. Removal of weapons from all of the DMZ's 22 "frontline" guard posts was complete on November 10, 2018 "frontline ===Withdrawal of Personnel=== Any military personnel, regardless of their country, who is stationed at the Joint Security Area on either side of the border will be forced to withdraw when demining is complete.https://thediplomat.com/2018/10/koreas-begin-land-mine-removal-at-joint-security-area-per-recent-military-agreement/https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/national-international/South-Korea-North-Korea-Removing-Mines-494759751.html On October 25, 2018, Personnel was replaced with 35 unarmed security guards.http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/25/c_137557889.htmhttps://www.apnews.com/d035517244c64a879d07f62897a80223 Withdrawal of military personnel from all of the DMZ's 22 "frontline" guard posts was complete on November 10, 2018.http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-korea-guard-post-withdrawals-20181110-story.htmlhttp://www.hastingstribune.com/koreas-complete-the-disarming-of-guard-posts/article_bddc8489-3eb5-5982-b626-a4ed5d6e69dc.htmlhttps://www.sfchronicle.com/world/article/North-South-dismantle-22-guard-posts-along-border-13380901.php ===Opening of Inter-Korean Liaison Office=== The first meeting at the [[Inter-Korean Liaison Office]] occurred between delegates from both Koreas on October 22, 2018. The meeting concerned, among other things, forestry cooperation between both Koreas.http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/866851.htmlhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2018/10/22/North-South-Korea-discuss-pine-wilt-disease-prevention-tree-nursery/7971540195207/ Forest ecology cooperation was one of the commitments in the Pyongyang Declaration. A meeting later took place at the office between South Korean Vice Minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism Roh Tae-kang and North Korean Vice-Minister of Physical Culture and Sports Won Kil U on November 2, 2018, talks at the office resulted in agreements for a unified Korean team at the 2020 Olympics and to hold the 2032 Summer Olympics in both Koreas.http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/11/02/0200000000AEN20181102000651315.htmlhttps://www.nknews.org/2018/11/two-koreas-agree-to-submit-bid-on-co-hosting-2032-summer-olympics/ Another meeting was held on November 2, 2018 between South Korean Vice Unification Minister [[Chun Hae-sung]] and his North Korean counterpart, [[Jon Jong-su]]. Both men are co-heads of the office and each serve as liaison chief for their perspective country.http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20181102000484http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/11/02/0200000000AEN20181102003552315.html Both Chun and Jon discussed cooperation in various joint-Korean projects. Following the meeting, it was reported that inter-Korean on-site railway inspections and a performance by a Pyongyang art troupe in Seoul were issues which remained unresolved. On November 7, 2018, health officials from North and South Korea held talks at the Inter-Korean Liaison Office to discuss health care cooperationhttps://www.unikorea.go.kr/eng_unikorea/news/news/?boardId=bbs_0000000000000033&mode=view&cntId=54486&category=&pageIdx= Greater cooperation between both countries in the field of health care was another one of the commitments in Pyongyang Declaration. ===Joint Celebration of October 4 Declaration=== On October 4, 2018, Pyongyang allowed a South Korean delegation to participate in a joint celebration of the 11th anniversary of the [[October 4 Declaration]].http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/10/05/0200000000AEN20181005001554315.html This event also commemorated the 100th anniversary of the [[March 1st Movement]] and was one of the commitments in the Pyongyang Declaration. ===Ratification of Summit Agreements=== On October 23, 2018, Moon ratified both the Pyongyang Declaration and the CMA just hours after they were approved by his cabinet.https://www.whig.com/article/20181023/AP/310239955#// Following the approval, it was acknowledged that the South Korean Constitution allows the President to approve treaties without consent from the National Assembly so long as they do not "give huge financial burdens to the people."http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/10/24/0200000000AEN20181024000700315.html ===Restoration of Economic Cooperation=== On October 30, 2018, members of a South Korean ad hoc parliamentary special committee on inter-Korean economic cooperation held its first meeting and saw members of both the ruling and opposition parties agree to restore inter-Korean economic cooperation which has ceased for about 10 years and to normalize operations of the now-shuttered North Korean [[Kaesong Industrial Region]] and the suspended joint tour project on Mount Kumgang, also located in the North, when conditions are met.http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/10/30/0200000000AEN20181030009000315.html Joint economic zones in these two areas were also commitments of the Pyongyang Declaration. ===Failure to Uphold October Commitments=== Some commitments of the Pyongyang Declaration which had been scheduled to be held in October 2018 were not upheld.http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20181031000772 Among them were a joint survey for a cross-border railway and sports and health meetings to bolster exchange in the respective areas. A Pyongyang art troupe also did not hold a scheduled performance in Seoul. The Pyongyang Declaration called for a Pyongyang art troupe to hold a performance in Seoul sometime in October 2018 as well. ===South Korean observation of North Korean WMD Program=== On October 31, 2018, Kim Min-ki of the ruling Democratic Party issued a statement revealing that officials from South Korea's National Intelligence Service had observed several of North Korea's nuclear and missile test sites and that they were now ready for the upcoming international inspections.https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/31/north-korea-reportedly-readies-nuclear-missile-sites-for-inspectors.html Kim also stated the now inactive [[Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site]] and the Sohae Satellite launching ground were included in these observations. The visit by the intelligence officials was also meant to make preparations for the international experts to observe the dismantling of the North Korean nuclear and missile test sites as well. The international experts will also be allowed to witness the dismantling of other North Korean nuclear and missile test sites as well. [[Yongbyon Nuclear Scientific Research Center|Yongbyon]], the last nuclear facility in North Korea which has yet to be closed, has also been inactive during the past year as well. ===Buffer, No-Fly, and Peace Zones Established=== On November 1, 2018, officials from the South Korea's Ministry of Defense confirmed that [[buffer zones]] were established across the DMZ by the North and South Korean militaries. In compliance with Comprehensive Military Agreement, the buffer zones help ensure that both Koreas will ban hostility on land, sea and air. The buffer zones stretch from the north of Deokjeok Island to the south of Cho Island in the West Sea and the north of Sokcho city and south of Tongchon County in the East (Yellow) Sea.https://www.nknews.org/2018/10/two-koreas-end-military-drills-begin-operation-of-no-fly-zone-near-mdl-mnd/ Both North and South Korea are prohibited from conducting live-fire artillery drills and regiment-level field maneuvering exercises or those by bigger units within 5 kilometers of the Military Demarcation Line (MDL).http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/11/01/0200000000AEN20181101002500315.html [[No-fly zone]]s have also been established along the DMZ to ban the operation of drones, helicopters and other aircraft over an area up to 40 km away from the MDL. Both Koreas also established "peace zones" near their disputed Yellow Sea border. A buffer zone was also established in the Yellow Sea's [[Northern Limit Line]] (NLL).http://www.tellerreport.com/news/--%5Bfile%5D-nll-buffer-zone--there-is-a-marine-corps--.BkJ1sMYnm.html ===Establishment of Joint Utilization Zones along Han and Imjin River estuaries=== On November 4, 2018, a 20-member team consisting of 10 people from North Korea and 10 people from South Korea began a joint inter-Korean survey which will lead to the development Joint Utilization Zones along the Han and River [[estuary|estuaries]].https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20181105001451315https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9yN3QUUXNik The Zones will allow civilians to access the estuary for tourism, ecological protection and the collection of construction aggregate under the protection of militaries from both sides of the Korean border. The establish of this Joint Utilization Zone and a joint survey beforehand is one of the objectives of the Comprehensive Military Agreement On November 5, 2018, the councils of South Korea's Gangwon and Gyeonggi provinces, which border the DMZ, signed a “peace working agreement” at Dorasan Station in Paju, giving local approval to the Joint Utilization Zones.http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/869084.html ===Unified Sports Bids=== In October 2018, both Koreas participated as a [[unified Korean sporting teams|united team]] at the [[2018 Asian Para Games]].https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1070952/more-history-for-unified-korean-sport-at-asian-para-games On October 4, 2018, it was announced that both Koreas would also participate as a unified team at the [[2019 World Men's Handball Championship]] as well.http://www.handball19.com/en/newspage/unifiedKoreaWillPlay/ On November 2, 2018, officials from both North and South Korea announced that their countries would participate at the 2020 Summer Olympics, held in Tokyo, Japan, as a unified team.https://edition.cnn.com/2018/11/02/sport/north-south-korea-tokyo-2020-olympics-spt-intl/index.htmlhttps://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/national/north-south-korea-set-to-combine-for-tokyo-2020-co-host-2032-olympics The officials from both Koreas also announced that the letters they would send to the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) regarding their bids for hosting the 2032 Summer Olympics would also consist of co-host bids so that the Olympic activities would take place in both nations if their bids were accepted as well.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2032-koreas/olympics-north-south-korea-to-send-letter-to-ioc-on-joint-2032-bid-idUSKCN1N70PT Participation as a united team in the 2020 Summer Olympics and other international games, as well as the bid for both Koreas to co-host 2032 Summer Olympic Games, were obligations which were agreed to in the Pyongyang Declaration. On November 26, 2018, the [[Unesco]] accepted a joint bid by North and South Korea and granted world cultural heritage status to [[Ssireum|Korean wrestling]].https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46341279https://www.reuters.com/article/us-korea-wrestling-unesco/north-south-korea-join-hands-to-get-wrestling-on-u-n-culture-list-idUSKCN1NV1F4 The sport, which consists of [[Folk wrestling|traditional wrestling]],https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/article222178040.html is known in South Korea as Ssireum and in North Korea as Ssirum. ===Inter-Korean transportation=== On October 14, 2018, North and South Korea, agreed to meet the summit's goal of restoring railway and road transportation which had been cut since the Korean War by either late November or early December 2018.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-southkorea/koreas-to-reconnect-roads-rail-u-s-concerned-over-easing-sanctions-idUSKCN1MP0D0 On November 22, 2018, North and South Korea completed construction to connect a three kilometer road along the DMZ.https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20181122006452315?section=national/defensehttps://www.aa.com.tr/en/politics/south-north-korea-connect-border-road-through-dmz/1318769 This road, which crosses the MDL Korean land border, consists of 1.7 km in South Korea and 1.3 km in North Korea. The road was reconnected for the first time in 14 years in an effort to assist with a process at the DMZ's Arrowhead Hill involving the removal of landmines and exhumation of Korean War remains.http://www.asianews.it/news-en/After-14-years,-a-road-to-unite-the-Koreas-and-recover-the-remains-of-the-fallen-45545.htmlhttps://www.yahoo.com/news/north-south-korea-join-roads-124905264.htmlhttps://www.cairnspost.com.au/news/national/north-and-south-korea-join-roads-after-14-years/video/af8a644187eb15024a900b16826ebd24 On November 24, 2018, it was announced that the UN Security Council had granted South Korea exemptions from sanctions so that both North and South Korea could finally conduct a planned inter-Korean railway survey.https://www.apnews.com/bbc5aafaf4b54a2b95cac6ee9f808da6https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-Relations/South-Korea-secures-UN-sanctions-exemption-for-inter-Korean-rail-surveyhttps://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFKCN1NT01Lhttps://www.yenisafak.com/en/news/skorea-secures-un-sanctions-exemption-for-inter-korean-railway-survey-3467254 In November 2008, North Korea shut down the railroad link between North and South Korea. However, railroad transportation from South Korea to North Korea resumed again on November 30, 2018, when a South Korean train carrying railroad inspectors entered North Korea.http://world.kbs.co.kr/service/news_view.htm?lang=e&Seq_Code=141207https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/29/asia/north-south-korea-train-intl/index.html The same day, 30 officials from North and South Korea began an 18-day survey in both Koreas to connect the Korean railroads.https://www.voanews.com/a/koreas-survey-railway-tracks-cut-since-the-korean-war/4681029.html https://www.thenewstribune.com/news/business/article222406610.html The survey, which had previously been obstructed by the Korean Demilitarized Zone's (DMZ) "frontline" guard posts and landmines located at the DMZ's Arrowhead Hill, consists of a 400-kilometre (248-mile) railroad section between Kaesong and Sinuiju that cuts through the North's central region and northeastern coast.https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/11/30/first-train-decade-departs-south-korea-north-korea/ The inter-Korean survey, as well as the railroad ground-breaking ceremony which will follow to symbolize the opening of the new inter-Korean railroad in this area,https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2018/11/356_259637.html were both objectives of the Pyongyang Agreement. ==See also== * {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox recurring event |name= Sturgis Motorcycle Rally |logo= |image= Main Street Sturgis South Dakota Bike Week.jpg |imagesize=240px |caption= Motorcycles lined up on Main Street during the Sturgis motorcycle rally. |location= [[Sturgis, South Dakota|Sturgis]], [[South Dakota]], United States |years_active= |founded= {{start date|1938|8|14}} |dates= First week in August | last = August 4-13, 2017 | next = August 3-12, 2018 |genre= [[Motorcycle rally]] |attendance=highest: 739,000 (2015)<ref name=dj2015>{{citation|title=Attendance at 75th Sturgis Motorcycle Rally estimated at 739,000 people, beating 2000 record|publisher=Associated Press|via=''[[Daily Journal (Franklin, Indiana)|Daily Journal]]'' (Franklin, Indiana)|date=September 22, 2015|url=http://www.dailyjournal.net/view/story/d2bbb3006a964982ba036f3102640856/SD--Sturgis-Rally-Attendance|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923060204/http://www.dailyjournal.net/view/story/d2bbb3006a964982ba036f3102640856/SD--Sturgis-Rally-Attendance|archivedate=September 23, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |patron= |website= {{url|sturgis.com}} }} The '''Sturgis Motorcycle Rally''' is an American [[motorcycle rally]] held annually in [[Sturgis, South Dakota|Sturgis]], [[South Dakota]], for ten days<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kotatv.com/content/news/Can-you-handle-10-official-days-of-the-Sturgis-Rally-399102701.html|title=Can you handle 10 official days of the Sturgis Rally?|last=KOTA|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref> usually during the first full week of August. In 2015 the city of Sturgis officially expanded the dates to have the rally start on the Friday before the first full week of August and end on the second Sunday. It was begun in 1938 by a group of Indian Motorcycle riders and was originally held for stunts and races. Attendance has historically been around 500,000 people, reaching a high of over 700,000 in 2015. The event generates around $800 million in revenue.<ref name=dj2015/><ref>{{Citation |url= http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-sturgis-motorcycle-rally-20140805-story.html |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date= August 5, 2014 |last=Fleming |first=Charles |title= Sturgis Motorcycle Rally by the numbers }}</ref>
==History== The first rally was held by [[Indian Motocycle Manufacturing Company|Indian Motorcycle]] riders on August 14, 1938, by the Jackpine Gypsies motorcycle club.<ref name="official-history">[http://sturgismotorcyclerally.com/timeline/ Official Site: Timeline]</ref> The club still owns and operates the tracks, [[Hillclimbing|hillclimb]], and field areas where the rally is centered. The first event was called the "Black Hills Classic" and consisted of a single race with nine participants and a small audience. The founder is [[J.C. Hoel|Clarence "Pappy" Hoel]]. He purchased an Indian motorcycle franchise in Sturgis in 1936 and formed the Jackpine Gypsies that same year.<ref name="official-history"/> The Jackpine Gypsies were inducted to the [[Motorcycle Hall of Fame]] in 1997.<ref>{{mhof|344|Jackpine Gypsies}}</ref> Hoel was inducted into the AMA Hall of Fame the following year, in 1998.<ref>{{mhof|198|J.C. Hoel}}</ref>
The focus of a motorcycle rally was originally [[Motorcycle sport|racing]] and [[stunt]]s. In 1961, the rally was expanded to include the Hillclimb and Motocross races.<ref name="official-history" /> This could include half-mile track racing (the first year in Sturgis, there were 19 participants), intentional board wall crashes, ramp jumps and head-on collisions with automobiles.
The Sturgis Rally has been held every year, with exceptions during World War II. For instance, in 1942, the event was not held due to gasoline rationing.<ref name="official-history"/>

Year !! SDDOT traffic count !! Official attendance |- | 1990 || 528,676 || 400,000 |- | 1999 || 539,475 || 325,000 |- | 2000 || 604,441 || 633,000 |- | 2001 || 530,667 || 410,000 |- | 2002 || 561,752 || 450,000 |- | 2003 || 605,140 || 502,000 |- | 2004 || 547,370 || 514,951 |- | 2005 || 524,656 || 525,250 |- | 2006 || 449,527 || 456,968 |- | 2007 || 461,507 || 507,234 |- | 2008 || 405,475 || 414,917 |- | 2009 || 394,009 || 442,163 |- | 2010 || 459,968 || 466,769 |- | 2011 || 415,367 || 416,727 |- | 2015 || {{circa}} 1,000,000<ref name=KSCJ>{{citation|title=Sturgis Rally Sets Records|author=Woody Gottburg|date= August 10, 2015 |publisher=KSCJ|url=http://kscj.com/2015/08/10/sturgis-rally-sets-records/}}</ref> || 739,000<ref name=dj2015/> |- | 2016 || {{circa}}360,000<ref name=AP2017/> || 448,000<ref name=Amundson2017/> – 463,412<ref>{{citation|title=Sturgis rally attendance down nearly 40 percent|newspaper=Rapid City Journal|date=October 28, 2016|url=http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/sturgis-rally-attendance-down-nearly-percent/article_1e58edbe-c1cb-5da7-aa2e-7ac0c69b6e97.html}}</ref> |- | 2017 || 376,033<ref name=AP2017>{{citation|title=South Dakota Completes 77th Sturgis Motorcycle Rally|publisher=Associated Press|date=August 14, 2017|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/south-dakota/articles/2017-08-14/south-dakota-completes-77th-sturgis-motorcycle-rally}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=2017 rally is quiet, cool, calm|date=August 14, 2017|newspaper=Rapid City Journal|url=http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/rally-quiet-cool-calm/article_639424e1-c196-5e59-a7ed-b3206d5bf452.html}}</ref> || 480,000<ref name=Amundson2017>{{citation|newspaper=News-Tribune|location=Duluth|title=Official attendance at Sturgis Motorcycle Rally set at 480,000|author= Barry Amundson |date= October 12, 2017}}</ref> |}
==Rally impact on community== For many years the city has been in a licensing agreement with a community non-profit, Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, Inc., and its predecessor-in-interest, the Sturgis Area Chamber of Commerce, that generates millions of dollars in royalties and sponsorship dollars.<ref name="Black Hills State University">{{citation|title=70th Sturgis motorcycle rally statistics compiled by the city of Sturgis and the rally department|publisher=[[Black Hills State University]]|date=February 8, 2011|url=http://www.bhsu.edu/StudentLife/Living/ResidenceLife/SturgisRally/RallyNews/tabid/11232/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/3453/70th-Sturgis-motorcycle-rally-statistics-compiled-by-the-city-of-Sturgis-and-the-rally-department.aspx|accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref> In 2012 the City Council reaffirmed this relationship through a unanimous proclamation.
The City of Sturgis has calculated that the Rally brings over $800 million to South Dakota annually.<ref name="Black Hills State University"/> The City of Sturgis earned almost $270,000 in 2011 from selling event guides and sponsorships. The rally makes up 95% of the city's annual revenue.<ref>[http://www.daytondailynews.com/photo/ap/top-news/sturgis-rally/pwrkr/ Sturgis area businesses make 95% of their annual revenue from the 7 days of the rally.]</ref>
There were 405 individuals jailed at the 2004 rally, and approximately $250,000 worth of motorcycles stolen annually.<ref>{{citation|last=Dalton|first=Aaron|title=Biggest thing on two wheels.(TECHWATCH: This Month)|journal=Popular Mechanics|publisher=Hearst Magazines via HighBeam Research.|date=August 1, 2005|accessdate=2013-01-25|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-134210834.html}}</ref> Rally-goers are a mix of white-collar and blue-collar workers and are generally welcomed as an important source of income for Sturgis and surrounding areas.<ref name=npr2000>{{citation|work=Morning Edition|publisher=[[National Public Radio]] via HighBeam Research.|title=Profile: Thousands of Harley riders converge on small South Dakota town every year for a rally|date=August 9, 2000|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-31350798.html|accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref> The rally turns local roads into "parking lots",<ref name=npr2000/> and draws local law enforcement away from routine patrols.<ref>{{citation|title=Security + Service = Satisfaction.|journal=Journal of Property Management|publisher=via HighBeam Research|date=May 1, 2000 | last=Vellani|first=Karim|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-63795876.html|accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref> Furthermore, the large numbers of people visiting the town and region served as a model for the state of Oregon in preparation for the [[solar eclipse of August 21, 2017]], given the expected impact on emergency services.<ref name="Oregonian Hospital Preparations">{{Cite web |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/health/index.ssf/2017/08/antidote_for_rattlesnake_bites.html |title=Eclipse 2017: Hospitals stock up on blood, rattlesnake bite antidote |last=Lynne |first=Terry |date=2017-08-10 |website=The Oregonian |access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref>
The [[Lakota people|Lakota Indian tribe]] in coalition with other tribes has protested the large amount of alcohol distributed at the event so close to the sacred [[Bear Butte]], but also acknowledged that income from the event was important to the region and also benefits some members of the tribes.<ref>{{citation|publisher=National Public Radio via HighBeam Research.|work=All Things Considered|date=August 2, 2006|title=In Sturgis, a Clash Over Motorcycle Rally|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-127005495.html|accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref>
There has been a number of mysterious, unsolved deaths at the Rally.<ref>http://www.sturgismotorcyclerally.com/assets/docs/uploads/rally-stats.pdf</ref>
==Transportation to Sturgis== Many attendees of the Sturgis Rally have families, bring their children and drive campers towing [[motorcycle trailer]]s to the rally, and ride their motorcycles just the last few miles. The director of the rally estimated in 2005 that less than half the attendees actually rode there.<ref name=nyt2005>{{cite news|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2005/08/05/automobiles/05sturgis.html|title=The Really Easy Rider|first=Michelle| last= Higgins|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 5, 2005|accessdate=2009-02-12}}</ref> Shipping companies transport thousands of motorcycles to Sturgis for attendees who arrive via airline.<ref name=nyt2005/>
==Black Hills Run== The '''Black Hills Run''' is a route favored by motorcycle riders, across the [[Black Hills]] from [[Deadwood, South Dakota|Deadwood]] to [[Custer State Park]], South Dakota. It reached the height of its popularity between 1939 and 1941. The popularity of the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally attracted additional attention to the route in recent years. The pine forested mountains of the Black Hills make for a unique scenic motorcycle ride.<ref>McKechnie, Gary. ''Great American Motorcycle Tours'' Avalon Travel Publishing, 2002. ({{ISBN|1-56691-448-5}})</ref>
==Media coverage==
===Print and online=== The ''[[Rapid City Journal]]'' features daily coverage of the Sturgis Rally.<ref>{{citation|title=Sturgis Rally Daily|url=http://rapidcityjournal.com/sturgisrallydaily/|newspaper=[[Rapid City Journal]]|accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref>
The ''[[Seattle Times]]'' covered some of the 2008 Sturgis Rally while rock band [[Judd Hoos]] was playing at the [[The HomeSlice Group|Loud American Roadhouse]].<ref>{{citation|title=Seattle Times|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/off-duty-seattle-cop-who-shot-hells-angel-feared-for-his-life/|newspaper=[[Seattle Times]]|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
===Television=== In 1997, the crew from the ''[[Cops (TV series)|COPS]]'' television series attended the rally, as well as [[Dennis Rodman]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0545885/|title=Cops Episode 147: Sturgis Bike Rally in South Dakota | publisher=imdb.com|accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref>
From 1996 to 1999, [[World Championship Wrestling]] held a [[pay-per-view]] event called [[Road Wild]] ([[WCW Hog Wild|Hog Wild]] for the 1996 event).<ref>{{cite news|title=2007 Wrestling Almanac & Book of Facts|work=Wrestling's Historical Cards|publisher=Kappa Publishing|year= 2007|pages=144}}</ref>
Annual television coverage of the festival by the [[VH1 Classic]] network includes interviews and performances as well as rock music videos. The rally was featured in 2005 as part of the [[ESPN]] ''[[SportsCenter]]'' promotion ''[[50 States in 50 Days]]''.<ref name="50/50">{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chat/sportsnation/fiftyfifty/index |title=50 States in 50 Days |date=August 10, 2005 |publisher=ESPN.com |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050810014037/http://sports.espn.go.com/chat/sportsnation/fiftyfifty/index |archivedate=August 10, 2005 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref>
Starting in 2009 an American [[reality television series]] began airing on the [[truTV]] network: ''[[Full Throttle Saloon]]'', showing the inner operations at the world's largest biker bar just prior to the rally opening and for the duration of the rally each year.
Sturgis was also featured on ''[[American Pickers]]'' Season 4, Episode 6, "What Happens In Sturgis...". Originally aired January 2, 2012 on the History Channel. ". . .When Mike tells Frank let's pack up for a trip to South Dakota, Frank says he can't. He's secretly going to his 30th annual trip to the legendary Sturgis motorcycle rally, but says he'll cover the shop. . .".<ref>[[List of American Pickers episodes]]</ref> Sturgis has also been featured in the TV Show [[Pawn Stars]] in which [[Rick Harrison|Richard Harrison]], [[Corey Harrison]] visit Sturgis with [[Chumlee Russell]] on his birthday.
===Documentaries=== The [[Travel Channel]] has aired two one-hour (43 minutes runtime) documentaries about Sturgis: * {{Cite AV media|title=Sturgis: The Wild Ride|people=Daniel Cesareo, Doug DePriest (executive producers)|medium=Television broadcast|publisher=Travel Channel|year=2010|url=http://www.travelchannel.com/TV_Shows/Sturgis_Wild_Ride}}<ref>{{IMDb title|id=1809352|title=Sturgis: The Wild Ride}}</ref> * {{Cite AV media|title=Sturgis Cops|people=Daniel Cesareo, Doug DePriest (executive producers)|medium=Television broadcast|publisher=Travel Channel|year=2010|url=http://www.travelchannel.com/TV_Shows/Sturgis_Cops}}<ref>{{IMDb title|id=1809351|title=Sturgis Cops}}</ref>
[[File:Indian-ed-spilker-771686.jpg|thumb|Indian Ed Spilker, One of the original Jackpine gypsies and cofounder of the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.]]

{{About|the novel|the animated featurette|The Small One|the Bing Crosby album|The Small One (album)}} {{italic title}} '''''The Small One''''' is a 1947 Christmas novelette written by [[Charles Tazewell]] and illustrated by [[Franklin Whitman]] about a young boy who has to sell his donkey named Small One.<ref>http://data.desmoinesregister.com/famous-iowans/charles-tazewell</ref> It was adapted into [[The Small One|the Disney featurette]] in Christmas 1978.
[[File:The Small One front cover book.jpg|thumb|Front cover of ''The Small One'']]
==Plot== The story starts with Padre who tells his boy Pablo about how donkeys aren't stubborn after Pablo is frustrated with the attitude of his donkey Cupido, who is doing nothing to work for him. So Padre tells the story that happened many miles from where they live in El Camino Del Notre [[Old Mexico]].
Small One was an old donkey who belonged to a woodcutter, whose son was kinder to him. One day the boy's father tells him to sell Small One to the tanner as he feels there is no use for him, as he is too old to work. The boy insists not to take him to the tanner's, but his father tells him not to cry over a donkey. The boy realizes there's no use arguing, so he goes off to town to sell Small One, but doesn't tell his father that he will sell him elsewhere. The first place he sees is an auction, where the bidder is selling horses. The boy asks the bidder to sell his donkey, but the bidder refuses and he and the crowd make fun of Small One which upsets the boy; the boy then sets off to see who else would buy him.
The boy and Small One both feel hopeless by sundown, and decide to go to the tanner's after all. Just then, the boy meets a nice man, who asks him if he can buy Small One, as he and his wife have a long way to go and she isn't very well. The boy sells the man Small One for one piece of [[silver]] and hurries to the gates before the guards close it. The boy promises Small One that when he grows up, he will buy him again and keep him. The man explains to the guards at the gate that his name is Joseph, his wife's name is Mary and they are heading to [[Bethlehem]], so they make their way into the distance. In the end the boy says his last goodbyes to his friend, and Small One, as told by Padre, made it all the way to Bethlehem with Joseph and Mary and saw the king being born; despite how he was made fun of, he became part of the Christmas miracle.
In the end, Pablo and Padre listen, wondering whether it was a donkey's hooves or to the sound of the church bells rehearsing the chimes for Christmas morning, but only Cupido knew what it really was.
==Characters== * Small One - The old and weary donkey who made his place at Christmas. * The Boy - Small One's friend who is kind to him. * Woodcutter - The Boy's father. * Auctioneer - A bidder who refused to sell Small One and made fun of him. * Pablo - The boy who is told by Padre the story of The Small One. * Padre - The teller of The Small One story that is told to Pablo. * Cupido - Padre and Pablo's Donkey. * Joseph - The buyer of Small One who he takes to Bethlehem with Mary riding him. * Mary - Joseph's wife who rides Small One to Bethlehem.
