|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/19/tunisia-political-prisoners |title=Tunisia set to release political prisoners |work=The Guardian |date=19 January 2011 |location=London |first=Peter |last=Beaumont}} *Elections to a [[Tunisian Constituent Assembly election, 2011|Constituent Assembly]] on 23 October 2011{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/08/us-tunisia-election-idUSTRE7571R020110608 |title=Tunisia election delayed until 23 October |agency=Reuters |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=8 June 2011}} *[[2013 protests in Tunisia|Subsequent protests]] against the interim Islamist-led constituent assembly. Government agrees to resign and engages in dialogue discussing the country's new transition.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/10/23/uk-tunisia-crisis-idUKBRE99M0ML20131023|title=Thousands protest before Tunisia crisis talks|date=23 October 2013|agency=Reuters}} *Start of the [[Arab Spring]] | side1 = | side2 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | injuries = 2,147 | fatalities = 338[http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/05/05/report-338-killed-during-tunisia-revolution/ Report: 338 killed during Tunisia revolution]. Associated Press via FoxNews. 5 May 2012. | arrests = | casualties_label = | notes = }} {{History of Tunisia}} The '''Tunisian Revolution'''{{cite web|author=Ryan, Yasmine |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/2011126121815985483.html |title=How Tunisia's revolution began – Features |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}} was an intensive campaign of [[civil resistance]], including a series of street [[demonstration (protest)|demonstrations]] taking place in [[Tunisia]], and led to the ousting of longtime president [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] in January 2011. It eventually led to a thorough [[democratization]] of the country and to free and democratic elections. The demonstrations were caused by high [[unemployment]], food [[inflation]], [[corruption]],{{cite web|title=A Snapshot of Corruption in Tunisia|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/middle-east-north-africa/tunisia/snapshot.aspx|publisher=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate=7 February 2014}}{{Cite news|last=Spencer |first=Richard |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/tunisia/8258077/Tunisia-riots-US-warns-Middle-East-to-reform-or-be-overthrown.html |title=Tunisia riots: Reform or be overthrown, US tells Arab states amid fresh riots |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=13 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011 |location=London}} a lack of [[political freedom]]s like [[freedom of speech]]{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=Yasmine |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/20111614145839362.html |title=Tunisia's bitter cyberwar |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=14 January 2011}} and poor [[living conditions]]. The protests constituted the most dramatic wave of social and political unrest in Tunisia in three decades{{cite web|url=http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/01/02/tunisia_s_protest_wave_where_it_comes_from_and_what_it_means_for_ben_ali |title=Tunisia's Protest Wave: Where It Comes From and What It Means for Ben Ali | The Middle East Channel |publisher=Mideast.foreignpolicy.com |date=3 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{Cite news|author=Borger, Julian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/29/tunisian-president-vows-punish-rioters|title=Tunisian president vows to punish rioters after worst unrest in a decade|date=29 December 2010|work=The Guardian |location=UK|accessdate=29 December 2010}} and resulted in scores of deaths and injuries, most of which were the result of action by police and security forces against demonstrators. The protests were sparked by the [[self-immolation]] of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] on 17 December 2010[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12120228 Tunisia suicide protester Mohammed Bouazizi dies], BBC, 5 January 2011.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/22/world/africa/22sidi.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2&src=twrhp|author=Fahim, Kareem|title=Slap to a Man's Pride Set Off Tumult in Tunisia|work=The New York Times|date=21 January 2011|page=2|accessdate=23 January 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/23/weekinreview/23worth.html?src=twrhp|title=How a Single Match Can Ignite a Revolution|author=Worth, Robert F.|work=The New York Times|date=21 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}} and led to the ousting of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali 28 days later on 14 January 2011, when he officially resigned after fleeing to [[Saudi Arabia]], ending 23 years in power.{{Cite news|author=Davies, Wyre |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12195025 |title=Tunisia: President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali forced out |publisher=BBC News |date=15 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2011/01/16/18669320.php |title=Uprising in Tunisia: People Power topples Ben Ali regime |publisher=Indybay |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Labour unions were an integral part of the protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347 |title=Trade unions: the revolutionary social network at play in Egypt and Tunisia |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |accessdate=11 February 2011}} The [[Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet]] was awarded the [[2015 Nobel Peace Prize]] for "its decisive contribution to the building of a pluralistic democracy in Tunisia in the wake of the Tunisian Revolution of 2011".{{cite web|title=The Nobel Peace Prize 2015 - Press Release|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/laureates/2015/press.html|website=Nobelprize.org|publisher=Nobel Media AB 2014|accessdate=9 October 2015}} The protests inspired similar actions throughout the Arab world, known as the [[Arab Spring]]. ==Naming== In Tunisia and the wider Arab world, the protests and change in government are called '''the Revolution''' or sometimes the '''Sidi Bouzid Revolt''', derived from [[Sidi Bouzid]], the city where the initial protests began.{{cite web|url=http://libcom.org/forums/news/protests-spread-tunisia-29122010 |title=The Sidi Bouzid Revolution: Ben Ali flees as protests spread in Tunisia |publisher=libcom.org |accessdate=8 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8thJM2nmd_g |title=Revolte Tunisie Sidi bouzid 3 |publisher=YouTube |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} In the Western media, these events have been dubbed the '''Jasmine Revolution or Jasmine Spring'''{{cite web|last=Carvin|first=Andy|title=Sidi Bou Zid: A Jasmine Revolution in Tunisia|url=http://storify.com/acarvin/sidi-bou-zid-a-jasmine-revolution-in-tunisia|publisher=Storify|accessdate=7 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211214152/http://storify.com/acarvin/sidi-bou-zid-a-jasmine-revolution-in-tunisia|archive-date=11 December 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} after Tunisia's national flower and in keeping with the geopolitical nomenclature of "[[color revolutions]]". The name "Jasmine Revolution" originated from American journalist [[Andy Carvin]], but it was not widely adopted in Tunisia itself.{{cite news|last=Carvin|first=Andy|title=Online Reports Detail Chaos, Deaths in Tunisia|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/01/13/132888992/tunisia-protests-social-media|accessdate=7 December 2013|publisher=NPR|date=13 January 2011|location=Washington DC}} In fact, the debate surrounding the name and the poetic influences behind the Tunisian revolution was a popular question among Tunisian intellectuals themselves as seen in the following article: [https://www.academia.edu/9808087/Tunisias_revolution_of_dignity_and_freedom_cannot_be_colour-codedhttp_www.tni.org_article_tunisia-revolution-dignity-and-freedom-can-not-be-colour-coded Tunisia's revolution of dignity and freedom cannot be color-coded]. The name adopted in Tunisia was the '''Dignity Revolution''', which is a translation of the [[Tunisian Arabic]] name for the revolution {{lang|ar|ثورة الكرامة}} (''{{transl|ar|Thawrat al-Karāmah}}'').Amira Aleya-Sghaier, The Tunisian Revolution: The Revolution of Dignity, The Journal of the Middle East and Africa Vol. 3, Iss. 1,2012 Within Tunisia, [[Coup d'État of 7 November 1987 (Tunisia)|Ben Ali's rise to power in 1987]] was also known as the Jasmine Revolution.{{cite web|author=Malaponti, Olivier |url=http://www.mediapart.fr/club/blog/olivier-malaponti/150111/revolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=Révolution de jasmin ? |work=Mediapart |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011 |language=french |trans-title=Jasmine Revolution?}} ([https://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediapart.fr%2Fclub%2Fblog%2Folivier-malaponti%2F150111%2Frevolution-de-jasmin-0 english translation]){{Cite news|url=https://arabist.net/blog/2011/1/17/why-you-shouldnt-call-it-the-jasmine-revolution.html|title=Why you shouldn't call it the "Jasmine Revolution"|work=The Arabist|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US}} ==Background== President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] had ruled Tunisia since 1987, mostly as a one-party state with the [[Democratic Constitutional Rally]] (known as the RCD) in power. His government was characterized by the development of Tunisia's private sector in favor of foreign investment, and the repression of political opposition. Foreign media and NGOs criticized his government, which was supported by the United States and France. As a result, the initial reactions to Ben Ali's abuses by the U.S. and France were muted, and most instances of socio-political protest in the country, when they occurred at all, rarely made major news headlines. Riots in Tunisia were rare{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/10/world/main7233191.shtml |title=Deadly Riots in Tunisia Shut Down Schools |publisher=CBS News |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} and noteworthy, especially since the country is generally considered to be wealthy and stable as compared to other countries in the region.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011191414183128.html |title=Protesters killed in Tunisia riots |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} Any form of protests in the country were previously successfully repressed and kept silent by the former regime and protesters would be jailed for such actions, as were for example protests by hundreds of unemployed demonstrators in [[Redeyef]] in 2008.{{cite web|first1=Jean-Marie|last1=Lemaire|first2=Rim|last2=Mathlouti|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110215-reporters-tunisia-redeyef-gafsa-mining-phosphate-accusations-competition-rigged-ben-ali-supporters-protests-journalists |title=Redeyef, the precursor of the Tunisian revolution |publisher=France 24 |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2011}} ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' also said that Tunisian activists are amongst the most outspoken in its part of the world with various messages of support being posted on ''Twitter'' for Bouazizi.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122063745828931.html |title=Riots reported in Tunisian city – Africa – Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=20 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} An [[op-ed]] article in the same network said of the action that it was "suicidal protests of despair by Tunisia's youth." It pointed out that the state-controlled [[National Solidarity Fund]] and the [[National Employment Fund]] had traditionally subsidized many goods and services in the country but had started to shift the "burden of providence from state to society" to be funded by the ''[[bidonville]]s'', or [[shanty towns]], around the richer towns and suburbs.{{clarify|date=January 2011}} It also cited the "marginalisation of the agrarian and arid central and southern areas [that] continue[s] unabated."{{cite web|author=Sadiki, Larbi |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2010/12/20101227142811755739.html |title=Tunisia: The battle of Sidi Bouzid – Opinion – Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=27 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} The protests were also called an "uprising" because of "a lethal combination of poverty, unemployment and political repression: three characteristics of most Arab societies."{{cite web|author=Andoni, Lamis |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2010/12/20101231161958792947.html |title=The rebirth of Arab activism – Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=31 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} ==Mohamed Bouazizi and Sidi Bouzid== Twenty-six-year-old [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] had been the sole income earner in his extended family of eight. He operated a vegetable or apple cart (the contents of the cart are disputed) for seven years in [[Sidi Bouzid]] 190 miles (300 km) south of Tunis. On 17 December 2010, a female officer confiscated his cart and produce. Bouazizi, who had had such an event happen to him before, tried to pay the 10-dinar fine (a day's wages, equivalent to 7USD). In response the policewoman insulted his deceased father and slapped him. The officer, [[Faida Hamdy|Faida Hamdi]], stated that she was not even a policewoman, but a city employee who had been tasked that morning with confiscating produce from vendors without licenses. When she tried to do so with Bouazizi a scuffle ensued. Hamdi says she called the police who then beat Bouazizi.{{cite journal|title=The Woman Who Blew Up the Arab World|journal=World Affairs Journal|date=17 May 2012|url=http://www.worldaffairsjournal.org/blog/michael-j-totten/woman-who-blew-arab-world|accessdate=17 May 2012|author=Totten, Michael J. |quote="Barack Obama mentioned me in a speech. He said I was a cop. He said I slapped Mohamed Bouazizi. He's a stupid fool for not checking. Americans are great people, but you need to do a better job of checking your information."}} A humiliated Bouazizi then went to the provincial headquarters in an attempt to complain to local municipality officials and to have his produce returned. He was refused an audience. Without alerting his family, at 11:30 am and within an hour of the initial confrontation, Bouazizi returned to the headquarters, doused himself with a flammable liquid and set himself on fire. Public outrage quickly grew over the incident, leading to protests.{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043557,00.html | title=Bouazizi: The Man Who Set Himself and Tunisia on Fire | author=Abouzeid, Rania | date=21 January 2011|work=Time}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/922279--suicide-protest-helped-topple-tunisian-regime | title=Suicide protest helped topple Tunisian regime | location=Toronto | work=The Star | date=14 January 2011}} This immolation and the subsequent heavy-handed response by the police to peaceful marchers caused riots the next day in [[Sidi Bouzid]] that went largely unnoticed, although [[social media]] sites such as Facebook and YouTube featured images of police dispersing youths who attacked shop windows and damaged cars. Bouazizi was subsequently transferred to a hospital near Tunis. In an attempt to quell the unrest President [[Zine el Abidine Ben Ali]] visited Bouazizi in hospital on 28 December 2010. Bouazizi died on 4 January 2011.{{Cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE70408420110105 | title=Tunisian who sparked rare protests dies: relatives -Reuters | agency=Reuters | date=5 January 2011 | accessdate=14 January 2011}} ==Protests== {{Revolution sidebar}} On 28 November 2010, [[WikiLeaks]] and five major newspapers (Spain's ''[[El País]]'', France's ''[[Le Monde]]'', Germany's ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', the United Kingdom's ''[[The Guardian]]'', and the United States' ''[[The New York Times]]'') simultaneously published the first 220 of 251,287 leaked documents labeled confidential.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/07/wikileaks-tunisia-first-lady |title=WikiLeaks cables: Tunisia blocks site reporting 'hatred' of first lady|first1=Ian |last1=Black|first2=Middle East|last2=editor|date=7 December 2010|work=The Guardian}} These included descriptions of corruption and repression by the Tunisian regime. It is widely believed that the information in the WikiLeaks documents contributed to the protests, which began a few weeks later. There were reports of police obstructing demonstrators and using [[tear gas]] on hundreds of young protesters in [[Sidi Bouzid]] in mid-December 2010. The protesters had gathered outside regional government headquarters to demonstrate against the treatment of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]]. Coverage of events was limited by Tunisian media. On {{Nowrap|19 December}}, extra police were present on the streets of the city.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122063745828931.html|title=Images posted on social-network sites show police intervening to halt disturbances ignored by national media|date=20 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=20 December 2010}} On 22 December, Lahseen Naji, a protester, responded to "hunger and joblessness" by electrocuting himself after climbing an [[electricity pylon]]. Ramzi Al-Abboudi also killed himself because of financial difficulties arising from a business debt by the country's [[micro-credit]] solidarity programme. On {{Nowrap|24 December}}, Mohamed Ammari was fatally shot in the chest by police in Bouziane. Other protesters were also injured, including Chawki Belhoussine El Hadri, who died later on {{Nowrap|30 December}}.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/201012317536678834.html|title=A protester dies after being shot by police, as activists criticise government repression of protests|date=31 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=31 December 2010}} Police claimed they shot the demonstrators in "self-defence." A "quasi-curfew" was then imposed on the city by police.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/20101224235824708885.html|title=Protester dies in Tunisia clash: Several wounded in Sidi Bouzid as demonstrations against unemployment turn violent|date=25 December 2010 |publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=25 December 2010}} Rapper [[El Général]], whose songs had been adopted by protesters, was arrested on 24 December but released several days later after "an enormous public reaction".{{cite news|last=Walt |first=Vivienne |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2049456,00.html |title=El Général and the Rap Anthem of the Mideast Revolution |work=Time |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} Violence later increased as Tunisian authorities and residents of [[Sidi Bouzid Governorate]] encountered each other once again. The protests had reached the capital [[Tunis]]{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122682433751904.html|title=Protests continue in Tunisia|date=26 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=26 December 2010}} on {{Nowrap|27 December}} with about 1,000 citizens expressing solidarity{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2010/12/20101228182021539319.html |title=Tunisia jobless protests rage |publisher=Al Jazeera|date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} with residents of Sidi Bouzid and calling for jobs. The rally, which was called by independent trade union activists, was stopped by security forces. The protests also spread to [[Sousse]], [[Sfax]] and [[Meknassy]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/20101227204853391930.html |title=Job protests escalate in Tunisia |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} The following day the Tunisian Federation of Labour Unions held another rally in [[Gafsa]] which was also blocked by security forces. At the same time about 300 lawyers held a rally near the government's palace in Tunis.{{cite web|author=Randeree, Bilal |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122819724363553.html |title=Tensions flare across Tunisia |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Protests continued again on the {{Nowrap|29 December}}. On 30 December, police peacefully broke up a protest in [[Monastir, Tunisia|Monastir]] while using force to disrupt further demonstrations in [[Sbikha]] and [[Chebba]]. Momentum appeared to continue with the protests on {{Nowrap|31 December}} and further demonstrations and public gatherings by lawyers in Tunis and other cities following a call by the Tunisian National Lawyers Order. Mokhtar Trifi, president of the Tunisian Human Rights League (LTDH), said that lawyers across Tunisia had been "savagely beaten." There were also unconfirmed reports of another man attempting to commit suicide in [[El Hamma]].{{cite news |url=http://24sur24.posterous.com/video-today-a-young-unemployed-man-trying-to|title=video: today a young unemployed man trying to commit a suicide in El Hamma #sidibouzid|date=31 December 2010|work=Nawaat|accessdate=31 December 2010}} On 3 January 2011, protests in [[Thala, Tunisia|Thala]] over unemployment and a high [[cost of living]] turned violent. At a demonstration of 250 people, mostly students, in support of the protesters in Sidi Bouzid, police fired tear gas; one canister landed in a local mosque. In response, the protesters were reported to have set fire to tyres and attacked the office of [[Constitutional Democratic Rally]].{{cite web|author=Randeree, Bilal |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201114101752467578.html |title=Violent clashes continue in Tunisia – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Some of the more general protests sought changes in the government's online censorship, where a lot of the media images have been broadcast. Tunisian authorities also allegedly carried out [[phishing]] operations to take control of user passwords and check online criticism. Both state and non-state websites had been hacked.{{cite web|author=Ryan, Yasmine |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/20111614145839362.html |title=Tunisia's bitter cyberwar |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} On 6 January 95% of Tunisia's 8,000 lawyers went on strike, according to the chairman of the national [[bar association]]. He said "The strike carries a clear message that we do not accept unjustified attacks on lawyers. We want to strongly protest against the beating of lawyers in the past few days."{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201116193136690227.html |title=Thousands of Tunisia lawyers strike |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} It was reported on the following day that teachers had also joined the strike.{{Cite news|last=Sandels |first=Alexandra |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-tunisia-riots-20110108,0,1279820.story |title=Rioting spreads across Tunisia; unrest also reported in Algeria |work=Los Angeles Times |date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} In response to 11 January protests police used riot gear to disperse protesters ransacking buildings, burning tires, setting fire to a bus and burning two cars in the working class suburb of [[Ettadhamen-Mnihla]] in Tunis. The protesters were said to have chanted "We are not afraid, we are not afraid, we are afraid only of God." Military personnel were also deployed in many cities around the country.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/01/2011111214716877786.html |title=Tunisia unrest spreads to capital – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=14 January 2011}} On 12 January, a reporter from the Italian state-owned television broadcaster ''[[RAI]]'' stated that he and his cameraman were beaten with batons by police during a riot in Tunis' central district and that the officers then confiscated their camera.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rai.tv/dl/RaiTV/programmi/media/ContentItem-0ec2c1f9-c6f3-48cd-8166-bc1eca6d13a9-tg3.html|title=Tunisi. Aggredita la troupe del Tg3|date=12 January 2011|publisher=[[TG3]]|language=Italian|accessdate=12 January 2011}} A night time curfew was also ordered in Tunis after protests and clashes with police.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12175959 |title=Tunisia imposes curfew in Tunis to quell protests |publisher=BBC News |date=13 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011}} [[Hizb ut-Tahrir]] also organised protests after [[Friday prayer]] on 14 January to call for re-establishing the Islamic [[caliphate]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNRhq4fFAto&feature=player_embedded |title=Protests organized by Hizb ut-Tahrir calling for the re-establishment of the Islamic caliphate |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=15 January 2011}} A day later, it also organised other protests that went to the [[9 April Prison]] to free political prisoners.{{cite web |url=http://www.alokab.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=56256 |title=Call for re-establishing Caliphate in streets of Tunisia and freeing political prisoners |publisher=Alokab.com |accessdate=15 January 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707115506/http://www.alokab.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=56256 |archive-date=7 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Also on 14 January (the same day that Ben Ali fled), [[Lucas Dolega]], a photojournalist working for [[European Pressphoto Agency]], was hit in the forehead by a [[tear gas]] canister allegedly fired by the police at short range; he died two days later.Laurent, Olivier (16 January 2011) "[http://www.bjp-online.com/british-journal-of-photography/news/1937417/french-photographer-dies-tunisia UNESCO, French government call for investigation of Lucas Dolega's death [update 7]]", ''British Journal of Photography'' {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119010423/http://www.bjp-online.com/british-journal-of-photography/news/1937417/french-photographer-dies-tunisia |date=19 January 2011 }}Walker, David (18 January 2011) "[http://www.pdnonline.com/pdn/news/Photographer-Dies-of-1505.shtml Photographer dies of injuries in Tunis]", ''Photo District News''Bruggmann, Matthias et al. (18 January 2011) "[http://www.visapourlimage.com/news/4967.do Lucas Mebrouk Dolega] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717214041/http://www.visapourlimage.com/news/4967.do |date=17 July 2011 }}", Visa pour l'image.Puech, Michel (22 January 2011) "[https://archive.is/20110121210150/http://www.lalettredelaphotographie.com/entries/lucas-dolega-succumbs-to-a-hand-grenade Lucas Dolega succumbs to a hand grenade]", ''La Lettre de la photographie''. ==The end of Ben Ali's rule== During a national television broadcast on {{Nowrap|28 December}}, [[List of Presidents of Tunisia|President]] [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] criticized people for their protests calling the perpetrators "extremists and mercenaries" and warned of "firm" punishment. He also accused "certain foreign television channels of broadcasting false allegations without verification, based on dramatization, fermentation and deformation by media hostile to Tunisia."{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122823238574209.html|title=Tunisia president warns protesters|date=28 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=28 December 2010}} His remarks were ignored and the protests continued.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/20101229122733122341.html|title=Tunisia struggles to end protests|date=29 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=29 December 2010}} On 29 December, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali shuffled his cabinet to remove his communications minister [[Oussama Romdhani]], while also announcing changes to the trade and handicrafts, religious affairs, communication and youth portfolios.{{Cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2010/12/29/131431.html|title=Tunisian president removes ministers after protests|date=29 December 2010|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|accessdate=29 December 2010}} The next day he also announced the dismissal of the governors of Sidi Bouzid, [[Jendouba Governorate|Jendouba]] and [[Zaghouan Governorate|Zaghouan]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/more-heads-roll-tunisian-social-crisis|title=More heads roll in Tunisian social crisis|date=30 December 2010|work=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310064305/http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/more-heads-roll-tunisian-social-crisis|archivedate=10 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} In January 2011, Ben Ali said 300,000 new jobs would be created, though he did not clarify what that meant. However, he also described the protests as "the work of masked gangs that attacked at night government buildings and even civilians inside their homes in a terrorist act that cannot be overlooked." [[Ahmed Najib Chebbi]], the leader of the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]], then said that despite official claims of police firing in self-defense "the demonstrations were non-violent and the youths were claiming their rights to jobs" and that "the funeral processions [for those killed on 9 January] turned into demonstrations, and the police fired [at] the youths who were at these ... processions." He then criticised Ben Ali's comments as the protesters were "claiming their civil rights, and there is no terrorist act...no religious slogans," while accusing Ben Ali of "looking for scapegoats." He further criticised the additional jobs offered as mere "promises."{{cite web|author=Randeree, Bilal |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201111016239214548.html |title=Tunisian leader promises new jobs – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Several [[weblog]]gers and the rapper Hamada Ben Amor, better known by his stage name [[El Général]],Ryan, Yasmine (7 January 2011) [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/01/20111718360234492.html Tunisia arrests bloggers and rapper – Africa]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 9 September 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.myvidster.com/video/908155/el_gnral_the_voice_of_Tunisia_english_subtitles |title=el général, the voice of Tunisia, english subtitles |publisher=Myvidster.com |accessdate=26 January 2011}} were arrested, but the rapper and some of the bloggers were later released.{{Cite news|last=Lewis |first=Aidan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12180954 |title=Tunisia protests: Cyber war mirrors unrest on streets |publisher=BBC News |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} [[Reporters Without Borders]] said the arrest of at least six bloggers and activists, who had either been arrested or had disappeared across Tunisia, was brought to their attention and that there were "probably" others.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111718360234492.html |title=Tunisia arrests bloggers and rapper|publisher=Al Jazeera |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} [[Tunisian Pirate Party]] activists Slah Eddine Kchouk, [[Slim Amamou]] (later released,{{cite web|url=http://jilliancyork.com/2011/01/06/tunisian-blogger-slim-amamou-arrested|title=Tunisian Blogger Slim Amamou Arrested}}https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/18/tunisia-dissident-blogger-minister Accessed 26/12/2016 and eventually appointed Secretary of State for Sport and Youth by the incoming government){{cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/slim404 |title=Slim Amamou (slim404) on Twitter |publisher=Twitter |accessdate=26 January 2011}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/9363808.stm |title=Turmoil in Tunisia: As it happened on Monday |publisher=BBC News |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and [[Azyz Amamy]] were arrested but later released.{{cite web|url=http://christianengstrom.wordpress.com/2011/01/09/tunisia-arrests-pirate-party-bloggers/ |title=Tunisia arrests Pirate Party bloggers |publisher=Christianengstrom.wordpress.com |date=23 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/pirate-party-members-arrested-in-tunisian-censorship-revolt-110108/ |title=Pirate Party Members arrested |publisher=Torrentfreak.com |date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}https://rsf.org/en/news/tunis-based-netizens-slim-amamou-and-azyz-amamy-arrested accessed 26/12/2016 [[Hamma Hammami]], the leader of the banned [[Tunisian Workers' Communist Party]] and a prominent critic of Ben Ali, was arrested on 12 January, though he was released two days later.[http://www.expatica.com/fr/news/french-news/tunisia-releases-opposition-communist-leader-party_123299.html Tunisia releases opposition Communist leader: party] Expatica, 14 January 2011 On 10 January, the government announced the indefinite closure of all schools and universities in order to quell the unrest.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12155670 |title=Tunisia closes schools and universities following riots |publisher=BBC News |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Days before departing office, Ben Ali announced that he would not change the [[Constitution of Tunisia|present constitution]], which was read as, in effect, promising to step down in 2014 due to his age.{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110113-tunisia-protests-ben-ali-speech-will-not-seek-reelection |title=Ben Ali rules out 'presidency for life' as chaos spreads| publisher=France 24| date=13 January 2011}} On 14 January, [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali|Ben Ali]] dissolved his government and declared a [[state of emergency]]. Officials said the reason for the emergency declaration was to protect Tunisians and their property. People were also barred from gathering in groups of more than three, otherwise courting arrest or being shot if they tried to run away.{{Cite news|author=Maktabi, Rima |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/14/tunisia.protests/ |title=Tunisian PM takes over as interim president as Ben Ali flees|publisher=CNN |date=15 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-01-14/tunisia-in-state-of-emergency-president-to-dissolve-parliament.html |title=Tunisia President Hands Power to Prime Minister |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=14 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110117123208/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-01-14/tunisia-in-state-of-emergency-president-to-dissolve-parliament.html |archivedate=17 January 2011 }} Ben Ali also called for an election within six months to defuse demonstrations aimed at forcing him out.{{cite news|author=Walker, Peter |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/14/tunisian-president-dismisses-government-violence |title=Tunisian president declares state of emergency and sacks government |work=The Guardian |date= 14 January 2011|accessdate=28 October 2011 |location=London}} ''[[France24]]'' also said the military took control of the airport and closed the country's [[airspace]].{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110114-tunisia-prime-minister-assumes-power-amid-reports-president-ben-ali-has-left/ |title=Prime minister takes over as Ben Ali flees Tunisian turmoil |publisher=France 24 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} On the same day, Ben Ali fled the country for [[Malta]] under Libyan protection{{cite news|last=Laghmari |first=Jihen |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-13/tunisia-president-to-stand-down-in-2014-slash-prices-amid-riots.html |title=Tunisia President Hands Power to Prime Minister |publisher=Bloomberg |date=13 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and landed in [[Jeddah]], Saudi Arabia, after France rejected a request for the plane to land on its territory. Saudi Arabia cited "exceptional circumstances" for their heavily criticised decision to give him asylum saying it was also "in support of the security and stability of their country." The Saudi decision was "not out of sympathy" for Ben Ali (who had long fought against [[Islamism|Islamists]] in Tunisia). Saudi Arabia demanded Ben Ali remain "out of politics" as a condition for accepting him.{{Cite news|title=Ben Ali gets refuge in Saudi Arabia|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201111652129710582.html|publisher=Al Jazeera}} ==Initial impact of Ben Ali's overthrow== [[File:Zabadehors.JPG|thumb|Translation from French: Ben Ali out]] Following Ben Ali's departure from the country, a [[state of emergency]] was declared. Army Commander Rashid Ammar pledged to "protect the revolution."{{cite news|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-31/egypt-s-military-leaders-tighten-six-decade-government-grip-amid-protests.html |title=Egypt's Military Tightens Control Over Regime |publisher=Bloomberg |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} Prime Minister [[Mohamed Ghannouchi]] then briefly took over as acting President.{{cite news|last=Ganley |first=Elaine |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AF_TUNISIA_RIOTS?SITE=CTDAN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |title=NewsTimes.com – The Latest |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=14 January 2011 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On the morning of 15 January, Tunisian state TV announced that Ben Ali had officially resigned his position and Ghannouchi had handed over the Presidency to parliamentary speaker [[Fouad Mebazaa]], with Ghannouchi returning to his previous position as Prime Minister.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/16/world/africa/16tunis.html|title=New Change of Power Raises Questions in Tunisia|author=Kirkpatrick, David D. | work=The New York Times|date=15 January 2011}} This was done after the head of Tunisia's Constitutional Court, Fethi Abdennadher, declared that Ghannouchi did not have right to power, and confirmed [[Fouad Mebazaa]] as acting President under Article 57 of the Constitution. Mebazaa was given 60 days to organise new [[Tunisian parliamentary election, 2011|election]]s.{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110115/D9KOQ2B01.html |title=Unrest engulfs Tunisia after president flees |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=23 November 2012}} Mebazaa said it was in the country's best interest to form a [[National Unity government]].{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110115/D9KOQT000.html |title=Tunisia's interim president backs a unity govt |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=23 November 2012}} [[INTERPOL]] confirmed that its National Central Bureau (NCB) in Tunis had issued a global alert via INTERPOL's international network to seek the location of and arrest former Tunisian President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali and six of his relatives.{{cite web |url=http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2011/PR007.asp |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110130042124/http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2011/PR007.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 January 2011 |title=Interpol Press Release |publisher=Interpol |accessdate=8 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }} A commission to reform the constitution and current law in general was set up under [[Yadh Ben Achour]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/en-tunisie-un-nouvel-executif-en-marche_1466513_3212.html |title=En Tunisie, le nouvel exécutif prépare les élections |work=Le Monde |location=Paris |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} There were also calls by the opposition to delay the elections and hold them in six or seven months and with international supervision.{{cite web |url=http://www.lepoint.fr/fil-info-reuters/trois-chefs-de-l-opposition-dans-le-gouvernement-tunisien-16-01-2011-129922_240.php |title=Trois chefs de l'opposition dans le gouvernement tunisien, actualité Reuters |work=Le Point |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119072852/http://www.lepoint.fr/fil-info-reuters/trois-chefs-de-l-opposition-dans-le-gouvernement-tunisien-16-01-2011-129922_240.php# |archive-date=19 January 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} [[File:Ordre Armee tunisienne 2011.JPG|thumb|Tunisian soldiers serving as [[gendarmarie|gendarmes]]]] [[File:Révolution des Jasmins 05.jpg|thumb|A Tunisian army tank deployed in front of the [[Cathedral of St. Vincent de Paul]] in Tunis]] Following Ben Ali's departure, violence and looting continued and the national army was reported to be extensively deployed in Tunisia. The identity of the perpetrators has not been determined. A high official of the Tunisian military, however, also stated that elements loyal to former President Ben Ali have deployed across the country.{{Cite news|journal=Le Monde|title=Paris prêt à bloquer les comptes du clan Ben Ali en France|date=15 January 2011|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/15/l-elysee-dit-surveiller-les-avoirs-financiers-tunisiens-en-france_1466190_3212.html#ens_id=1245377|accessdate=15 January 2011|quote=L'identité de ces hommes n'a pas été établie, mais un haut responsable militaire, s'exprimant sous couvert de l'anonymat, a affirmé que des éléments loyaux au président Ben Ali se déployaient à travers la Tunisie.}} The capital's main train station was also torched.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011115135844457245.html |title=Army on streets amid Tunisia unrest |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} A prison director in [[Mahdia]] freed about 1,000 inmates following a prison rebellion that left 5 people dead.{{Cite news |author1=Ganley, Elaine |author2=Bouazza, Bouazza Ben |lastauthoramp=yes |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2042712,00.html |archive-url=http://web.archive.bibalex.org/web/20110216151317/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2042712,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 February 2011 |title=1,000 Inmates Freed Amid Tunisia Unrest |work=Time |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Many other prisons also had jail breaks or raids from external groups to force prisoner releases, some suspected to be aided by prison guards. Residents who were running out of necessary food supplies had armed themselves and barricaded their homes, even to the extent of having formed armed neighbourhood watches. Al Jazeera's correspondent said there were apparently three different armed groups: the police (250,000 people of the country's population were supposedly part of the police force), security forces from the Interior Ministry, and irregular militias supportive of Ben Ali who were vying for control.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111167140864373.html |title=Tunisia gripped by uncertainty |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Gun battles took place near the Presidential Palace between the Tunisian army and elements of security organs loyal to the former regime after Ali Seriati, head of presidential security, was arrested and accused of threatening state security by fomenting violence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12202283 |title=Tunis gun battles erupt after Ben Ali aide arrested |publisher=BBC News |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} The Tunisian army was reportedly struggling to assert control.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/01/2011116102520122416.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119051628/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/01/2011116102520122416.html |archivedate=19 January 2011 |title=Tunisia army tries to restore calm |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Gunfire continued in Tunis and Carthage as security services struggled to maintain law and order.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011116191514949896.html |title=Tunisia PM to unveil new government – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=23 November 2012}} The most immediate result of the protests was seen in increased [[Right to Internet access|internet freedoms]].{{cite web|author=York, Jillian C. |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/201111410250537313.html |title=Tunisia's taste of internet freedom – Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=15 January 2011}} While commentators were divided about the extent to which the internet contributed to the ousting of Ben Ali from power,Luke Alnutt (2012)[http://www.rferl.org/content/tunisia_can_we_please_stop_talking_about_twitter_revolutions/2277052.html TANGLED WEB Tunisia: Can We Please Stop Talking About 'Twitter Revolutions'?]. Retrieved 15 January 2011.{{cite web|url=http://technosociology.org/?p=263 |title=Tunisia, Twitter, Aristotle, Social Media and Final and Efficient Causes |publisher=technosociology |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Facebook remained accessible to roughly 20% of the population throughout the crisis{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-01-15/tunisa-protests-the-facebook-revolution |title=Tunisia Protests: The Facebook Revolution |work=The Daily Beast |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119222902/http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-01-15/tunisa-protests-the-facebook-revolution/ |archivedate=19 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} whilst its passwords were hacked by a country-wide [[man-in-the-middle attack]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2011/01/the-inside-story-of-how-facebook-responded-to-tunisian-hacks/70044/ |title=The Inside Story of How Facebook Responded to Tunisian Hacks |work=The Atlantic |date=24 January 2011 |first=Alexis |last=Madrigal |accessdate=26 January 2011}} YouTube and [[DailyMotion]] became available after Ben Ali's ouster,{{cite web|author=York, Jillian C. |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/201111410250537313.html |title=Tunisia's taste of internet freedom |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and the [[Tor (anonymity network)|''Tor'' anonymity network]] reported a surge of traffic from Tunisia.{{cite web|url=https://blog.torproject.org/blog/update-tor-usage-tunisia |title=Update on Tor usage in Tunisia |publisher=The Tor Blog |accessdate=26 January 2011}} ==Ghannouchi government 15 January-27 February 2011== [[File:Manifestation UGTT anti RCD I.JPG|thumb|A protest by the General Labour Union]] [[File:Révolution des Jasmains 01.jpg|thumb|Anti-RCD graffiti and vandalism]] * 17 January - Ghannouchi announces his cabinet, including twelve members of the ruling RCD, the leaders of three opposition parties ([[Mustapha Ben Jafar]] from the [[Democratic Forum for Labour and Liberties]] (FTDL), [[Ahmed Brahim (Tunisian politician)|Ahmed Brahim]] of the [[Ettajdid Movement]], and [[Ahmed Najib Chebbi]] of the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90031186?Tunisian%20prime%20minister%20invites%20all%20political%20parties%20to%20form%20unity%20government |title=Tunisian prime minister invites all political parties to form unity government |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120091646/http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90031186?Tunisian%20prime%20minister%20invites%20all%20political%20parties%20to%20form%20unity%20government |archivedate=20 November 2011 }} three representatives from the [[Tunisian General Labour Union]] (UGTT) and representatives of civil society (including prominent blogger [[Slim Amamou]]). Three notable movements not included in the national unity government were the banned [[Ennahda Movement]], the communist [[Tunisian Workers' Communist Party]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12225856|title=Could Tunisian opposition groups re-ignite the revolt?|author=Sadiki, Larbi | publisher=BBC News|date=19 January 2011}} and the secular reformist [[Congress for the Republic]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12214649|title=Tunisia: Key players | publisher=BBC News | date=27 February 2011}} Daily protests begin against the presence of [[Constitutional Democratic Rally|RCD]] members in the new government. Thousands of anti-RCD protesters rally in a protest with relatively little violence between security services and protestors.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Article/201009115896853 |title=Tunisia: Violence As New Govt Announced |publisher=BSkyB |accessdate=23 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120165651/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Article/201009115896853 |archivedate=20 January 2011 }} * 18 January - Street protests against RCD participation in the new government include hundreds of people demonstrating in Tunis, [[Sfax]], [[Gabes]], [[Bizerta]], [[Sousse]] and [[Monastir, Tunisia|Monastir]]. The three members of the UGTT and Ben Jafaar of the FTDL quit it, saying that they had "no confidence" in a government that still featured members of the RCD party that ruled under Ben Ali.Chrisafis, Angelique (18 January 2011) [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/18/tunisia-caretaker-government-ministers-quit "Tunisia's caretaker government in peril as four ministers quit,"] ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 22 January 2011David D. Kirkpatrick, [http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20110122/znyt03/101223013 "Protesters Say Ruling Party in Tunisia Must Dissolve,"] ''Herald Tribune'' (21 January 2011). [. Retrieved 22 January 2011]{{Cite news| title=Tunisia announces withdrawal of 3 ministers from unity gov't: TV | date=18 January 2011 | work=[[People's Daily]] | url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7264930.html |accessdate=20 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vrgMnytL?url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7264930.html |archivedate=20 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} [[Mustapha Ben Jafar]] also refuses to take up his post. The interim President, Mebazaa, and Prime Minister Ghannouchi resign their memberships of the RCD in a bid to calm protests against the inclusion of RCD members in the government. Ghannouchi states that all members of the national unity government had "clean hands."{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12220862|title=Tunisia: New government leaders quit ruling party | publisher=BBC News | date=18 January 2011}} * 19 January - Protests continue - with the demand that no "former allies" of Ben Ali should remain in the government, including hundreds of protestors marching in central Tunis and about 30 staging a sit-in near the [[Ministry of the Interior (Tunisia)|Ministry of the Interior]], ignoring a curfew.{{Cite news| title=Tunisia leader vows break with past | date=19 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011119201252887481.html |accessdate=19 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vrfRSxUe?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011119201252887481.html |archivedate=19 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} Protestors also called for the RCD to be disbanded. * 20 January - Hundreds of people demonstrate outside the RCD headquarters in Tunis with the same aims, and protests in other towns around Tunisia are reported.{{Cite news| title=Tunisia cabinet to lift party bans | date=20 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201112014107109184.html |accessdate=20 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vstKVA6X?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201112014107109184.html |archivedate=20 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} [[Zouhair M'Dhaffer]], a close confidant of Ben Ali seen as the main architect of the 2002 constitutional reform to lift term limits, resigns from the government. All other RCD ministers resign from the party on the same day and the central committee of the RCD disbands itself on that day.{{cite web|url=http://www.taz.de/1/politik/afrika/artikel/1/ben-alis-partei-ohne-politbuero/ |title=Regierungsbildung in Tunesien: Ben Alis Partei ohne Politbüro |work=die Tageszeitung |accessdate=26 January 2011|language=German}}{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/01/20/8-Tunisian-leaders-quit-ruling-party/UPI-57211295546906/ |title=8 Tunisian leaders quit ruling party |agency=United Press International |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} The new government announces in its first sitting that all banned parties would be legalised and that all political prisoners would be freed.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111215365840302.html |title=Tunisia mourns unrest victims |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} It was unclear whether the ban on these parties and the ban on Hizb ut-Tahrir would be lifted until 12 March 2011, when they were declared as banned again.{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gYSo-aNuYiO1QSK1E6-18ALIC6JQ?docId=CNG.4caadd27ed3929bab816dcdc2d6a2705.841 |title=Tunisian Ministry of Interior denies permit for 5 parties including Hizb ut-Tahrir |agency=Agence France-Presse |work=Google news |accessdate=22 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525115907/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gYSo-aNuYiO1QSK1E6-18ALIC6JQ?docId=CNG.4caadd27ed3929bab816dcdc2d6a2705.841 |archivedate=25 May 2012 }} The Ennahda Movement on the other hand, got a permit.{{cite news|title=Exiled opposition chief returns to Tunisia|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110118/world-news/exiled-opposition-chief-returns-to-tunisia.345888|accessdate=15 March 2012|newspaper=The Times|location=Malta|date=18 January 2011}}{{cite news|title=President and PM quit ruling party but hold on to Thousands participate in protests outside the Interior Ministry.{{Cite news| title= Protests hit Tunisia amid mourning | date=21 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011121104023232257.html |accessdate=21 January 2011
