resigning after holding transparent and free elections within six months.{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/tunisia_pm_quit_politics/2283958.html |title=Tunisian PM Pledges To Quit Politics After Elections |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} * 23 January - Thousands of police begin to join protests in Tunis over salaries and to deflect blame over political deaths attributed to them during Ben Ali's rule.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1349766/Tunisia-riots-Police-join-protesters-streets.html |title=Tunisia riots: Police join protesters on the streets |work=Daily Mail |date=24 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011 |location=London}} * 24 January - As army chief [[Rachid Ammar]] announces that the armed forces are on the side of the protesters and would "defend the revolution", rumours emerge that the government would be replaced by a council of "wise men".{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011124163051778391.html |title=Tunisia cabinet to be reshuffled |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} * 25 January - Protesters continue to defy a curfew in Tunis{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/antigovt-protests-intensify-in-tunisia/141431-2.html |title=Anti-govt protests intensify in Tunisia |publisher=CNN-IBN |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} as reverberations continued around the region. * 26 January - International arrest warrants issued for Ben Ali, his wife and several other members of his family.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/26/tunisia.warrant/ |title=Tunisia issues warrant for ousted leader, family members |publisher=CNN |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} * 27 January - Prime Minister Mohammed Ghannouchi reshuffles his government and announces a [[Second cabinet of Mohamed Ghannouchi|new cabinet]]. Six former members of the RCD party leave the interim government, including Defence Minister, Foreign Minister, Finance Minister and Interior Minister. Apart from the prime minister, the new government retained just two ministers from Ben Ali's old government—the industry and international cooperation ministers—but neither of these had been a member of his ruling RCD party. This move was seen as meeting one of the demands of the protesters in Tunisia,{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12302232 |title=Tunisia announces major cabinet reshuffle after protest |publisher=BBC News |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} and was supported by the UGTT, which stated its support for the reorganised cabinet.Kirkpatrick, David D. (27 January 2011) [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/africa/28tunisia.html Most Members of Old Cabinet in Tunisia Step Down]. ''The New York Times'' New ministers included independent state attorney [[Farhat Rajhi]] as interior minister, retired career diplomat [[Ahmed Ounaies]] as foreign minister and [[Elyes Jouini]] (an economist living in France) as minister delegate to the prime minister in charge of administrative and economic reform.[http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7275560.html Tunisian labor union backs reshuffle of interim government]. People's Daily Online, 28 January 2011. *28 January - Hundreds of people camp beside Mohamed Ghannouchi's office protesting against his remaining in the interim government.{{Cite news | first=Lin | last=Noueihed | title=Tunisia protesters turn government HQ into campsite | date=28 January 2011 | agency=Reuters | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE70R13720110128?sp=true | accessdate=29 January 2011 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w6ESsvhm?url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE70R13720110128?sp=true | archivedate=29 January 2011 | deadurl=no | df=dmy-all }} A student coordinating food distribution at the protests, Saifeddine Missraoui, stated, "We are not leaving here until Ghannouchi leaves and we get a brand new government." Another protestor, Naim Garbousi from Casbah Media Relations, stated, "The new line-up is a theatre. The symbols of the old regime are left, like Ghannouchi. Why is he insisting on staying? We are 10 million people, there will surely be someone who can replace him." * 2 February - Former interior minister, Rafik Belhaj Kacem arrested by his successor, Farhat Rajhi, concurrently with accusations of former allies of Ben Ali trying to destabilize the state.{{cite web |url=http://dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=2&article_id=124437 |title=Politics – Tunisia interior minister says predecessor arrested |work=The Daily Star |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011 |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20171011235210/http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Feb-02/89593-tunisia-interior-minister-says-predecessor-arrested.ashx |archive-date=11 October 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} * 3 February - All 24 regional governors are replaced.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/03/us-tunisia-protests-governors-idUSTRE7127X520110203 |title=Tunisia replaces regional governors |agency=Reuters |date=3 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}} The Interior Ministry replaces 34 top-level security officials in a bid to bring change to the police, security services and spies that were a part of Ben Ali's security infrastructure. The interim [[head of state]] Fouad Mebazaa promises a national dialogue to address protester demands.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121210345525985.html |title=Middle East rulers make concessions – Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=13 February 2011}} * 4 February - Sidi Bouzid again the scene of protests despite the arrests of two security forces personnel for deaths of two. Several hundred people turned up at the local police station as a result of medical staff at a local hospital saying they found signs of burning on the victims' bodies. On 5 February, protesters in [[El Kef]] called for the local police chief Khaled Ghazouani to be sacked for abusing his authority. Protesters threw stones and small firebombs as well as burned two cars, one of which was a police vehicle. Police first responded with tear gas and then fired on the protesters in which two people were killed immediately and two died in hospital, 15 others were also wounded. The region's [[prefect]] Mohamed Najib Tlijali called for calm{{cite news|author=Bouazza Ben Bouazza|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/05/tunisian-police-chief-fires-crowd-kills-1796100495/ |title=Tunisian police fire on crowd, killing 2|publisher=Fox News Channel |date=5 February 2011}} as the police chief was arrested.* 13 February - Foreign minister [[Ahmed Ounaies]] resigns over controversial praise he gave to French Foreign Minister [[Michele Alliot-Marie]], who was being criticised for her ties to Ben Ali.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121314913447933.html |title=Tunisian foreign minister resigns |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}} [[Mouldi Kefi]] becomes the new foreign minister on 21 February.{{cite web|url=http://www.shemsfm.net/actualite/actualites_tunisie-news/mouldi-kefi-est-le-nouveau-ministre-des-affaires-etrangeres/12 |title=Mouldi Kefi est le nouveau Ministre des Affaires Etrangères |publisher=Shemsfm.net |accessdate=1 March 2011}} *6 February - The former ruling RCD's activities are suspended to prevent a breakdown in state security, with an order for dissolution of the party pending.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/06/tunisia-protests-party-idUSLDE7150FS20110206 |title=Tunisia suspends activities of ex-ruling party |agency=Reuters |date=6 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/05/tunisian-police-chief-fires-crowd-kills/ |agency=Associated Press|title=Tunisian minister suspends ex-ruling party |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=5 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newstime.co.za/WorldNews/Ben_Ali%E2%80%99s_RCD_Party_Banned_By_Interim_Tunisian_Government/20217/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525210655/http://www.newstime.co.za/WorldNews/Ben_Ali%E2%80%99s_RCD_Party_Banned_By_Interim_Tunisian_Government/20217/ |archivedate=25 May 2011 |title=Ben Ali's RCD Party Banned By Interim Tunisian Government : NewsTime : World News |publisher=NewsTime |date=7 February 2011}} * 7 February - Tunisia's Defense Ministry calls up recently retired soldiers as the country is still struggling to contain unrest. Soldiers retired within the last five years, as well as those who had recently completed their mandatory military service, were asked to report for duty.{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110207/D9L853V00.html |title=Tunisia calls up reserve troops amid unrest |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=8 February 2011}} First steps taken on a bill that would give the interim President, Fouad Mebazaa, emergency powers, allowing him to bypass the RCD-dominated parliament.{{cite news|last=Bouderbala |first=Sofia |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5juBHIGNP6tw4F6SZgHqEqUv_71IA?docId=CNG.f633c1f93ead7c4ea82895634cdfeeaf.481 |agency=Agence France-Presse |title=Tunisian lawmakers approve emergency powers |publisher=Google |accessdate=8 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208041905/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5juBHIGNP6tw4F6SZgHqEqUv_71IA?docId=CNG.f633c1f93ead7c4ea82895634cdfeeaf.481 |archivedate=8 February 2011 }} *8 February - An agreement is reached between the interim government and the [[UGTT]] on nomination of new governors.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7281826.html |title=Tunisian gov't reaches agreement with labor union on governor nomination – People's Daily Online |work=People's Daily |accessdate=11 February 2011}} *9 February - The bill to grant [[Fouad Mebazaa]] emergency powers is passed on 9 February. He states that all banned parties will be legalised within days.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12410704 |title=Tunisia senate agrees to widen presidential powers |publisher=BBC News |date=9 February 2011|accessdate=11 February 2011}} The bill also allows Mebazaa to ratify international human rights treaties without parliament;{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/1297216065664/Praesident-gestaerkt-Tunesiens-Parlament-entmachtet-sich |title=Tunesiens Parlament entmachtet sich |work=Der Standard |accessdate=11 February 2011}} He has previously stated Tunisia would accede to the [[International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance]], the [[Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court|Rome Statute]] of the [[International Criminal Court]], the [[Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment]], and the [[First Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights|First]] and [[Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (which would mean abolishing the death penalty).{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/tunisia_286/france-and-tunisia_5166/political-relations_5169/tunisia-endorsement-of-major-international-commitments-relating-to-human-rights-02.02.11_14974.html |title=France-Diplomatie |publisher=Diplomatie.gouv.fr |accessdate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628203902/http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/tunisia_286/france-and-tunisia_5166/political-relations_5169/tunisia-endorsement-of-major-international-commitments-relating-to-human-rights-02.02.11_14974.html |archivedate=28 June 2011 }} * 19 February - Protests flare up again, with 40,000 protesters demanding a new interim government completely free of any people associated with the old regime. Protesters also demand a parliamentary system of government instead of the current presidential one.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/world/tunisia-protests-resume-for-second-straight-day-amid-uncertainty-of-future-government-1.344628 |title=Tunisia protests resume for second straight day amid uncertainty of future government |work=Haaretz |location=Israel |date=18 January 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7294037.html |title=Thousands call for setting up parliamentary system in Tunisia – People's Daily Online |work=People's Daily |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} ==Caid Essebsi government== As a date was announced for an [[Tunisian general election, 2011|election]] in mid-July 2011, more than 100,000 protesters continued to demand the removal of Ghannouchi as interim prime minister.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/167012.html |title=PressTV – Tunisians want PM Ghannouchi gone |publisher=Press TV |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304232450/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/167012.html |archivedate=4 March 2011 }} * 27 February - After an even larger rally Ghannouchi resigns, saying: "After having taken more than one week of thinking, I became convinced, and my family shared my conviction, and decided to resign. It is not fleeing my responsibilities; I have been shouldering my responsibilities since 14 January [when Mr Ben Ali fled]," and "I am not ready to be the person who takes decisions that would end up causing casualties. This resignation will serve Tunisia, and the revolution and the future of Tunisia."{{Cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12591445 | title = Tunisian PM Mohammed Ghannouchi resigns over protests | publisher=BBC | date=27 February 2011}}{{Cite news| title = Tunisian prime minister resigns amid renewed protests | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/27/tunisia.government/ | publisher=CNN | date=1 April 2011}} [[Béji Caïd Essebsi]] becomes Prime Minister * 28 February - Two more ministers resign (industry minister [[Afif Chelbi]] and international co-operation minister [[Mohamed Nouri Jouini]]) amid continuing protests for the entire interim government to resign, with the UGTT calling for an elected constituent assembly to write a new constitution.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c98b8226-4382-11e0-8f0d-00144feabdc0.html |title=/ Middle East & North Africa – Two more Tunisian ministers resign |work=Financial Times |accessdate=1 March 2011}} * 1 March - The [[Ennahda Movement]] is legalised.{{cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZW20110301000110 |title=Zawya |publisher=Zawya |accessdate=23 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810061035/http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZW20110301000110 |archivedate=10 August 2011 }} The resignations of the Minister for Higher Education and Scientific Research [[Ahmed Brahim (politician)|Ahmed Brahim]]{{cite news | title=Tunisia Minister of Higher Education Ahmed Brahim Tells Reuters | publisher=Reuters | date=1 March 2011}} and the Minister of Local Development [[Ahmed Nejib Chebbi]] are officially announced by the [[Tunis Afrique Presse]] (TAP) agency. A private radio broadcaster [[Shems FM]] also reported that the Minister of Economic Reform [[Elyes Jouini]] had resigned as well.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/201131134458332348.html |title=Tunisian ministers continue to quit |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=22 June 2011}} * 3 March - President Mebazaa announces that [[Tunisian Constituent Assembly election, 2011|elections to a Constituent Assembly]] would be held on 24 July 2011; this likely means that [[Tunisian general election, 2011|general elections]] will be postponed to a later date.{{cite web|url=http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n243650 |title=Tunisia to elect constituent assembly on 24 July, says president – FOCUS Information Agency |publisher=Focus-fen.net |accessdate=22 June 2011}} This fulfilled a central demand of protesters.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7308013.html |title=Tunisia's interim president announces election of constitutional council – People's Daily Online |work=People's Daily |date=4 March 2011 |accessdate=22 June 2011}} * 7 March - The interim government announces that the secret police will be dissolved, one of the hallmarks of Ben Ali's rule.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12669461 | publisher=BBC News | title=Tunisia interim leaders dissolve secret police agency | date=7 March 2011}} * 9 March - A court in Tunis announces the dissolution of the former ruling party, the Rally for Constitutional Democracy (RCD), and the liquidation of its assets and funds, but the party said it would appeal the decision.{{cite news |title=Tunisia dissolves Ben Ali party |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/20113985941974579.html|date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=9 March 2011}} * 14 April - It is announced that Ben Ali will face 18 charges, including voluntary manslaughter and drug-trafficking. His family and former ministers are also going to face 26 further charges.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13082028 | publisher=BBC News | title=Tunisia's former President Ben Ali faces 18 charges | date=14 April 2011}} * 23 October - Tunisians vote for the first time post-revolution. The election appointed members to a [[Constituent Assembly of Tunisia|Constituent Assembly]] charged with rewriting Tunisia's Constitution. The formerly banned Islamic party Ennahda won by capturing 41% of the total vote.{{cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/world/jan-june12/tunisia_02-15.html|title="Post Revolution Tunisia Attempts Painful Transition to Democracy" PBS Newshour|date=15 February 2012}} ==Reactions== ===Domestic=== Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi's government asked Saudi Arabia to extradite Ben Ali saying that "following a new batch of charges against the ousted president regarding his involvement in several serious crimes aimed at perpetrating and inciting voluntary homicide and sowing discord between the citizens of the same country by pushing them to kill one another."{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g1FkUvosmNAcR0vpAT99VQg3f_tg?docId=CNG.2fa97f53bfcdc1875eb8f281d95222b2.601 |title=AFP: Tunisia asks Saudi Arabia to extradite Ben Ali |publisher=Google |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525115936/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g1FkUvosmNAcR0vpAT99VQg3f_tg?docId=CNG.2fa97f53bfcdc1875eb8f281d95222b2.601 |archivedate=25 May 2012 }} Reports emerged on 18 February 2011 that Ben Ali had had a stroke and was gravely ill.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12497988 |title=Tunisia's Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali 'seriously ill' |publisher=BBC News |date=17 February 2011|accessdate=20 February 2011}} Plans for a general amnesty were also announced on that day.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7293137.html |title=Tunisian PM says general amnesty to be proclaimed this week – People's Daily Online |work=People's Daily |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} ===Refugees=== In mid-February 2011, about 4,000 mostly Tunisian refugees landed on the Italian island of [[Lampedusa]], causing the authorities to declare a state of emergency{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/02/20112122328974957.html |title=Italy declares migrant emergency – Europe |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=13 February 2011}} that would allow for federal aid to the island. Interior Minister [[Roberto Maroni]] accused the EU of not doing enough to curb immigration and asked them to do more.{{cite news|agency=Agenzia Giornalistica Italia |url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/world/elenco-notizie/201102112043-pol-ren1094-tunisia_italy_asks_eu_to_start_frontex_mission |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110629122522/http://www.agi.it/english-version/world/elenco-notizie/201102112043-pol-ren1094-tunisia_italy_asks_eu_to_start_frontex_mission |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 June 2011 |title=Tunisia: Italy Asks Eu To Start Frontex Mission |publisher=Agi.it |accessdate=13 February 2011 }} He said that the "Tunisian system was 'collapsing'" and that he would "ask the Tunisian Foreign Ministry for permission for our authorities to intervene to stop the flow in Tunisia," suggesting Italian troops would be on Tunisian soil.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12443740 |title=Italy 'to deploy police to Tunisia' to tackle migration |publisher=BBC News |date=13 February 2011|accessdate=13 February 2011}} He called the event a "biblical exodus." The comments started a row between the two countries with the Tunisian Foreign Ministry saying it was ready to work with Italy and others but that it "categorically rejects any interference in its internal affairs or any infringement of its sovereignty." In response, Italy's Foreign Minister [[Franco Frattini]] said that both countries share a "common interest" to halt the immigration, while he also offered "logistical help in terms of police and equipment. Until now the system of patrolling the coasts of Northern Africa has worked and we want to re-establish the technique, which had reduced illegal immigration to zero until a month ago." Tunisia then said that it had troops patrolling southern fishing ports and that checkpoints had been erected in coastal towns. By 14 February, at least 2,000 refugees had been sent to [[Sicily]] with the other 2,000 [[quarantine]]d at a re-opened holding centre. On 2 March about 350 more people arrived on the island. In response Italy declared a humanitarian emergency.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/03/201132135258524383.html |title=Tunisian migrants land in Italy |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=22 June 2011}} The [[International Organisation for Migration]] said that no new boats had been spotted. The EU's Catherine Ashton was on a visit to Tunisia to discuss the issue. German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said that "not everyone who does not want to be in Tunisia can come to Europe. Rather, we need to talk to each other how we can strengthen the rule of law in Tunisia again and whether Europe can be of help."{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/02/2011214133653175984.html |title=Italy struggles with Tunisia influx – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}} ;Other The national stock market, the [[Bourse de Tunis|TUNINDEX]], fell on 12 January for a three consecutive day loss of 9.3%.{{cite web |url=http://www.africanmanager.com/site_eng/detail_article.php?art_id=16151 |title=Tunisia: further decline in Tunis stock market for third consecutive day |publisher=Africanmanager.com |accessdate=15 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707094758/http://www.africanmanager.com/site_eng/detail_article.php?art_id=16151 |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Following the curfew in Tunis, the market index again fell 3.8% as the cost of protecting against a sovereign default in [[credit default swaps]] rose to its highest level in almost two years.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-13/tunisia-stocks-slump-to-year-low-as-troops-deployed-to-tunis-amid-curfew.html|title=Tunisia Stocks Slump to Year-Low as Troops Deployed to Tunis Amid Curfew|author=Namatalla, Ahmed | work=Bloomberg|date=13 January 2011}}{{Cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE70C11W20110113|title=Tunisia c.bank CDS at 18-mth high of 154 bps-CMA | agency=Reuters | date=13 January 2011}} Following Ghanoucchi and two other Ben Ali-era ministers resigning, the bourse was again suspended.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/28/tunisia-government-jouini-idUSLDE71R2G620110228 |title=Second Tunisian minister quits, bourse suspended |agency=Reuters |date=28 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}} ===International and non-state=== {{main|International reactions to the Tunisian revolution}} [[File:Manif tunisie Nantes.JPG|thumb|Demonstration in support of the Tunisian protests in [[Nantes]], France, 15 January 2011.]] Many governments and supranational organisations expressed concerns over use of force against protesters. France, the former colonial power of Tunisia, was one of just a few states that expressed strong support for the Ben Ali government prior to its ouster, though protests were held in solidarity with Tunisia in several French cities and the [[French Socialist Party]] voiced support for the popular revolution. ===Media and punditry=== [[File:The rest will follow (2010–2011 Arab world protests).jpg|thumb|left|"The rest will follow". Symbolic middle finger gesture representing the Tunisian Revolution and its influences in the Arab world. From left to right, the fingers are painted as flags of [[Flag of Libya|Libya]], [[Flag of Egypt|Egypt]], [[Flag of Tunisia|Tunisia]], [[Flag of Sudan|Sudan]] and [[Flag of algeria|Algeria]]. The red-painted hand may be interpreted as a symbol of revolution]] The protests and resultant political crisis have generally been called the ''Jasmine revolution''' only in the foreign media.{{Cite news|first=Mona |last=Eltahawy |title=Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/14/AR2011011405084.html|work=The Washington Post|date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}}[[Mona Eltahawy]]{{Cite news|title=Tunisia's 'Jasmine Revolution' jolts Arab world|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/2/8/3955/World/Region/Tunisias-Jasmine-Revolution-jolts-Arab-world.aspx|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |publisher=Ahram Online |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} Tunisian philosopher [[Youssef Seddik (philosopher)|Youssef Seddik]] deemed the term inappropriate because the violence that accompanied the event was "perhaps as deep as [[Bastille Day]],"{{cite web |url=http://www.sudouest.fr/2011/01/16/une-prise-de-la-bastille-291463-652.php |title=Tunisie : " Une prise de la Bastille " |author=Béziat, Bruno |date=16 January 2011 |work=Sud Ouest|accessdate=17 January 2011}} and although the term was coined by the Tunisian journalist Zied El Hani, who first used it on his blog on 13 January and initially spread via social media such as Facebook (hence "Revolution Facebook" amongst the youth of Tunisia),{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/revolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html |title="Révolution du jasmin" : une expression qui ne fait pas l'unanimité |work=Le Monde |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=30 March 2011}} it is not in widespread use in Tunisia itself.{{cite web|author=Frangeul, Frédéric |url=http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ |title=D'où vient la "révolution du jasmin" ? |publisher=Europe 1 |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011 |language=french |trans-title=From where does the "Jasmin Revolution" come from?}} ([https://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.europe1.fr%2FInternational%2FD-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743%2F Google Translate version]) The lack of coverage in the domestic state-controlled media was criticised. Writer/activist [[Jillian York]] alleged that the [[mainstream media]], particularly in the Western world, was providing less coverage and less sympathetic coverage to the Tunisia protests relative to Iranian protests and the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green movement]] and China's censorship. York alleged the "US government—which intervened heavily in Iran, approving circumvention technology for export and famously asking Twitter to halt updates during a critical time period—has not made any public overtures toward Tunisia at this time."{{cite web|author=York, Jillian |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/20111981222719974.html |title=Activist crackdown: Tunisia vs Iran – Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Despite criticism about the "sparse" level of coverage and "little interest" given to the demonstrations by the international media, the protests were hailed by some commentators as "momentous events" in Tunisian history. [[Brian Whitaker]], writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', suggested on 28 December 2010, that the protests would be enough to bring an end to Ben Ali's presidency and noted similarities with the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|protests]] that led to the end of [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]]'s reign in [[Romania]] in 1989,{{Cite news|author=Whitaker, Brian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/dec/28/tunisia-ben-ali|title=How a man setting fire to himself sparked an uprising in Tunisia|date=28 December 2010|work=The Guardian |location=UK|accessdate=28 December 2010}} although Steven Cook, writing for the [[Council of Foreign Relations]], notes that a [[Tipping point (sociology)|tipping point]] is only obvious after the fact, and points to the counter-example of the [[2009-2010 Iranian election protests]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/cook/2011/01/06/the-last-days-of-ben-ali/ |title=The Last Days of Ben Ali? |publisher=Steven Cook's Blog |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Ben Ali's governing strategy was nevertheless regarded as in serious trouble, and [[Elliot Abrams]] noted both that demonstrators were able for the first time at the end of 2010 to defy the security forces and that the regime had no obvious successors outside of Ben Ali's own family.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/abrams/2011/01/07/is-tunisia-next/ |title=Is Tunisia Next? |publisher=Elliott Abrams: Pressure Points |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} The French management of the crisis came under severe criticism{{cite web|url=http://www.lepost.fr/article/2011/01/15/2371842_la-calamiteuse-gestion-de-la-crise-tunisienne-par-la-diplomatie-francaise.html |title=La calamiteuse gestion de la crise tunisienne par la diplomatie française – calvero sur |publisher=Lepost.fr |accessdate=26 January 2011}} with notable silence in the mainstream media in the run-up to the crisis with its former protectorate with which it maintained friendly relations.{{cite web|first=Claire |last=Ulrich |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/16/france-our-embarassing-ex-friend-monsieur-ben-ali/ |title=France: Our Embarrassing Ex Friend, Monsieur Ben Ali |publisher=Global Voices |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} ==Repercussion analysis== ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' believed the ousting of the president meant the "glass ceiling of fear has been for ever shattered in Tunisia and that the police state that Ben Ali created in 1987 when he came to power in a coup seems to be disintegrating", though it added that Ben Ali's resignation, following his statement that he had been "duped by his entourage" may not entirely be sincere. ''[[Le Monde]]'' criticised French President Nicolas Sarkozy and the European Union's "Silence over the Tragedy" when the unrest broke.{{cite web|author=Ahelbarra, Hashem |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/2011/01/14/tunisia-end-era |title=Tunisia: The end of an era | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |accessdate=15 January 2011}} The ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' suggested that [[mobile telecommunications]] played an influential role in the "revolution."{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0115/Tunisia-s-Jasmine-Revolution-and-how-mobile-phones-helped-it-happen |title=Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution, and how mobile phones helped it happen |work=The Christian Science Monitor |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} The revolt in Tunisia began speculation that the Tunisian Jasmine Revolution would lead to protests against the multiple other autocratic regimes across the [[Arab world]]. This was most famously captured in the phrase asking whether "Tunisia is the Arab [[Gdańsk]]?". The allusion refers to the Polish [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity movement]] and Gdańsk's role as the birthplace of the movement that [[Collapse of Communism|ousted Communism in Eastern Europe]]. The phrase appeared in outlets such as the [[BBC]],{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9362000/9362677.stm |title=Today – Is this the 'Arab world's Gdansk?' |publisher=BBC News |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} as well as editorials by well known columnists [[Rami George Khouri|Rami Khouri]]{{cite web|url=http://mondoweiss.net/2011/01/khouri-tunisia-is-gdansk-shipyard-of-80-with-jazeera-as-megaphone-to-other-arab-countries.html |title=Khouri: Tunisia is Gdansk shipyard of ‘80 with Jazeera as megaphone to other Arab countries! |publisher=Mondoweiss.net |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and [[Roger Cohen]].{{Cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/18/opinion/18iht-edcohen18.html | title = The Arab Gdansk | accessdate=28 January 2011 | author=Cohen, Roger |work=The New York Times | date=17 January 2011}} [[Larbi Sadiki]] suggested that although "conventional wisdom has it that 'terror' in the Arab world is monopolised by al-Qaeda in its various incarnations", there was also the fact that "regimes in countries like Tunisia and Algeria have been arming and training security apparatuses to fight Osama bin Laden [but] were [still] caught unawares by the 'bin Laden within': the terror of marginalisation for the millions of educated youth who make up a large portion of the region's population. The winds of uncertainty blowing in the Arab west – the [[Maghreb]] – threaten to blow eastwards towards the [[Levant]] as the marginalised issue the fatalistic scream of despair to be given freedom and bread or death."{{cite web|author=Sadiki, Larbi |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/201111413424337867.html |title=The 'bin Laden' of marginalisation – Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=15 January 2011}} A similar opinion by [[Lamis Ardoni]] carried by Al Jazeera said that the protests had "brought down the walls of fear, erected by repression and marginalisation, thus restoring the Arab peoples' faith in their ability to demand social justice and end tyranny." He also said that the protests that succeeded in toppling the leadership should serve as a "warning to all leaders, whether supported by international or regional powers, that they are no longer immune to popular outcries of fury" even though Tunisia's ostensible change "could still be contained or confiscated by the country's ruling elite, which is desperately clinging to power." He called the protests the "Tunisian [[wikt:intifada|intifada"]] which had "placed the Arab world at a crossroads." He further added that if the change was ultimately successful in Tunisia it could "push the door wide open to freedom in Arab word {{sic}}. If it suffers a setback we shall witness unprecedented repression by rulers struggling to maintain their absolute grip on power. Either way, a system that combined a starkly unequal distribution of wealth with the denial of freedoms has collapsed."{{cite web|author=Andoni, Lamis|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/2011115135046129936.html |title=To the tyrants of the Arab world... |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Similarly, [[Mark LeVine]] noted that the events in Tunisia could spiral into the rest of the [[Arab world]] as the movement was "inspiring people...to take to the streets and warn their own sclerotic and autocratic leaders that they could soon face a similar fate." He then cited solidarity protests in Egypt where protesters chanted "[[Kefaya]]" and "We are next, we are next, Ben Ali tell Mubarak he is next;" and that Arab bloggers were supporting the movement in Tunisia as "the African revolution commencing...the global anti-capitalist revolution." He pointed to an article in ''[[al-Nahar]]'' that talked of an "inhuman globalisation" that had been imposed on the Arab world, however a "human" nationalism had not taken place. LeVine then accused the Obama administration in the United States of double standards when Clinton was in the region meeting with political and civil society leaders; however, she responded to a question about the protests, saying "We can't take sides", which was read{{By whom|date=March 2015}} as a failure to seize the "[[rein]]s of history" and "usher in a new era" to "defeat the forces of extremism" without the violent conflict in the Afghanistan-Pakistan area. Pointing out Clinton's remarks about regimes whose "foundations are sinking into the sand" and needed "reform", LeVine argued that US foreign policy in the Middle East and the [[ummah|Muslim world]] was "equally in danger of sinking into the sands if the President and his senior officials are not willing to get ahead of history's suddenly accelerating curve." He added, "It is the US and Europe, as much as the leaders of the region, who in Clinton's words are in need of 'a real vision for that future.'" Finally he said there were two scenarios that could play out: "a greater democratic opening across the Arab world," or a similar situation to Algeria in the early 1990s when the [[Algerian legislative election, 1991|democratic election]] was annulled and Algeria went into a [[Algerian Civil War|civil war]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/20111167156465567.html|title=Tunisia: How the US got it wrong}} [[Robert Fisk]] asked if this was "The end of the age of dictators in the Arab world?" and partly answered the question in saying that Arab leaders would be "shaking in their boots". He also pointed out that the "despot" Ben Ali sought refuge in the same place as the ousted [[Idi Amin]] of [[Uganda]] and that "the French and the Germans and the Brits, dare we mention this, always praised the dictator for being a 'friend' of civilised Europe, keeping a firm hand on all those Islamists." He notably pointed at the "demographic explosion of youth" of the Maghreb, though he said that the change brought about in Tunisia may not last. He thinks "this is going to be the same old story. Yes, we would like a democracy in Tunisia – but not too much democracy. Remember how we wanted Algeria to have a democracy back in the early Nineties? Then when it looked like the Islamists might win the second round of voting, we supported its military-backed government in suspending elections and crushing the Islamists and initiating a civil war in which 150,000 died. No, in the Arab world, we want law and order and stability." He added that "If it can happen in the holiday destination Tunisia, it can happen anywhere, can't it?"{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/fisk/the-brutal-truth-about-tunisia-2186287.html|title=The brutal truth about Tunisia|work=The Independent | location=London|first=Robert|last=Fisk|date=17 January 2011}} Blake Hounshell wrote on Foreign Policy.com that the Tunisian precedent raised the prospect of a "new trend. There is something horrifying and, in a way, moving about these suicide attempts. It's a shocking, desperate tactic that instantly attracts attention, revulsion, but also sympathy."https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-12206551 Accessed 26/12/2016 ===Impact of the Internet=== {{further|Internet#Politics and political revolutions}} The use of communication technologies, and the Internet in particular, has been widely credited as contributor to the mobilisation of protests.Kravets, David. (22 August 2013) [https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/ Threat Level]. ''Wired''. Retrieved 9 September 2013. A blog associated with ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' described the intricate efforts of the Tunisian authorities to control such online media as{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/01/tunisia/|title=Tweeting Tyrants Out of Tunisia: Global Internet at Its Best|publisher=Threat Level / Wired | first1=Nate|last1=Anderson|first2=Ars|last2=Technica|date=14 January 2011}} Twitter and Facebook. Other regional regimes were also on higher alert to contain spillover effects that may ensue. On 11 March 2011, [[Reporters Without Borders]] gave its annual award for online media freedom to the Tunisian blogging group [[Nawaat.org]]. Founded in 2004, it played an important role rallying anti-government protesters by reporting on the protests which the national media ignored.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110314155555/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jn6P6Y2M4esLbvifHY0Foqb2vQTA?docId=361d3296b81a471bbfffeccbe1202202 Tunisian bloggers win online media award], [[Associated Press|AP]], 11 March 2011 ==Regional instability== {{main|Arab Spring}} {{see also|Mohamed Bouazizi#Copycat incidents}} Bouazizi's actions resonated across the region, with many others across the Arab world following suit. In January 2011, the BBC reported: "Clearly the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi has resonated across the region...'There is great interest. The Egyptian people and the Egyptian public have been following the events in Tunisia with so much joy, since they can draw parallels between the Tunisian situation and their own.'"{{Cite news|last=Westcott |first=Kathryn |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-12206551 |title=Why do people set themselves on fire? |publisher=BBC News |date=18 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} After the beginning of the uprising in Tunisia, similar protests took place in almost all Arab countries from [[Morocco]] to [[Iraq]], as well as in other states, ranging from [[Gabon]] to [[Albania]], Iran, [[Kazakhstan]], [[2011 United States public employee protests|United States]], [[2011 Indian anti-corruption movement|India]] and others. Following [[2011 Egyptian revolution|weeks of protests]], Egyptian president [[Hosni Mubarak]] resigned on 11 February. Major protests against longtime Libyan leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] broke out on 17 February and quickly deteriorated into [[2011 Libyan civil war|civil war]], ultimately resulting in the downfall of the Gaddafi regime later in the year. [[2011 Syrian uprising|Syria]] experienced a major uprising of people calling for the removal of President [[Bashar al-Assad]]. The Syrian uprising also deteriorated into a [[Syrian Civil War|civil war]], giving rise to the militant group, [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]], and partly causing the current [[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War|refugee crisis]]. In addition, [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahrain]], and [[2011 Algerian protests|Algeria]] have seen major protests. However, a financial analyst in [[Dubai]] suggested that "the spillover effect of the political turbulence to the large countries in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] is non-existent as there are no similar drivers."{{cite news|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/dubai-shares-plunge-most-in-year-lead-gulf-drop-on-egypt-risk-protests.html |title=Dubai Shares Fall Most Since May on Egypt Unrest, Pacing Mideast Decline |publisher=Bloomberg |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}} ==Aftermath== In mid-May 2013, Tunisia banned the Salafist [[Ansar al-Sharia (Tunisia)|Ansar al-Sharia]] from carrying out party congresses. The day after the congress was due to be carried out, clashes between security forces and party supporters in [[Kairouan]] resulted in one death amid attempts to disperse those who wanted to carry out the events.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/05/20135198155650292.html Salafist group clashes with police in Tunisia – Africa]. ''Al Jazeera''. 20 May 2013. The Tunisian president, Beji Caid Essebsi, renewed the state of emergency in October 2015 for three months due to previous terror attacks.{{Cite news|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/10/why-is-the-state-of-emergency-renewed-three-times-tunisia.html|title=The real reason Tunisia renewed its state of emergency|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|via=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220140248/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/10/why-is-the-state-of-emergency-renewed-three-times-tunisia.html|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==See also== {{Portal|Tunisia|Human rights}} * [[Art and politics in post-2011 Tunisia]] * [[Lebanese Civil War]] * [[List of conflicts in Africa]] * [[List of modern {{Orphan|date=August 2018}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = USA Freedom Kids | image = File:USA Freedom Kids logo.png | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = | background = group_or_band <!-- mandatory format: please do not change or remove --> | alias = | origin = [[Naples, Florida]], U.S. | genre = | years_active = {{start date|2015}} – present | label = | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|www.usafreedomkids.com}} | current_members = {{Flatlist| * Alexis * Bianca * Izzy * Sarah * Victoria }} | past_members = }}
'''USA Freedom Kids''', sometimes referred to as '''USA Freedom Girls''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teenvogue.com/story/usa-freedom-girls-sue-trump-campaign-15000k|title=Why This All-Girls Singing Group Is Suing Donald Trump for $15,000|first=Laura|last=Stampler|publisher=|work=Teen Vogue}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-usa-freedom-kids-2016-1|title=Here's the story behind the incredible performance by 3 young children at a Donald Trump rally|publisher=|work=[[Business Insider]]}}</ref> is a dancing girl group, known for performing to their song "Freedom's Call" at a [[Donald Trump]] rally in [[Pensacola, Florida]], in January 2016 during his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]].
==History== {{As of|2016}}, there were 5 girls in USA Freedom Kids: Alexis, age 8, Bianca, age 11, Izzy, age 11, Sarah, age 13, and Victoria, age 12. The group was formed and is managed by Alexis{{'}} father, Jeff Popick,<ref name=IE>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideedition.com/headlines/14106-usa-freedom-kids-trump-says-hell-listen-to-our-cd-all-night|title=USA Freedom Kids: Trump Says He'll Listen to Our CD All Night|work=[[Inside Edition]]|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/video/usa-freedom-kids-video-001|title=Watch Our Interview with the Patriotic Preteen Girls Singing Donald Trump's Praises|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref> a former television stunt man and Trump supporter.<ref name=Flores/> They came together from a casting call. Sarah, a member of the group has been blind since birth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=LOW1aG78alI|date=February 12, 2016|publisher=Vice Media|title=Behind the Music: Donald Trump's USA Freedom Kids by VICE MEDIA}}</ref> The group is from [[Naples, Florida]].<ref name=People>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/politics/donald-trumps-usa-freedom-kids-do-a-song-and-dance-at-convention/|title=Donald Trump's USA Freedom Kids Do a Song and Dance at Convention|date=21 July 2016|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref>
Bianca, Alexis, and Elena performed the song "Freedom's Call" at the January 13, 2016 [[Donald Trump]] rally in [[Pensacola, Florida]], during his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]].<ref name=People/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/28/us/politics/trump-freedom-kids.html|title=USA Freedom Kids Are in Dispute with Trump|date=28 July 2016|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name="Flores">{{cite news|last1=Flores|first1=Reena|title=At Trump rally, USA Freedom Kids flaunt their "Ameritude"|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/at-trump-rally-usa-freedom-kids-flaunt-their-ameritude/|accessdate=November 12, 2016|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=January 15, 2016}}</ref> The performance was viewed more than 2 million times on YouTube by January 15.<ref name=Billboard>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6843988/usa-freedom-kids-donald-trump-rally-video|title='USA Freedom Kids' Sing About 'Crushing' Enemies at Donald Trump Rally, Performance Goes Viral|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref> "Freedom's Call" was written by Popick and is sung to the tune of [[George M. Cohan]]'s "[[Over There]]" (1917), which was popularized during World Wars I and II.<ref name=IE/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/live-from-charleston/2016/01/donald-trump-song-usa-freedom-kids-217791|title=The complete lyrics to the infectious 'USA Freedom Kids' song from the Donald Trump rally|first=Nick|last=Gass|accessdate=November 12, 2016|date=January 14, 2016|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref>
The group also performed in front of the [[Rock & Roll Hall of Fame]] at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]] in Cleveland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/usa-freedom-kids-sing-at-rnc-in-cleveland-/277261420|title=USA Freedom Kids sing at RNC in Cleveland|first=|last=|publisher=WKYC|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref>
On August 30, 2016, Popick sued the Trump campaign for failing to let the group sell CDs at a rally and for canceling their performance in Des Moines, Iowa.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/07/politics/usa-freedom-kids-lawsuit-trump/index.html |title=USA Freedom Kids v. Donald Trump: Dancing kids group sues |first=Eli |last=Watkins |work=[[CNN]] |date=September 7, 2016 |access-date=April 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/09/07/here-it-is-usa-freedom-kids-v-donald-j-trump-for-president-inc/ |title=Here it is: USA Freedom Kids v. Donald J. Trump for President Inc. |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Philip |last=Bump |date=September 7, 2016 |access-date=April 11, 2017}}</ref> The lawsuit was voluntarily dropped on December 13, 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.naplesnews.com/story/news/2016/12/19/usa-freedom-kids-drops-lawsuit-against-trump-campaign/95346680/ |title=USA Freedom Kids drops lawsuit against Trump campaign |newspaper=[[Naples Daily News]] |first=Maryann |last=Batile |date=December 19, 2016 |access-date=April 11, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== In response to the group's January 2016 performance, Sophie Gilbert of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' said, "To quote ''New Girl'', this is what every day is like in North Korea."<ref name=Billboard/> ''[[The Huffington Post]]''{{'}} Paul Blumenthal tweeted: "Unsurprisingly, American fascism is kind of tacky."<ref name=Billboard/> [[James Corden]] of ''[[The Late Late Show with James Corden|The Late Late Show]]'' called the performance "horrific".<ref name=IE/> Glen Weldon, an [[NPR]] pop culture contributor, said in disbelief, "I don't. Is this. What."<ref name=Billboard/>
The USA Freedom Kids were named one of the "45 Americans Who Defined the Election" by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/2016-election-americans/|title=45 Americans Who Defined the Election|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2016}}</ref>
==Parodies== The group was parodied by ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', who had the "Number One America Liberty Children" perform a song in support of [[Jeb Bush]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/shows/jimmy-kimmel-live/video/featured/VDKA0_bvctesnr|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|title=Jeb Bush Gets His Own USA Freedom Kids|accessdate=November 12, 2016}}</ref>
The parody group "USA Freedom Grown-Ups", comprising four women and one man,<ref name=Moran>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/usa-freedom-grown-ups-trump_us_57a45e6ae4b021fd98783adc|title=The USA Freedom Grown-Ups Are Donald Trump's Worst Nightmare|first1=Lee Moran Trends|last1=Editor|first2=The Huffington Post|last2=Post|date=5 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref> performed on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/comedy/2016/8/09/song-when-donald-trump-cheats-singing-children-money-video|title=A Song for When Donald Trump Cheats Singing Children of Money (Video)|date=9 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2016|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/stephen-colbert-taunts-trump-his-usa-freedom-grown-240677|title=Stephen Colbert taunts Trump with his "USA Freedom Grown-Ups"|date=August 5, 2016|work=The A.V. Club|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref> Colbert introduced the group by saying, "Well folks, Donald Trump thinks he can get away with [neglecting to pay the group], but I'm going to hold him accountable and get his attention with a flashy song-and-dance number. And because I don't think children should be involved in the dirty world of politics, here with a new song for Donald Trump, please welcome the USA Freedom Grown-Ups."<ref name=Week>{{cite web|url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/641149/stephen-colbert-showcases-new-song-mock-donald-trump-stiffing-trio-young-girls|title=Stephen Colbert showcases new song to mock Donald Trump for stiffing trio of young girls|date=5 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2016|work=The Week}}</ref> The song was sung to the same tune as "Freedom's Call" and included the lyrics, "Don't be such a douche, pay your I-O-Youche"<ref name=Moran/> and "That might be your real hair, but you're a fake billionaire. Pay people what they've earned, and release your tax returns!"<ref name=Week/>

{{redirect|Jedność|the ship|SS Jedność}} '''Yedinstvo''' (literally: ''Unity'', {{lang-ru|Единство}}, {{lang-lt|Vienybė}}, {{lang-pl|Jedność}})<ref name=mgb>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lMgbPeeVg7IC&pg=PA97&dq=lithuania+jedinstvo&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES Political Transformation and Changing Identities in Central and Eastern Europe by Andrew M. Blasko, Diana Januauskiene, p. 97]</ref> was a pro-Moscow and anti-[[Sąjūdis]] movement in the [[Lithuanian SSR]] during the [[Perestroika]] era. The goals of the movement were similar to those of the [[International Front of the Working People of Latvia|Latvian]] and [[Intermovement|Estonian]] [[Interfront|Internationalist Movements]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=UJMzpeUHkQcC&pg=PA55&dq=lithuania+yedinstvo&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES Taming nationalism? by Dovile Budryte, p. 55]</ref> e.g. opposition to [[disintegration of the Soviet Union]]. Yedinstvo was supported by the Soviet military and the [[KGB]].
In addition to ethic Russians, the organization had some success among the [[Polish minority in Lithuania]], many{{specify|date=September 2016}} of whom preferred Lithuania as a member of the Soviet Union. Yedinstvo went as far as to support forming a [[Polish National-Territorial Region|Polish autonomous region]] in southeastern Lithuania.<ref name=mgb/> Some commentators suggested that the organization was more popular with the Polish minority than the Russophone minority of Lithuania,<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=CMDqCL_rEPgC&pg=PA253</ref> which might have surprised the Poles of Warsaw, then seeking a de-communization in Poland. At the election to the Soviet [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union|Congress of People's Deputies]], two Poles were elected to that body, both pro-Moscow.
The movement lost influence after the abortive [[August coup]] that its leaders had supported. Since 1991, the organization has been inactive.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JtxHWKJOBN4C&pg=RA1-PA238&dq=lithuania+yedinstvo&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES Ethnicity and electoral politics by Jóhanna Kristín Birnir, p. 238]</ref>
